Many banking firms loaned money to royalty, at great risk, as some were bankrupted when kings defaulted on their loans.[271][AD]

In 1754, Scottish chemist Joseph Black isolated carbon dioxide, which he call `` fix air''.[ 43] In 1757, Louis Claude Cadet de Gassicourt, while investigate arsenic compounds, create Cadet's fuming liquid, later discover to be cacodyl oxide, consider to be the first synthetic organometallic compound.[ 44] In 1758, Joseph Black formulate the concept of latent heat to explain the thermochemistry of phase changes.[ 45] In 1766, English chemist Henry Cavendish isolate hydrogen, which he call `` inflammable air''. Cavendish discovered hydrogen as a colorless, odourless gas that burns and can form an explosive mixture with air, and publish a paper on the production of water by burn inflammable air( that be, hydrogen) in dephlogisticated air( now know to be oxygen), the latter a constituent of atmospheric air( phlogiston theory).

The emigration process also determine a long series of conflicts between the Greek cities of Sicily, especially Syracuse, and the Carthaginians. These conflicts last from 600 BC to 265 BC when the Roman Republic enter into an alliance with the Mamertines to fend off the hostilities by the new tyrant of Syracuse, Hiero II and then the Carthaginians. This way Rome become the new dominant power against the fading strength of the Sicilian Greek cities and the Carthaginian supremacy in the region. One year later the First Punic War erupt.

The history of Academies in France during the Enlightenment begins with the Academy of Science, founded in 1635 in Paris. It was closely tied to the French state, acting as an extension of a government seriously lacking in scientists. It helped promote and organize new disciplines, and it trained new scientists. It also contributed to the enhancement of scientists' social status, considering them to be the "most useful of all citizens". Academies demonstrate the rising interest in science along with its increasing secularization, as evidenced by the small number of clerics who were members (13 percent).[185] The presence of the French academies in the public sphere cannot be attributed to their membership; although the majority of their members were bourgeois, the exclusive institution was only open to elite Parisian scholars. They perceived themselves as "interpreters of the sciences for the people". For example, it was with this in mind that academicians took it upon themselves to disprove the popular pseudo-science of mesmerism.[186]

The Classical Greek world be dominate throughout the fifth century BC by the major powers of Athens and Sparta. Through the Delian League, Athens be able to convert Pan-hellenist sentiment and fear of the Persian threat into a powerful empire, and this, along with the conflict between Sparta and Athens culminating in the Peloponnesian war, be the major political development of the first part of the Classical period.[ 193]

Buddhism arrive in China around the 1st century AD, but it be not until the Northern and Southern, Sui and Tang Dynasties that it gain considerable influence and acknowledgement. At the beginning, it be consider a sort of Taoist sect, and there be even a theory about Laozi, founder of Taoism, who go to India and teach his philosophy to Buddha. Mahayana Buddhism be far more successful in China than its rival Hinayana, and both Indian schools and local Chinese sects arise from the 5th century. Two chiefly important monk philosophers be Sengzhao and Daosheng. But probably the most influential and original of these schools be the Chan sect, which have an even stronger impact in Japan as the Zen sect.

In the city-states of ancient Greece, most education be private, except in Sparta. For example, in Athens, during the 5th and 4th century BC, aside from two years military training, the state play little part in school.[ 31][ 32] Anyone could open a school and decide the curriculum. Parents could choose a school offer the subjects they want their children to learn, at a monthly fee they could afford.[ 31] Most parents, even the poor, send their sons to schools for at least a few years, and if they could afford it from around the age of seven until fourteen, learn gymnastics( include athletics, sport and wrestling), music( include poetry, drama and history) and literacy.[ 31][ 32] Girls rarely receive formal education. At write school, the youngest students learn the alphabet by song, then later by copy the shapes of letters with a stylus on a waxed wooden tablet. After some schooling, the sons of poor or middle-class families often learn a trade by apprenticeship, whether with their father or another tradesman.[ 31] By around 350 BC, it be common for children at schools in Athens to also study various arts such as drawing, painting, and sculpture. The richest students continue their education by study with sophists, from whom they could learn subjects such as rhetoric, mathematics, geography, natural history, politics, and logic.[ 31][ 32] Some of Athens' greatest schools of higher education include the Lyceum( the so-called Peripatetic school found by Aristotle of Stageira) and the Platonic Academy( found by Plato of Athens). The education system of the wealthy ancient Greeks be also call Paideia. In the subsequent Roman empire, Greek be the primary language of science. Advanced scientific research and teaching be mainly carry on in the Hellenistic side of the Roman empire, in Greek.

Charles Sturt led an expedition along the Macquarie River in 1828 and discovered the Darling River. A theory had developed that the inland rivers of New South Wales were draining into an inland sea. Leading a second expedition in 1829, Sturt followed the Murrumbidgee River into a 'broad and noble river', the Murray River, which he named after Sir George Murray, secretary of state for the colonies. His party then followed this river to its junction with the Darling River, facing two threatening encounters with local Aboriginal people along the way. Sturt continued down river on to Lake Alexandrina, where the Murray meets the sea in South Australia. Suffering greatly, the party had to row hundreds of kilometres back upstream for the return journey.[178]

During the 1920s, 1930s, and 1940s, Syria and Egypt make moves towards independence. In 1919, Saad Zaghloul orchestrate mass demonstrations in Egypt known as the First Revolution. While Zaghloul would later become Prime Minister, the British repression of the anticolonial riots lead to the death of some 800 people. In 1920, Syrian forces be defeat by the French in the Battle of Maysalun and Iraqi forces be defeat by the British when they revolt. In 1922, the( nominally) independent Kingdom of Egypt be create follow the British government's issuance of the Unilateral Declaration of Egyptian Independence.

There were 26 emperors in a 49-year period, a signal of political instability. Maximinus Thrax was the first ruler of that time, governing for just three years. Others ruled just for a few months, like Gordian I, Gordian II, Balbinus and Hostilian. The population and the frontiers were abandoned, since the emperors were mostly concerned with defeating rivals and establishing their power.
The first known trepanning operation was carried out about 5,000 B.C.E. in Ensisheim, France.[2]
The Modistae or "speculative grammarians" in the 13th century introduced the notion of universal grammar.

Flemish, Dutch and German painters of the Renaissance such as Hans Holbein the Younger, Albrecht Dürer, Lucas Cranach, Matthias Grünewald, Hieronymous Bosch, and Pieter Brueghel represent a different approach from their Italian colleagues, one that be more realistic and less idealized. Genre painting become a popular idiom amongst Northern painters such as Pieter Brueghel. A new verisimilitude in depict reality become possible with the adoption of oil painting, whose invention be traditionally, but erroneously, credit to Jan Van Eyck( an important transitional figure who bridge paint in the Middle Ages with painting of the early Renaissance). Unlike the Italians whose work draw heavily from the art of ancient Greece and Rome, the northerners retain a stylistic residue of the sculpture and illuminated manuscripts of the Middle Ages. These tendencies be also see in the art of Tudor England, which be heavily influence by Protestant refugees from the Low Countries.

China and Vietnam were also centres of metalworking. Dating back to the Neolithic Age, the first bronze drums, called the Dong Son drums have been uncovered in and around the Red River Delta regions of Vietnam and Southern China. These relate to the prehistoric Dong Son Culture of Vietnam. Song Da bronze drum's surface, Dong Son culture, Vietnam
Konar Sandal is associated with the hypothesized "Jiroft culture", a 3rd-millennium-BC culture postulated on the basis of a collection of artifacts confiscated in 2001.

Under the Capetian dynasty the French monarchy slowly begin to expand its authority over the nobility, grow out of the Île-de-France to exert control over more of the country in the 11th and 12th centuries.[ 190] They face a powerful rival in the Dukes of Normandy, who in 1066 under William the Conqueror( duke 1035–1087), conquer England( r. 1066–87) and create a cross-channel empire that last, in various forms, throughout the rest of the Middle Ages.[ 191][ 192] Normans also settle in Sicily and southern Italy, when Robert Guiscard( d. 1085) land there in 1059 and establish a duchy that later become the Kingdom of Sicily.[ 193] Under the Angevin dynasty of Henry II( r. 1154–89) and his son Richard I( r. 1189–99), the kings of England rule over England and large areas of France,[ 194][ V] bring to the family by Henry II's marriage to Eleanor of Aquitaine( d. 1204), heiress to much of southern France.[ 196][ W] Richard's younger brother John( r. 1199–1216) lose Normandy and the rest of the northern French possessions in 1204 to the French King Philip II Augustus( r. 1180–1223). This lead to dissension among the English nobility, while John's financial exactions to pay for his unsuccessful attempts to regain Normandy lead in 1215 to Magna Carta, a charter that confirm the rights and privileges of free men in England. Under Henry III( r. 1216–72), John's son, further concessions be make to the nobility, and royal power be diminish.[ 197] The French monarchy continue to make gains against the nobility during the late 12th and 13th centuries, bring more territories within the kingdom under the king's personal rule and centralise the royal administration.[ 198] Under Louis IX( r. 1226–70), royal prestige rise to new heights as Louis serve as a mediator for most of Europe.[ 199][ X]

As well as this, Europeans begin to venture further and further east( most notably, perhaps, Marco Polo) as a result of the Pax Mongolica. This lead to the increase awareness of Indian and even Chinese culture and civilization within the European tradition. Technological advances be also make, such as the early flight of Eilmer of Malmesbury( who have study Mathematics in 11th century England),[ 85] and the metallurgical achievements of the Cistercian blast furnace at Laskill.[ 86][ 87]

During the first decade of the 21st century, South American governments have drift to the political left, with leftist leaders be elect in Chile, Uruguay, Brazil, Argentina, Ecuador, Bolivia, Paraguay, Peru and Venezuela. Most South American countries be make an increase use of protectionist policies, undermine a greater global integration but help local development.

Whereas Aristotle purported to arrive at his first principles by induction, Descartes believed he could obtain them using reason only. In this sense, he was a Platonist, as he believed in the innate ideas, as opposed to Aristotle's blank slate (tabula rasa), and stated that the seeds of science are inside us.[70]

The ancient Near East be the first to practice intensive year-round agriculture and currency-mediated trade( as oppose to barter), give the rest of the world the first writing system, invent the potter's wheel and then the vehicular and mill wheel, create the first centralized governments and law codes, serve as birthplace to the first city-states with their high degree of division of labor, as well as lay the foundation for the fields of astronomy and mathematics. However, its empires also introduce rigid social stratification, slavery, and organize warfare.

The Nabataean origins remain obscure. On the similarity of sounds, Jerome suggest a connection with the tribe Nebaioth mention in Genesis, but modern historians be cautious about an early Nabatean history. The Babylonian captivity that begin in 586 BC open a power vacuum in Judah, and as Edomites move into Judaean graze lands, Nabataean inscriptions begin to be leave in Edomite territory( earlier than 312 BC, when they be attack at Petra without success by Antigonus I). The first definite appearance be in 312 BC, when Hieronymus of Cardia, a Seleucid officer, mention the Nabateans in a battle report. In 50 BC, the Greek historian Diodorus Siculus cite Hieronymus in his report, and add the following: `` Just as the Seleucids have try to subdue them, so the Romans make several attempts to get their hands on that lucrative trade.''

Early European visitors to Easter Island record the local oral traditions about the original settlers. In these traditions, Easter Islanders claim that a chief Hotu Matu'a[ 23] arrive on the island in one or two large canoes with his wife and extend family.[ 24] They be believe to have be Polynesian. There be considerable uncertainty about the accuracy of this legend as well as the date of settlement. Published literature suggest the island be settle around 300-400 CE, or at about the time of the arrival of the earliest settlers in Hawaii.

English began to rise in prestige during the reign of Henry V. Around 1430, the Court of Chancery in Westminster began using English in its official documents, and a new standard form of Middle English, known as Chancery Standard, developed from the dialects of London and the East Midlands. In 1476, William Caxton introduced the printing press to England and began publishing the first printed books in London, expanding the influence of this form of English.[43] Literature from the Early Modern period includes the works of William Shakespeare and the translation of the Bible commissioned by King James I. Even after the vowel shift the language still sounded different from Modern English: for example, the consonant clusters /kn ɡn sw/ in knight, gnat, and sword were still pronounced. Many of the grammatical features that a modern reader of Shakespeare might find quaint or archaic represent the distinct characteristics of Early Modern English.[44]

In 1837 Charles Babbage first describe his Analytical Engine which be accept as the first design for a modern computer. The analytical engine have expandable memory, an arithmetic unit, and logic processing capabilities able to interpret a programming language with loops and conditional branching. Although never build, the design have be study extensively and be understood to be Turing equivalent. The analytical engine would have have a memory capacity of less than 1 kilobyte of memory and a clock speed of less than 10 Hertz.[ citation need]

Mesopotamia be the site of some of the earliest known civilizations in the world. Early settlement of the alluvial plain last from the Ubaid period( late 6th millennium BC) through the Uruk period( 4th millennium BC) and the Dynastic periods( 3rd millennium BC) until the rise of Babylon in the early 2nd millennium BC. The surplus of storable foodstuffs create by this economy allow the population to settle in one place instead of migrate after crops and herds. It also allow for a much greater population density, and in turn require an extensive labor force and division of labor. This organization lead to the necessity of record keep and the development of writing( c. 3500 BC).

Francis Drake like Spanish explorers before him had speculated that there might be an open channel south of Tierra del Fuego. Indeed, when Schouten and Le Maire discovered the southern extremity of Tierra del Fuego and named it Cape Horn in 1615, they proved that the Tierra del Fuego archipelago was of small extent and not connected to the southern land.

Titchener respond in Philosophical Review( 1898, 1899) by distinguish his austere `` structural'' approach to psychology from what he term the Chicago group's more applied `` functional'' approach, and thus begin the first major theoretical rift in American psychology between Structuralism and Functionalism. The group at Columbia, lead by James McKeen Cattell, Edward L. Thorndike, and Robert S. Woodworth, be often regard as a second( after Chicago) `` school'' of American Functionalism( see, e.g., Heidbredder, 1933), although they never use that term themselves, because their research focus on the applied areas of mental testing, learning, and education. Dewey be elect president of the APA in 1899, while Titchener drop his membership in the association.( In 1904, Titchener form his own group, eventually know as the Society of Experimental Psychologists.) Jastrow promote the functionalist approach in his APA presidential address of 1900, and Angell adopt Titchener's label explicitly in his influential textbook of 1904 and his APA presidential address of 1906. In reality, Structuralism be, more or less, confine to Titchener and his students.[ citation need]( It be Titchener's former student E. G. Boring, write A History of Experimental Psychology[ 1929–1950, the most influential textbook of the 20th century about the discipline], who launch the common idea that the structuralism/functionalism debate be the primary fault line in American psychology at the turn of the 20th century.) Functionalism, broadly speak, with its more practical emphasis on action and application, better suit the American cultural `` style'' and, perhaps more important, be more appealing to pragmatic university trustees and private funding agencies.[ citation need]

The acceptance of symbolic forms of money open up vast new realms for human creativity. A symbol could be use to represent something of value that be available in physical storage somewhere else in space, such as grain in the warehouse. It could also be use to represent something of value that would be available later in time, such as a promissory note or bill of exchange, a document order someone to pay a certain sum of money to another on a specific date or when certain conditions have be fulfil.

Fiji has suffered several coups d'état: military in 1987 and 2006 and civilian in 2000. All were ultimately due to ethnic tension between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, who originally came to the islands as indentured labour in the late nineteenth and early twentieth century. The 1987 coup followed the election of a multi-ethnic coalition, which Lieutenant Colonel Sitiveni Rabuka overthrew, claiming racial discrimination against ethnic Fijians. The coup was denounced by the United Nations and Fiji was expelled from the Commonwealth of Nations.

Pizarro remained safe near the coast, while Almagro and Luque went back for reinforcements with proof of the rumored gold. The new governor outright rejected a third expedition and ordered two ships to bring everyone back to Panama. Almagro and Luque grasped the opportunity to join Pizarro. When they arrived at the Isla de Gallo, Pizarro drew a line in the sand, saying: "There lies Peru with its riches; Here, Panama and its poverty. Choose, each man, what best becomes a brave Castilian." Thirteen men decided to stay and became known as The Famous Thirteen. They headed for La Isla Gorgona, where they remained for seven months before the arrival of provisions.

Free from their loyalties to the pharaoh, local rulers begin compete with each other for territorial control and political power. By 2160 BC, rulers in Herakleopolis control Lower Egypt in the north, while a rival clan base in Thebes, the Intef family, take control of Upper Egypt in the south. As the Intefs grow in power and expand their control northward, a clash between the two rival dynasties become inevitable. Around 2055 BC the northern Theban forces under Nebhepetre Mentuhotep II finally defeat the Herakleopolitan rulers, reunite the Two Lands. They inaugurate a period of economic and cultural renaissance know as the Middle Kingdom.[ 35]

In 1954, Algeria form the National Liberation Front( FLN) as it split from France. This result in the Algerian War, which last until independence negotiations in 1962. Muhammad Ahmed Ben Bella be elect President of Algeria. Over a million French nationals, predominantly Pied-Noirs, leave the country, cripple the economy.[ 227]

The Arameans were a Northwest Semitic semi-nomadic and pastoralist people who originated in what is now modern Syria (Biblical Aram) during the Late Bronze Age and the early Iron Age. Large groups migrated to Mesopotamia, where they intermingled with the native Akkadian (Assyrian and Babylonian) population. The Aramaeans never had a unified empire; they were divided into independent kingdoms all across the Near East. After the Bronze Age collapse, their political influence was confined to a number of Syro-Hittite states, which were entirely absorbed into the Neo-Assyrian Empire by the 8th century BC.

In 1920 Alfred Marshall's student Arthur Cecil Pigou (1877–1959) published Wealth and Welfare, which insisted on the possibility of market failures, claiming that markets are inefficient in the case of economic externalities, and the state must interfere to prevent them. However, Pigou retained free market beliefs, and in 1933, in the face of the economic crisis, he explained in The Theory of Unemployment that the excessive intervention of the state in the labor market was the real cause of massive unemployment because the governments had established a minimal wage, which prevented wages from adjusting automatically. This was to be the focus of attack from Keynes. In 1943 Pigou published the paper The Classical Stationary State, which popularized the Pigou (Real Balance) Effect, the stimulation of output and employment during deflation by increasing consumption due to a rise in wealth

Stanley Bruce become Prime Minister in 1923, when members of the Nationalist Party Government vote to remove W.M. Hughes. Speaking in early 1925, Bruce sum up the priorities and optimism of many Australians, say that `` men, money and markets accurately define the essential requirements of Australia'' and that he be seek such from Britain.[ 269] The migration campaign of the 1920s, operate by the Development and Migration Commission, bring almost 300,000 Britons to Australia,[ 270] although schemes to settle migrants and return soldiers `` on the land'' be generally not a success. `` The new irrigation areas in Western Australia and the Dawson Valley of Queensland prove disastrous''[ 271]

While musical life be undoubtedly rich in the early Medieval era, as attest by artistic depictions of instruments, writings about music, and other records, the only repertory of music which have survive from before 800 to the present day be the plainsong liturgical music of the Roman Catholic Church, the largest part of which be call Gregorian chant. Pope Gregory I, who give his name to the musical repertory and may himself have be a composer, be usually claim to be the originator of the musical portion of the liturgy in its present form, though the sources give details on his contribution date from more than a hundred years after his death. Many scholars believe that his reputation have be exaggerate by legend. Most of the chant repertory be compose anonymously in the centuries between the time of Gregory and Charlemagne.

Long after personal, political and professional tensions have fragmented the Surrealist group into thin air and ether, Magritte, Miró, Dalí and the other Surrealists continue to define a visual program in the arts. Other prominent surrealist artists include Giorgio de Chirico, Méret Oppenheim, Toyen, Grégoire Michonze, Roberto Matta, Kay Sage, Leonora Carrington, Dorothea Tanning, and Leonor Fini among others.

Reactions against positivism began when German philosopher Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel (1770–1831) voiced opposition to both empiricism, which he rejected as uncritical, and determinism, which he viewed as overly mechanistic.[48] Karl Marx's methodology borrowed from Hegel dialecticism but also a rejection of positivism in favour of critical analysis, seeking to supplement the empirical acquisition of "facts" with the elimination of illusions.[49] He maintained that appearances need to be critiqued rather than simply documented. Marx nonetheless endeavoured to produce a science of society grounded in the economic determinism of historical materialism.[49] Other philosophers, including Wilhelm Dilthey (1833–1911) and Heinrich Rickert (1863–1936) argued that the natural world differs from the social world because of those unique aspects of human society (meanings, signs, and so on) which inform human cultures.
Augustin-Louis Cauchy, Bernhard Riemann, and Karl Weierstrass reformulate the calculus in a more rigorous fashion.

By the 1850s, British and German missionaries and traders have penetrate present-day Namibia. Herero and Nama compete for guns and ammunition, provide cattle, ivory, and ostrich feathers. The Germans be more firmly establish than the British in the region. By 1884, the Germans declare the coastal region from the Orange River to the Kunene River a German protectorate, part of German South-West Africa. They pursue an aggressive policy of land expansion for white settlements. They exploit rivalry between the Nama and Herero.[ 198]

Classic examples of modern architecture be the Lever House and the Seagram Building in commercial space, and the architecture of Frank Lloyd Wright or the Bauhaus movement in private or communal spaces. Transitional examples of postmodern architecture be the Portland Building in Portland and the Sony Building( New York City)( originally AT& T Building) in New York City, which borrow elements and references from the past and reintroduces color and symbolism to architecture. A prime example of inspiration for postmodern architecture lie along the Las Vegas Strip, which be study by Robert Venturi in his 1972 book Learning from Las Vegas celebrate the strip's ordinary and common architecture. Venturi opine that `` Less be a bore'', invert Mies Van Der Rohe's dictum that `` Less be more''.

William Gilbert be an early advocate of this method. He passionately reject both the prevailing Aristotelian philosophy and the Scholastic method of university teaching. His book De Magnete be write in 1600, and he be regard by some as the father of electricity and magnetism.[ 39] In this work, he describe many of his experiments with his model Earth call the terrella. From these experiments, he conclude that the Earth be itself magnetic and that this be the reason compasses point north.

Bacon proposed a great reformation of all process of knowledge for the advancement of learning divine and human, which he called Instauratio Magna (The Great Instauration). For Bacon, this reformation would lead to a great advancement in science and a progeny of new inventions that would relieve mankind's miseries and needs. His Novum Organum was published in 1620. He argued that man is "the minister and interpreter of nature", that "knowledge and human power are synonymous", that "effects are produced by the means of instruments and helps", and that "man while operating can only apply or withdraw natural bodies; nature internally performs the rest", and later that "nature can only be commanded by obeying her".[35] Here is an abstract of the philosophy of this work, that by the knowledge of nature and the using of instruments, man can govern or direct the natural work of nature to produce definite results. Therefore, that man, by seeking knowledge of nature, can reach power over it – and thus reestablish the "Empire of Man over creation", which had been lost by the Fall together with man's original purity. In this way, he believed, would mankind be raised above conditions of helplessness, poverty and misery, while coming into a condition of peace, prosperity and security.[36]

Fossilized remain of Homo ergaster and Homo erectus between 1.8 and 1.0 million years old have be find in Europe( Georgia( Dmanisi), Spain), Indonesia( e.g., Sangiran and Trinil), Vietnam, and China( e.g., Shaanxi).( see also: Multiregional hypothesis). The first remains be of Olduwan culture, later of Acheulean and Clactonian culture. Finds of later fossils, such as Homo cepranensis, be local in nature, so the extent of human residence in Eurasia during 1,000,000- 300,000 bp remain a mystery.

During the Age of Enlightenment of the 17th and 18th centuries, many critical thinkers saw religion as antithetical to reason. For them the Middle Ages, or "Age of Faith", was therefore the opposite of the Age of Reason.[28] Kant and Voltaire were vocal in attacking the Middle Ages as a period of social regress dominated by religion, while Gibbon in The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire expressed contempt for the "rubbish of the Dark Ages".[29] Yet just as Petrarch, seeing himself at the cusp of a "new age", was criticising the centuries before his own time, so too were Enlightenment writers.

The use of the geologic time scale for pre-human time periods, and of the three-age system for human prehistory, is a system that emerged during the late nineteenth century in the work of British, German and Scandinavian archeologists, antiquarians and anthropologists.[4]

Around 1500 BCE, the cultures of the West entered a period of decline, accompanied by an assimilation into the other peoples with whom they had maintained connections. As a result, the Tlatilco culture emerged in the Valley of Mexico, and the Olmec culture in the Gulf. Tlatilco was one of the principal Mesoamerican population centers of this period. Its people were adept at harnessing the natural resources of Lake Texcoco and at cultivating maize. Some authors posit that Tlatilco was founded and inhabited by the ancestors of today's Otomi people.

Copernicus' 1543 work on the heliocentric model of the solar system try to demonstrate that the sun be the center of the universe. Few be bother by this suggestion, and the pope and several archbishops be interested enough by it to want more detail.[ 67] His model be later use to create the calendar of Pope Gregory XIII.[ 68] However, the idea that the earth move around the sun be doubt by most of Copernicus' contemporaries. It contradict not only empirical observation, due to the absence of an observable stellar parallax,[ 69] but more significantly at the time, the authority of Aristotle.

Historians consider the early modern period to be approximately between 1500 and 1800. It follow the Late Middle Ages period and be mark by the first European colonies, the rise of strong centralized governments, and the beginnings of recognizable nation-states that be the direct antecedents of today's states.

Some bushrangers, most notably Ned Kelly in his Jerilderie Letter, and in his final raid on Glenrowan, explicitly represented themselves as political rebels. Attitudes to Kelly, by far the most well-known bushranger, exemplify the ambivalent views of Australians regarding bushranging.

The Persian scientist Abū Rayhān al-Bīrūnī introduce early scientific methods for several different fields of inquiry during the 1020s and 1030s. For example, in his treatise on mineralogy, Kitab al-Jawahir( Book of Precious Stones), al-Biruni be `` the most exact of experimental scientists'', while in the introduction to his study of India, he declare that `` to execute our project, it have not be possible to follow the geometric method'' and thus become one of the pioneers of comparative sociology in insist on field experience and information.[ 36] He also develop an early experimental method for mechanics.[ 37]

European geographers connected the coast of Tierra del Fuego with the coast of New Guinea on their globes, and allowing their imaginations to run riot in the vast unknown spaces of the south Atlantic, south Indian and Pacific oceans they sketched the outlines of the Terra Australis Incognita ("Unknown Southern Land"), a vast continent stretching in parts into the tropics. The search for this great south land or Third World was a leading motive of explorers in the 16th and the early part of the 17th centuries. In 1599, according to the account of Jacob le Maire, the Dutch Dirck Gerritsz Pomp observed mountainous land at latitude (64°). If so, these were the South Shetland Islands, and possibly the first European sighting of Antarctica (or offshore-lying islands belonging to it). Other accounts, however, do not note this observation, casting doubt on their accuracy. It has been argued that the Spaniard Gabriel de Castilla claimed to have sighted "snow-covered mountains" beyond the 64° S in 1603, but this claim is not generally recognized.

Barton promise to `` create a high court, ... and an efficient federal public service ... He propose to extend conciliation and arbitration, create a uniform railway gauge between the eastern capitals,[ 223] to introduce female federal franchise, to establish a ... system of old age pensions. ``[ 224] He also promise to introduce legislation to safeguard `` White Australia'' from any influx of Asian or Pacific Island labour.

In 1736 training in reading was made compulsory for all children, but was not effective until some years later. In 1827, Norway introduced the folkeskole, a primary school which became mandatory for 7 years in 1889 and 9 years in 1969. In the 1970s and 1980s, the folkeskole was abolished, and the grunnskole was introduced.

In the second half of the century the ideas of population genetics begin to be apply in the new discipline of the genetics of behavior, sociobiology, and, especially in humans, evolutionary psychology. In the 1960s W.D. Hamilton and others develop game theory approaches to explain altruism from an evolutionary perspective through kin selection. The possible origin of higher organisms through endosymbiosis, and contrast approaches to molecular evolution in the gene-centered view( which hold selection as the predominant cause of evolution) and the neutral theory( which make genetic drift a key factor) spawn perennial debates over the proper balance of adaptationism and contingency in evolutionary theory.[ 59]

Following the end of the war in 1945, the British bases be hand over to civilian members of the newly create Falkland Islands Dependencies Survey( subsequently the British Antarctic Survey) the first such national scientific body to be establish in Antarctica.

The colony included the current islands of New Zealand. In 1817, the British government withdrew the extensive territorial claim over the South Pacific. In practice, the governors' writ had been shown not to run in the islands of the South Pacific.[128] The Church Missionary Society had concerns over atrocities committed against the natives of the South Sea Islands, and the ineffectiveness of the New South Wales government to deal with the lawlessness. As a result, on 27 June 1817, Parliament passed an Act for the more effectual Punishment of Murders and Manslaughters committed in Places not within His Majesty's Dominions, which described Tahiti, New Zealand and other islands of the South Pacific as being not within His Majesty's dominions.[129]

After 1868 reformers set Japan on a rapid course of modernization, with a public education system like that of Western Europe. Missions like the Iwakura mission were sent abroad to study the education systems of leading Western countries. They returned with the ideas of decentralization, local school boards, and teacher autonomy. Elementary school enrollments climbed from about 40 or 50 percent of the school-age population in the 1870s to more than 90 percent by 1900, despite strong public protest, especially against school fees.

Also, for the first time, the limits of mathematics were explored. Niels Henrik Abel, a Norwegian, and Évariste Galois, a Frenchman, proved that there is no general algebraic method for solving polynomial equations of degree greater than four (Abel–Ruffini theorem). Other 19th-century mathematicians utilized this in their proofs that straightedge and compass alone are not sufficient to trisect an arbitrary angle, to construct the side of a cube twice the volume of a given cube, nor to construct a square equal in area to a given circle. Mathematicians had vainly attempted to solve all of these problems since the time of the ancient Greeks. On the other hand, the limitation of three dimensions in geometry was surpassed in the 19th century through considerations of parameter space and hypercomplex numbers.

Knowledge of navigation was well developed at this time, and reached a peak of skill not exceeded (except perhaps by Polynesian sailors) until 1730 when the invention of the chronometer enabled the precise determination of longitude.

By 1400 a Latin translation of Ptolemy's Geographia reached Italy coming from Constantinople. The rediscovery of Roman geographical knowledge was a revelation,[15] both for mapmaking and worldview,[16] although reinforcing the idea that the Indian Ocean was landlocked.

The Phoenician writing system be adapt from the Proto-Canaanite script in around the 11th century BC, which in turn borrow ideas from Egyptian hieroglyphics. This script be adapt by the Greeks. A variant of the early Greek alphabet give rise to the Etruscan alphabet, and its own descendants, such as the Latin alphabet. Other descendants from the Greek alphabet include the Cyrillic script, use to write Russian, among others.
Classical sources frequently use the term Chaldeans for the astronomers of Mesopotamia, who were, in reality, priest-scribes specializing in astrology and other forms of divination.

After a month's stay, Cook resume his exploration of the Northern Pacific. Shortly after leave Hawaii Island, however, the Resolution's foremast break, so the ships return to Kealakekua Bay for repairs. Tensions rise, and a number of quarrels break out between the Europeans and Hawaiians. On 14 February 1779, at Kealakekua Bay, some Hawaiians take one of Cook's small boats. As thefts be quite common in Tahiti and the other islands, Cook would have take hostages until the steal articles be return.[ 74] He attempt to take as hostage the King of Hawaiʻi, Kalaniʻōpuʻu. The Hawaiians prevent this, and Cook's men have to retreat to the beach. As Cook turn his back to help launch the boats, he be strike on the head by the villagers and then stab to death as he fell on his face in the surf.[ 79] Hawaiian tradition say that he be kill by a chief name Kalaimanokahoʻowaha or Kanaʻina.[ 80] The Hawaiians drag his body away. Four of Cook's men be also kill and two others be wound in the confrontation.

Library expansion be calculate in 1945 by Fremont Rider to double in capacity every 16 years, if sufficient space be make available.[ 5] He advocate replace bulky, decay print works with miniaturized microform analog photographs, which could be duplicate on-demand for library patrons or other institutions. He do not foresee the digital technology that would follow decades later to replace analog microform with digital imaging, storage, and transmission media. Automated, potentially lossless digital technologies allow vast increases in the rapidity of information growth. Moore's law, which be formulate around 1965, calculate that the number of transistors in a dense integrate circuit doubles approximately every two years.[ 6]

His successor at the Lyceum be Theophrastus, who write valuable books describe plant and animal life. His works be regard as the first to put botany and zoology on a systematic footing. He also produce one of the very first work on mineralogy, with descriptions of ores and minerals know to the world at that time. He make some shrewd observations of their properties. For example, he make the first know reference to the phenomenon of pyroelectricity, note that the mineral tourmaline becomes charge when heat. Pliny the Elder make clear references to his use of the work in his Naturalis Historia of 77 AD, while update and make much new information available on minerals himself. From both these early texts be to emerge the science of mineralogy, and ultimately geology. Both authors describe the sources of the minerals they discuss in the various mines exploit in their time, so their works should be regard not just as early scientific texts, but also important for the history of engineering and the history of technology. Pliny be especially significant because he provide full bibliographic details of the earlier authors and their works he use and consults. Because his encyclopedia survive the Dark Ages, we know of these lose works, even if the texts themselves have disappear. The book be one of the first to be print in 1489, and become a standard reference work for Renaissance scholars, as well as an inspiration for the development of a scientific and rational approach to the world.

The 3rd and 4th centuries saw the rise of the Xuanxue (mysterious learning), also called Neo-Taoism. The most important philosophers of this movement were Wang Bi, Xiang Xiu and Guo Xiang. The main question of this school was whether Being came before Not-Being (in Chinese, ming and wuming). A peculiar feature of these Taoist thinkers, like the Seven Sages of the Bamboo Grove, was the concept of feng liu (lit. wind and flow), a sort of romantic spirit which encouraged following the natural and instinctive impulse.

In the 18th century James Burnett, Lord Monboddo analyze numerous languages and deduce logical elements of the evolution of human language. His thinking be interleave with his precursive concepts of biological evolution. Some of his early concepts have be validate and be consider correct today. In his The Sanscrit Language( 1786), Sir William Jones propose that Sanskrit and Persian have resemblances to Classical Greek, Latin, Gothic, and Celtic languages. From this idea spring the field of comparative linguistics and historical linguistics. Through the 19th century, European linguistics center on the comparative history of the Indo-European languages, with a concern for find their common roots and trace their development.

Throughout the Yuan dynasty, there be some general sentiment among the populace against the Mongol dominance. Yet rather than the nationalist cause, it be mainly strings of natural disasters, and incompetence governance that trigger widespread peasant uprisings since the 1340s. After the massive naval engagement at Lake Poyang, Zhu Yuanzhang prevail over other rebel forces in the south. He proclaim himself emperor and found the Ming Dynasty in 1368. The same year his northern expedition army capture the capital Khanbaliq. The Yuan remnants flee back to Mongolia and sustain the regime. Other Mongol Khanates in Central Asia continue to exist after the fall of Yuan dynasty in China.

Alhazen view his scientific studies as a search for truth: `` Truth be seek for its own sake. And those who be engage upon the quest for anything for its own sake be not interested in other things. Finding the truth be difficult, and the road to it be rough. ...[ 31]

The creation of the public sphere has been associated with two long-term historical trends: the rise of the modern nation state and the rise of capitalism. The modern nation state, in its consolidation of public power, created by counterpoint a private realm of society independent of the state, which allowed for the public sphere. Capitalism also increased society's autonomy and self-awareness, and an increasing need for the exchange of information. As the nascent public sphere expanded, it embraced a large variety of institutions; the most commonly cited were coffee houses and cafés, salons and the literary public sphere, figuratively localized in the Republic of Letters.[119] In France, the creation of the public sphere was helped by the aristocracy's move from the King's palace at Versailles to Paris in about 1720, since their rich spending stimulated the trade in luxuries and artistic creations, especially fine paintings.[120]

In 208 BC Xiongnu emperor Modu Chanyu, in his first major military campaign, defeat the formerly superior Donghu, who split into the Xianbei and Wuhuan. The Xianbei flee east all the way to Liaodong. In 49 AD the Xianbei ruler Bianhe attack the Xiongnu and kill 2000 people after have receive generous gifts from Emperor Guangwu of Han. In 54 AD the Xianbei rulers Yuchoupen and Mantu present themselves to the Han emperor and receive the titles of wang and gou. Until 93 AD the Xianbei be quietly protect the Chinese border from Wuhuan and Xiongnu attacks and receive ample rewards. From 93 AD the Xianbei begin to occupy the lands of the Xiongnu. 100,000 Xiongnu families change their name to Xianbei. In 97 AD Feijuxian in Liaodong be attack by the Xianbei, and the governor Qi Sen be dismiss for inaction. Other Xianbei rulers who be active before the rise of the Xianbei emperor Tanshihuai( 141-181) be Yanzhiyang, Lianxu and Cizhiqian. The Xianbei give rise to different Mongolic branches, for example the Rouran( 330-555), Khitan( 388-1218) and Shiwei( 444-present day). The Khitans develop the Khitan scripts in 920-925 AD. The Rouran king Shelun be the first major leader of the steppes to adopt( in 402 AD) the title of Khagan( 可汗) or Qiudoufa Khan( 丘豆伐可汗)( which be originally a title use by Xianbei nobles).

A precursor of the engine be design by the German scientist Otto von Guericke who, in 1650, design and build the world's first vacuum pump and create the world's first ever vacuum know as the Magdeburg hemispheres experiment. He be drive to make a vacuum to disprove Aristotle's long-held supposition that'Nature abhors a vacuum'. Shortly thereafter, Irish physicist and chemist Boyle have learn of Guericke's designs and in 1656, in coordination with English scientist Robert Hooke, build an air pump. Using this pump, Boyle and Hooke notice the pressure-volume correlation for a gas: PV= k, where P be pressure, V be volume and k be a constant: this relationship be know as Boyle's Law. In that time, air be assume to be a system of motionless particles, and not interpret as a system of move molecules. The concept of thermal motion come two centuries later. Therefore, Boyle's publication in 1660 speaks about a mechanical concept: the air spring.[ 27] Later, after the invention of the thermometer, the property temperature could be quantify. This tool give Gay-Lussac the opportunity to derive his law, which lead shortly later to the ideal gas law. But, already before the establishment of the ideal gas law, an associate of Boyle's name Denis Papin build in 1679 a bone digester, which be a closed vessel with a tightly fit lid that confine steam until a high pressure be generate.

In the mid-1840s German economist Wilhelm Roscher( 1817–1894) found the German historical school of economics, which promote the cyclical theory of nations—economies pass through youth, manhood, and senility—and spread through academia in Britain and the U.S., dominate it for the rest of the 19th century.[ 40]

Puddling produce a structural grade iron at a relatively low cost. Puddling be a means of decarburize pig iron by slow oxidation, with iron ore as the oxygen source, as the iron be manually stir use a long rod. The decarburized iron, have a higher melting point than cast iron, be rake into globs by the puddler. When the glob be large enough the puddler would remove it. Puddling be backbreaking and extremely hot work. Few puddlers live to be 40.[ 38] Puddling be do in a reverberatory furnace, allow coal or coke to be use as fuel. The puddling process continue to be use until the late 19th century when iron be be displace by steel. Because puddle required human skill in sense the iron globs, it be never successfully mechanise.

It has been argued that GDP per capita was much more stable and progressed at a much slower rate until the industrial revolution and the emergence of the modern capitalist economy, and that it has since increased rapidly in capitalist countries.[59]

The Lucas–Spielberg combine would dominate `` Hollywood'' cinema for much of the 1980s, and lead to much imitation. Two follow-ups to Star Wars, three to Jaws, and three Indiana Jones films help to make sequels of successful films more of an expectation than ever before. Lucas also launch THX Ltd, a division of Lucasfilm in 1982,[ 58] while Spielberg enjoy one of the decade's greatest successes in E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial the same year. 1982 also saw the release of Disney's Tron which be one of the first films from a major studio to use computer graphics extensively. American independent cinema struggle more during the decade, although Martin Scorsese's Raging Bull( 1980), After Hours( 1985), and The King of Comedy( 1983) help to establish him as one of the most critically acclaimed American film makers of the era. Also during 1983 Scarface be release, be very profitable and result in even greater fame for its leading actor Al Pacino. Probably the most successful film commercially be vend during 1989: Tim Burton's version of Bob Kane's creation, Batman, exceed box-office records. Jack Nicholson's portrayal of the demented Joker earn him a total of$ 60,000,000 after figure in his percentage of the gross.

The rediscovery of ancient texts and the invention of printing democratized learning and allowed a faster propagation of ideas. In the first period of the Italian Renaissance, humanists favoured the study of humanities over natural philosophy or applied mathematics, and their reverence for classical sources further enshrined the Aristotelian and Ptolemaic views of the universe. Writing around 1450, Nicholas Cusanus anticipated the heliocentric worldview of Copernicus, but in a philosophical fashion.

John Stuart Mill (1806–1873) was the dominant figure of political economic thought of his time, as well as a Member of parliament for the seat of Westminster, and a leading political philosopher. Mill was a child prodigy, reading Ancient Greek from the age of 3, and being vigorously schooled by his father James Mill.[45] Jeremy Bentham was a close mentor and family friend, and Mill was heavily influenced by David Ricardo. Mill's textbook, first published in 1848 and titled Principles of Political Economy was essentially a summary of the economic thought of the mid-nineteenth century.[46]

The clergy be divide into two types: the secular clergy, who live out in the world, and the regular clergy, who live under a religious rule and be usually monks.[ 166] Throughout the period monks remain a very small proportion of the population, usually less than one per cent.[ 167] Most of the regular clergy be draw from the nobility, the same social class that serve as the recruiting ground for the upper levels of the secular clergy. The local parish priests be often draw from the peasant class.[ 168] Townsmen be in a somewhat unusual position, as they do not fit into the traditional three-fold division of society into nobles, clergy, and peasants. During the 12th and 13th centuries, the ranks of the townsmen expand greatly as exist towns grow and new population centres be found.[ 169] But throughout the Middle Ages the population of the towns probably never exceed 10 per cent of the total population.[ 170]

The 19th century saw the founding of a number of national mathematical societies: the London Mathematical Society in 1865, the Société Mathématique de France in 1872, the Circolo Matematico di Palermo in 1884, the Edinburgh Mathematical Society in 1883, and the American Mathematical Society in 1888. The first international, special-interest society, the Quaternion Society, be form in 1899, in the context of a vector controversy.

In the history of geography, the key classical text was the Geographia of Claudius Ptolemy (2nd century). It was translated into Latin in the 15th century by Jacopo d'Angelo. It was widely read in manuscript and went through many print editions after it was first printed in 1475. Regiomontanus worked on preparing an edition for print prior to his death; his manuscripts were consulted by later mathematicians in Nuremberg.

The Kingdom of Mapungubwe was the first state in Southern Africa, with its capital at Mapungubwe. The state arose in the 12th century CE. Its wealth came from controlling the trade in ivory from the Limpopo Valley, copper from the mountains of northern Transvaal, and gold from the Zimbabwe Plateau between the Limpopo and Zambezi rivers, with the Swahili merchants at Chibuene. By the mid-13th century, Mapungubwe was abandoned.[126]

Harsha Vardhana( Sanskrit: हर्षवर्धन), commonly call Harsha, be an Indian emperor who rule from 606 to 647 CE. He be the son of Prabhakarvardhana and the younger brother of Rajyavardhana, who be members of the Pushyabhuti dynasty and rule Thanesar, in present-day Haryana.

However, even though science continued under the Roman Empire, Latin texts were mainly compilations drawing on earlier Greek work; advanced scientific research and teaching continued to be carried on in Greek. Meanwhile, such Greek and Hellenistic works as survived were preserved and developed in the Byzantine Empire and in the Islamic world. Late Roman attempts to translate Greek writings into Latin had limited success and direct knowledge of most ancient Greek texts only reached western Europe from the 12th century onwards.[30]

Behavioralism seeks to examine the behavior, actions, and acts of individuals – rather than the characteristics of institutions such as legislatures, executives, and judiciaries and groups in different social settings and explain this behavior as it relates to the political.[12]
In the Early Middle Ages, Persia become a stronghold of Islamic science.

The Eastern Roman Empire, today commonly know as the Byzantine Empire, rule from the Balkans to the Euphrates, become increasingly define by and dogmatic about Christianity, gradually create religious rifts between the doctrines dictate by the establishment in Constantinople and believers in many parts of the Middle East. By this time, Greek have become the'lingua franca' of the region, although ethnicities such as the Syriacs and the Hebrew continue to exist. Under Byzantine/Greek rule the area of the Levant meet an era of stability and prosperity.

There be an independent invention of copper and bronze smelt first by Andean civilizations in South America extend later by sea commerce to the Mesoamerican civilization in West Mexico( see Metallurgy in pre-Columbian America and Metallurgy in pre-Columbian Mesoamerica).

Thus, a cross-Pacific Spanish route be establish, between Mexico and the Philippines. For a long time these routes be use by the Manila galleons, thereby create a trade link join China, the Americas, and Europe via the combined trans-Pacific and trans-Atlantic routes.

Even cities and states beyond central Italy, such as the Republic of Florence at this time, be also notable for their merchant Republics, especially the Republic of Venice. Although in practice these be oligarchical, and bore little resemblance to a modern democracy, they do have democratic features and be responsive states, with forms of participation in governance and belief in liberty.[ 32][ 33][ 34] The relative political freedom they afford be conducive to academic and artistic advancement.[ 35] Likewise, the position of Italian cities such as Venice as great trading centres make them intellectual crossroads. Merchants bring with them ideas from far corners of the globe, particularly the Levant. Venice be Europe's gateway to trade with the East, and a producer of fine glass, while Florence be a capital of textiles. The wealth such business bring to Italy meant large public and private artistic projects could be commission and individuals have more leisure time for study.[ 35]

Prior to World War II, China faced a civil war between Mao Zedong's Communist party and Chiang Kai-shek's nationalist party; the nationalists appeared to be in the lead. However, once the Japanese invaded in 1937, the two parties were forced to form a temporary cease-fire in order to defend China. The nationalists faced many military failures that caused them to lose territory and subsequently, respect from the Chinese masses. In contrast, the communists' use of guerilla warfare (led by Lin Biao) proved effective against the Japanese's conventional methods and put the Communist Party on top by 1945. They also gained popularity for the reforms they were already applying in controlled areas, including land redistribution, education reforms, and widespread health care. For the next four years, the nationalists would be forced to retreat to the small island east of China, known as Taiwan (formerly known as Formosa), where they remain today. In mainland China, the People's Republic of China was established by the Communist Party, with Mao Zedong as its state chairman.

After the war ended, commercial aviation grew rapidly, using mostly ex-military aircraft to transport people and cargo. This growth was accelerated by the glut of heavy and super-heavy bomber airframes like the Lancaster that could be converted into commercial aircraft. The first commercial jet airliner to fly was the British De Havilland Comet. This marked the beginning of the Jet Age, a period of relatively cheap and fast international travel.

Due to the rapid expansion of Islam in the 8th century, many people learn Arabic as a lingua franca. For this reason, the earliest grammatical treatises on Arabic be often write by non-native speakers.
All sonorants( liquids /l, r/ and nasals /m, n, ŋ/) devoice when follow a voiceless obstruent, and they be syllabic when follow a consonant at the end of a word.[ 143]

Lewis Mumford have propose that the Industrial Revolution have its origins in the Early Middle Ages, much earlier than most estimates.[ 144] He explain that the model for standardised mass production be the printing press and that `` the archetypal model for the industrial era be the clock''. He also cite the monastic emphasis on order and time-keeping, as well as the fact that medieval cities have at their centre a church with bell ring at regular intervals as be necessary precursors to a greater synchronisation necessary for later, more physical, manifestations such as the steam engine.

Africa's history have be challenge for research in the field of African studies because of the scarcity of write sources in large parts of the continent, particularly with the destruction of many of the most important manuscripts from Timbuktu. Disciplines such as the recording of oral history, historical linguistics, archaeology and genetics have be crucial.

By the early 15th century, a new power have arise in western Anatolia, the Ottoman Empire. Ottoman khans, who in 1453 capture the Christian Byzantine capitol of Constantinople and make themselves sultans. The Mamluks hold the Ottomans out of the Middle East for a century, but in 1514 Selim the Grim begin the systematic Ottoman conquest of the region. Syria be occupy in 1516 and Egypt in 1517, extinguish the Mameluk line. Iraq be conquer almost in 40 years from the Iranian Safavids, who be successors of the Aq Qoyunlu.

Menzies remain a staunch supporter of links to the monarchy and Commonwealth of Nations and formalise an alliance with the United States, but also launch post-war trade with Japan, begin a growth of Australian exports of coal, iron ore and mineral resources that would steadily climb until Japan become Australia's largest trading partner.[ 343]

The innovation of smelt and cast metals in the Bronze Age start to change the way that culture develop and interact with each other.[ citation need] Starting around 5500 BCE, early smiths begin to re-shape native metals of copper and gold- without the use of fire- for tools and weapons. The heating of copper and its shaping with hammers begin around 5000 BCE. Melting and casting start around 4000 BCE. Metallurgy have its dawn with the reduction of copper from its ore around 3500 BCE. The first alloy, bronze come into use around 3000 BCE. Iron-working come into prominence from about 1200 BCE.

Public health measures became particular important during the 1918 flu pandemic, which killed at least 50 million people around the world.[148] It became an important case study in epidemiology.[149] Bristow shows there was a gendered response of health caregivers to the pandemic in the United States. Male doctors were unable to cure the patients, and they felt like failures. Women nurses also saw their patients die, but they took pride in their success in fulfilling their professional role of caring for, ministering, comforting, and easing the last hours of their patients, and helping the families of the patients cope as well.[150]

One of the oldest organised systems of medicine is known from the Indian subcontinent in the form of Ayurveda which originated around 1500 BCE from Atharvaveda (one of the four most ancient books of Indian knowledge, wisdom and culture).

According to diplomat Alan Renouf, the dominant theme in Australia's foreign policy under Australia's Liberal – Country Party governments of the 1950s and 1960s was anti-communism.[375] Another former diplomat, Gregory Clark, suggested that it was specifically a fear of China that drove Australian foreign policy decisions for twenty years.[376] The ANZUS security treaty, which had been signed in 1951, had its origins in Australia's and New Zealand's fears of a rearmed Japan. Its obligations on the US, Australia and New Zealand are vague, but its influence on Australian foreign policy thinking, at times significant.[377] The SEATO treaty, signed only three years later, clearly demonstrated Australia's position as a US ally in the emerging Cold War.

As Western Europe witnessed the formation of new kingdoms, the Eastern Roman Empire remained intact and experienced an economic revival that lasted into the early 7th century. There were fewer invasions of the eastern section of the empire; most occurred in the Balkans. Peace with the Sasanian Empire, the traditional enemy of Rome, lasted throughout most of the 5th century. The Eastern Empire was marked by closer relations between the political state and Christian Church, with doctrinal matters assuming an importance in eastern politics that they did not have in Western Europe. Legal developments included the codification of Roman law; the first effort—the Codex Theodosianus—was completed in 438.[57] Under Emperor Justinian (r. 527–565), another compilation took place—the Corpus Juris Civilis.[58] Justinian also oversaw the construction of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople and the reconquest of North Africa from the Vandals and Italy from the Ostrogoths,[59] under Belisarius (d. 565).[60] The conquest of Italy was not complete, as a deadly outbreak of plague in 542 led to the rest of Justinian's reign concentrating on defensive measures rather than further conquests.[59]

In 960, the Song dynasty was founded by Emperor Taizu, with its capital established in Kaifeng (also known as Bianjing). In 979, the Song dynasty reunified most of the China proper, while large swaths of the outer territories were occupied by sinicized nomadic empires. The Khitan Liao dynasty, which lasted from 907 to 1125, ruled over Manchuria, Mongolia, and parts of Northern China. Meanwhile, in what are now the north-western Chinese provinces of Gansu, Shaanxi, and Ningxia, the Tangut tribes founded the Western Xia dynasty from 1032 to 1227.

The Aztec Empire arose in the early 15th century and appear to be on a path to assert dominance over the Valley of Mexico region not see since Teotihuacan. Spain be the first European power to contact Mesoamerica, however, and its conquistadores and a large number of native allies conquer the Aztecs.

Abel and Galois's investigations into the solutions of various polynomial equations laid the groundwork for further developments of group theory, and the associated fields of abstract algebra. In the 20th century physicists and other scientists have seen group theory as the ideal way to study symmetry.

However, the fall of Tula checked the power of the zuyuano system, which finally broke down with the dissolution of the League of Mayapán, the Mixtec state, and the abandonment of Tula. Mesoamerica received new immigrants from the north, and although these groups were related to the ancient Toltecs, they had a completely different ideology than the existing residents. The final arrivals were the Mexica, who established themselves on a small island on Lake Texcoco under the dominion of the Texpanecs of Azcapotzalco. This group would, in the following decades, conquer a large part of Mesoamerica, creating a united and centralized state whose only rivals were the Tarascan state of Michoacán. Neither one of them could defeat the other, and it seems that a type of non-aggression pact was established between the two peoples. When the Spaniards arrived many of the peoples controlled by the Mexica no longer wished to continue under their rule. Therefore, they took advantage of the opportunity presented by the Europeans, agreeing to support them, thinking that in return they would gain their freedom, and not knowing that this would lead to the subjugation of all of the Mesoamerican world.

There are many observable trends in mathematics, the most notable being that the subject is growing ever larger, computers are ever more important and powerful, the application of mathematics to bioinformatics is rapidly expanding, the volume of data to be analyzed being produced by science and industry, facilitated by computers, is explosively expanding.[citation needed]

Traditionally, the Yoruba people viewed themselves as the inhabitants of a united empire, in contrast to the situation today, in which "Yoruba" is the cultural-linguistic designation for speakers of a language in the Niger–Congo family. The name comes from a Hausa word to refer to the Oyo Empire. The first Yoruba state was Ile-Ife, said to have been founded around 1000 CE by a supernatural figure, the first oni Oduduwa. Oduduwa's sons would be the founders of the different city-states of the Yoruba, and his daughters would become the mothers of the various Yoruba obas, or kings. Yoruba city-states were usually governed by an oba and a iwarefa, a council of chiefs who advised the oba. By the 18th century, the Yoruba city-states formed a loose confederation, with the Oni of Ife as the head and Ife as the capital. As time went on, the individual city-states became more powerful with their obas assuming more powerful spiritual positions and diluting the authority of the Oni of Ife. Rivalry became intense among the city-states.[187]

Since 1990 our understanding of prehistoric Europeans has been radically changed by discoveries of ancient astronomical artifacts throughout Europe. The artifacts demonstrate that Neolithic and Bronze Age Europeans had a sophisticated knowledge of mathematics and astronomy.

In Britain, the Cinematograph Act 1909 was the first primary legislation to specifically regulate the film industry. Film exhibitions often took place in temporary venues and the use of highly flammable cellulose nitrate for film, combined with limelight illumination, created a significant fire hazard. The Act specified a strict building code which required, amongst other things, that the projector be enclosed within a fire resisting enclosure.[28]

But this initial period be usually see as one of scientific backwardness. There be no new developments in physics or astronomy, and the reverence for classical sources further enshrine the Aristotelian and Ptolemaic views of the universe. Philosophy lose much of its rigour as the rules of logic and deduction be see as secondary to intuition and emotion. At the same time, Humanism stress that nature come to be view as an animate spiritual creation that be not govern by laws or mathematics. Science would only be revive later, with such figures as Copernicus, Gerolamo Cardano, Francis Bacon, and Descartes.

After the defeat of revolutionary France, the other great powers tried to restore the situation which existed before 1789. In 1815 at the Congress of Vienna, the major powers of Europe managed to produce a peaceful balance of power among the various European empires. This was known as the Metternich system. However, their efforts were unable to stop the spread of revolutionary movements: the middle classes had been deeply influenced by the ideals of the French revolution, the Industrial Revolution brought important economical and social changes. The working classes and some intellectuals became a base for socialist, communist and anarchistic ideas (especially those summarised by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels in The Communist Manifesto). The middle classes and businessmen promoted liberalism, free trade and capitalism. Aristocratic elements concentrated in government service, the military and the established churches. Nationalist movements (in Germany, Italy, Poland, Hungary, and elsewhere) called upon the "racial" unity (which usually meant a common language and an imagined common ethnicity) to seek national unification and/or liberation from foreign rule. As a result, the period between 1815 and 1871 saw a large number of revolutionary attempts and independence wars. Greece successfully revolted against Ottoman rule in the 1820s. European diplomats and intellectuals saw the Greek struggle for independence, with its accounts of Turkish atrocities, in a romantic light.

The materialist explanations of the origins of the cosmos seem to miss an important point. It do n't make much sense to think that an ordered universe come out of a random collection of matter. How can a random assemblage of fire or water produce an ordered universe without the existence of some order principle?

The grain be the earliest unit of mass and be the smallest unit in the apothecary, avoirdupois, Tower, and troy systems. The early unit be a grain of wheat or barleycorn use to weigh the precious metals silver and gold. Larger units preserve in stone standards be develop that be use as both units of mass and of monetary currency. The pound be derive from the mina use by ancient civilizations. A smaller unit be the shekel, and a larger unit be the talent. The magnitude of these units vary from place to place. The Babylonians and Sumerians have a system in which there be 60 shekels in a mina and 60 minas in a talent. The Roman talent consist of 100 libra( pound) which be smaller in magnitude than the mina. The troy pound( ~373.2 g) use in England and the United States for monetary purposes, like the Roman pound, be divide into 12 ounces, but the Roman uncia( ounce) be smaller. The carat be a unit for measure gemstones that have its origin in the carob seed, which later be standardize at 1/144 ounce and then 0.2 gram.

Some historians such as David Landes and Max Weber credit the different belief systems in Asia and Europe with dictate where the revolution occur.[ 154] The religion and beliefs of Europe be largely products of Judaeo-Christianity and Greek thought. Conversely, Chinese society be found on men like Confucius, Mencius, Han Feizi( Legalism), Lao Tzu( Taoism), and Buddha( Buddhism), result in very different worldviews.[ 155] Other factors include the considerable distance of China's coal deposits, though large, from its cities as well as the then unnavigable Yellow River that connect these deposits to the sea.[ 156]

Conditions improve over the course of the 19th century due to new public health acts regulate things such as sewage, hygiene and home construction. In the introduction of his 1892 edition, Engels note that most of the conditions he write about in 1844 have be greatly improve.

Jacques Turgot( 1727–1781) be bear in Paris to an old Norman family. His best know work, Réflexions sur la formation et la distribution des richesses( Reflections on the Formation and Distribution of Wealth)( 1766) develop Quesnay's theory that land be the only source of wealth. Turgot view society in terms of three classes: the productive agricultural class, the salaried artisan class( classe stipendice) and the landowning class( classe disponible). He argue that only the net product of land should be tax and advocate the complete freedom of commerce and industry.

Early Filipino painting can be found in red slip (clay mixed with water) designs embellished on the ritual pottery of the Philippines such as the acclaimed Manunggul Jar. Evidence of Philippine pottery-making dated as early as 6000 BC has been found in Sanga-sanga Cave, Sulu and Laurente Cave, Cagayan. It has been proven that by 5000 BC, the making of pottery was practiced throughout the country. Early Filipinos started making pottery before their Cambodian neighbors and at about the same time as the Thais as part of what appears to be a widespread Ice Age development of pottery technology. Further evidences of painting are manifested in the tattoo tradition of early Filipinos, whom the Portuguese explorer referred to as Pintados or the 'Painted People' of the Visayas.[31] Various designs referencing flora and fauna with heavenly bodies decorate their bodies in various colored pigmentation. Perhaps, some of the most elaborate painting done by early Filipinos that survive to the present day can be manifested among the arts and architecture of the Maranao who are well known for the Nāga Dragons and the Sarimanok carved and painted in the beautiful Panolong of their Torogan or King's House.

In 1772, a French expedition lead by Louis Aleno de St Aloüarn, become the first Europeans to formally claim sovereignty over the west coast of Australia, but no attempt be make to follow this with colonisation.[ 100] The ambition of Sweden's King Gustav III to establish a colony for his country at the Swan River in 1786 remain stillborn.[ 101] It be not until 1788 that economic, technological and political conditions in Great Britain make it possible and worthwhile for that country to make the large effort of send the First Fleet to New South Wales.[ 102]

The term British empiricism come into use to describe philosophical differences perceive between two of its founders Francis Bacon, describe as empiricist, and René Descartes, who be describe as a rationalist. Thomas Hobbes, George Berkeley, and David Hume be the philosophy's primary exponents, who develop a sophisticated empirical tradition as the basis of human knowledge.

The Americas be colonise via the Bering land bridge which be expose during this period by lower sea levels. These people be call the Paleo-Indians, and the earliest accepted dates be those of the Clovis culture sites, some 13,500 years ago. Globally, societies be hunter-gatherers but evidence of regional identities begin to appear in the wide variety of stone tool types be develop to suit very different environments.

Up through the 19th century, the scope of biology be largely divide between medicine, which investigate questions of form and function( i.e., physiology), and natural history, which be concern with the diversity of life and interactions among different forms of life and between life and non-life. By 1900, much of these domains overlap, while natural history( and its counterpart natural philosophy) have largely give way to more specialized scientific disciplines—cytology, bacteriology, morphology, embryology, geography, and geology.

In documentary film the sixties saw the blossoming of Direct Cinema, an observational style of film making as well as the advent of more overtly partisan films like In the Year of the Pig about the Vietnam War by Emile de Antonio. By the late 1960s however, Hollywood filmmakers be begin to create more innovative and groundbreaking films that reflect the social revolution take over much of the western world such as Bonnie and Clyde( 1967), The Graduate( 1967), 2001: A Space Odyssey( 1968), Rosemary's Baby( 1968), Midnight Cowboy( 1969), Easy Rider( 1969) and The Wild Bunch( 1969). Bonnie and Clyde be often consider the beginning of the so-called New Hollywood.

The most influential publication of the Enlightenment be the Encyclopédie( Encyclopaedia). Published between 1751 and 1772 in thirty-five volumes, it be compile by Denis Diderot, Jean le Rond d'Alembert( until 1759), and a team of 150 scientists and philosophers and it help spread the ideas of the Enlightenment across Europe and beyond.[ 11]
Persians who write on geography or create maps during the Middle Ages include:

Astronomy: The first textual mention of astronomical concepts comes from the Vedas, religious literature of India.[39] According to Sarma (2008): "One finds in the Rigveda intelligent speculations about the genesis of the universe from nonexistence, the configuration of the universe, the spherical self-supporting earth, and the year of 360 days divided into 12 equal parts of 30 days each with a periodical intercalary month.".[39] The first 12 chapters of the Siddhanta Shiromani, written by Bhāskara in the 12th century, cover topics such as: mean longitudes of the planets; true longitudes of the planets; the three problems of diurnal rotation; syzygies; lunar eclipses; solar eclipses; latitudes of the planets; risings and settings; the moon's crescent; conjunctions of the planets with each other; conjunctions of the planets with the fixed stars; and the patas of the sun and moon. The 13 chapters of the second part cover the nature of the sphere, as well as significant astronomical and trigonometric calculations based on it.

Indian economist Amartya Sen( 1933–) express considerable skepticism about the validity of neoclassical assumptions, and be highly critical of rational expectations theory, devote his work to Development Economics and human rights.

Still, Hannibal's invasion last over 16 years, ravage Italy. The term'pink tide'( Spanish: marea rosa, Portuguese: onda rosa) or'turn to the Left'( Sp.: vuelta hacia la izquierda, Pt.: Guinada à Esquerda) be phrases use in contemporary 21st century political analysis in the media and elsewhere to describe the perception that leftist ideology in general, and left-wing politics in particular, be increasingly become influential in Latin America.[ 51][ 54][ 55]

Xerxes I of Persia, son and successor of Darius I, attempted his own invasion 10 years later.
