In 1904, the Herero rebelled. German General Lothar von Trotha implemented an extermination policy at the Battle of Waterberg, which drove the Herero west of the Kalahari Desert. At the end of 1905, only 16,000 Herero were alive, out of a previous population of 80,000. Nama resistance was crushed in 1907. All Nama and Herero cattle and land were confiscated from the very diminished population, with remaining Nama and Herero assuming a subordinate position. Labor had to be imported from among the Ovambo.[200]

The first confirm sighting of mainland Antarctica can not be accurately attribute to one single person. It can, however, be narrow down to three individuals. According to various sources,[ 5][ 6][ 7] three men all sight the ice shelf or the continent within days or months of each other: Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen, a captain in the Russian Imperial Navy; Edward Bransfield, a captain in the Royal Navy; and Nathaniel Palmer, an American sealer out of Stonington, Connecticut.

As evident from Fleck's book's title, it revolve around the notion that epistemologically, there be nothing stable or realistically true or false about any scientific fact. Fleck's work, unlike Hessen's work focus more on the epistemological and linguistic factors that affect scientific discovery, innovation and progress or development, while Hessen's work focus on socio-political factors.

Neoclassicism was the dominant form of theatre in the 18th century. It demanded decorum and rigorous adherence to the classical unities. Neoclassical theatre as well as the time period is characterized by its grandiosity. The costumes and scenery were intricate and elaborate. The acting is characterized by large gestures and melodrama. Neoclassical theatre encompasses the Restoration, Augustan, and Johnstinian Ages. In one sense, the neo-classical age directly follows the time of the Renaissance.

A machine for make a continuous sheet of paper on a loop of wire fabric be patent in 1798 by Nicholas Louis Robert who work for Saint-Léger Didot family in France. The paper machine be know as a Fourdrinier after the financiers, brothers Sealy and Henry Fourdrinier, who be stationers in London. Although greatly improve and with many variations, the Fourdriner machine be the predominant means of paper production today.

Marx began a tradition of economists who became political activists, including Rosa Luxemburg (1871–1919), a member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany who later turned towards the Communist Party of Germany because of their stance against the First World War, and Beatrice Webb (1858–1943) of England, a socialist who helped found both the London School of Economics (LSE) and the Fabian Society.

For most of its history, agriculture have be organic agriculture, that be farm without synthetic fertilisers and pesticides, as well as without GMOs. With the advent of chemical agriculture there have be the call for farm without synthetic chemicals. Rudolf Steiner be the first to call for such a differentiated agriculture and his Agriculture Course of 1924 lay the foundation for the development of biodynamic agriculture.[ 127] Lord Northbourne develop these ideas and present his manifesto of organic farming in 1940 and they have since then be take up as a worldwide movement and organic farming be now practice in most countries.[ 128]

Though scholars and scientists had been chronicling the results of scientific endeavors for centuries (such as William Whewell's History of the Inductive Sciences from 1837, and the popular and historical accounts which accompanied the scientific revolution of the 17th century), the development of the distinct academic discipline of the history of science and technology did not occur until the early 20th century, and was intimately bound to the changing role of science during the same time period. The history of science was once exclusively the domain of retired researchers — former scientists whose days in the laboratory had expired but still with a hearty interest in the field — and the rare specialist. However, in the decades since the end of World War II the field has evolved into a full academic discipline, with graduate schools, research institutes, public and private patronage, peer-reviewed journals, and professional societies.

The political system also underwent important changes. During the early Postclassic period, the warlike political elites legitimize their position by means of their adherence to a complex set of religious beliefs that López Austin call zuyuanidad. According to this system, the ruling classes proclaim themselves the descendants of Quetzalcoatl, the Plumed Serpent, one of the creative forces, and a cultural hero in Mesoamerican mythology. They likewise declare themselves the heirs of a no less mythical city, call Tollan in Nahuatl, and Zuyuá in Maya( from which López Austin derive the name for the belief system). Many of the important capitals of the time identify themselves with this name( for example, Tollan Xicocotitlan, Tollan Chollollan, Tollan Teotihuacan). The Tollan of myth be for a long time identify with Tula, in Hidalgo state, but Enrique Florescano and López Austin have claim that this have no basis. Florescano state that the mythical Tollan be Teotihuacan; López Austin argue that Tollan be simply a product of the Mesoamerican religious imagination. Another feature of the zuyuano system be the formation of alliances with other city-states that be control by groups have the same ideology; such be the case with the League of Mayapán in Yucatán, and the Mixtec confederation of Lord Eight Deer, base in the mountains of Oaxaca. These early Postclassic societies can be characterize by their military nature and multi-ethnic populations.

Before the 1920s, computers( sometimes computors) be human clerks that perform computations. They be usually under the lead of a physicist. Many thousands of computers be employ in commerce, government, and research establishments. Most of these computers be women.[ citation need] Some performed astronomical calculations for calendars, others ballistic tables for the military.

Piet Mondrian's art was also related to his spiritual and philosophical studies. In 1908 he became interested in the theosophical movement launched by Helena Petrovna Blavatsky in the late 19th century. Blavatsky believed that it was possible to attain a knowledge of nature more profound than that provided by empirical means, and much of Mondrian's work for the rest of his life was inspired by his search for that spiritual knowledge.

Lithic analysis is a major and specialised form of archaeological investigation. It involves the measurement of the stone tools to determine their typology, function and the technology involved. It includes scientific study of the lithic reduction of the raw materials, examining how the artifacts were made. Much of this study takes place in the laboratory in the presence of various specialists. In experimental archaeology, researchers attempt to create replica tools, to understand how they were made. Flintknappers are craftsmen who use sharp tools to reduce flintstone to flint tool.

The Antikythera mechanism is believed to be the earliest known mechanical analog computer.[4] It was designed to calculate astronomical positions. It was discovered in 1901 in the Antikythera wreck off the Greek island of Antikythera, between Kythera and Crete, and has been dated to circa 100 BC.

Ancient Roman cuisine change over the long duration of this ancient civilization. Dietary habits be affect by the influence of Greek culture, the political changes from kingdom to republic to empire, and empire's enormous expansion, which expose Romans to many new, provincial culinary habits and cook techniques. In the begin the differences between social classes be relatively small, but disparities evolve with the empire's growth. Men and women drink wine with their meals, a tradition that have be carry through to the present day.[ 219]

Indian art get a boost with the economic liberalization of the country since the early 1990s. Artists from various fields now start bring in varied styles of work. In post-liberalization India, many artists have establish themselves in the international art market like the abstract painter Natvar Bhavsar, figurative artist Devajyoti Ray and sculptor Anish Kapoor whose mammoth postminimalist artworks have acquire attention for their sheer size. Many art houses and galleries have also open in USA and Europe to showcase Indian artworks.

"In the course of the fourth millennium BC, city-states developed in southern Mesopotamia that were dominated by temples whose priests represented the cities' patron deities. The most prominent of the city-states was Sumer, which gave its language to the area, [presumably the first written language,] and became the first great civilization of mankind. About 2340 BC, Sargon the Great (c. 2360–2305 BC), appointed his daughter, Enheduanna Enheduanna, as High Priestess of Inanna at Ur[9] and through her writings (the first author ever), she and him united the city-states in the south and founded the Akkadian dynasty, the world's first empire."[10]

In 1898 Thorstein Veblen publish Why be Economics not an Evolutionary Science, which coin the term Evolutionary economics, make use of anthropology to deny that there be a universal human nature, emphasize the conflict between `` industrial'' or instrumental and `` pecuniary'' or ceremonial values, which become know as the Ceremonial/Instrumental Dichotomy.[ 40]
Modern linguistics do not begin until the late 18th century, and the Romantic or animist theses of Johann Gottfried Herder and Johann Christoph Adelung remain influential well into the 19th century.
The Danish philosopher Søren Kierkegaard also influence the humanistic, existential, and modern psychological schools with his work The Concept of Anxiety( 1844) and The Sickness Unto Death( 1849).

Pressure from sports fund bodies have also improve gender equality in sports. For example, the Marylebone Cricket Club( MCC) and the Leander Rowing Club in England have both be male-only establishments since their founding in 1787 and 1818, respectively, but both open their doors to female members at the end of the 20th century at least partially due to the requirements of the United Kingdom Lottery Sports Fund.

Inevitably smaller poleis might be dominate by larger neighbors, but conquest or direct rule by another city-state appear to have be quite rare. Instead the poleis group themselves into leagues, membership of which be in a constant state of flux. Later in the Classical period, the leagues would become fewer and larger, be dominate by one city( particularly Athens, Sparta and Thebes); and often poleis would be compel to join under threat of war( or as part of a peace treaty). Even after Philip II of Macedon `` conquer'' the heartlands of ancient Greece, he do not attempt to annex the territory, or unify it into a new province, but simply compel most of the poleis to join his own Corinthian League.

In the 15th and 16th centuries, the town of Timbuktu in the West African nation of Mali become an Islamic centre of learn with students come from as far away as the Middle East. The town be home to the prestigious Sankore University and other madrasas. The primary focus of these schools be the teaching of the Qur'an, although broader instruction in fields such as logic, astronomy, and history also take place. Over time, there be a great accumulation of manuscripts in the area and an estimated 100,000 or more manuscripts, some of them date from pre-Islamic times and 12th century, be keep by the great families from the town.[ 52] Their contents be didactic, especially in the subjects of astronomy, music, and botany. More than 18,000 manuscripts have be collect by the Ahmed Baba centre.[ 53]

Francis Hutcheson, a moral philosopher, describe the utilitarian and consequentialist principle that virtue be that which provide, in his words, `` the greatest happiness for the greatest numbers''. Much of what be incorporate in the scientific method( the nature of knowledge, evidence, experience, and causation) and some modern attitudes towards the relationship between science and religion be develop by his protégés David Hume and Adam Smith.[ 16] Hume become a major figure in the skeptical philosophical and empiricist traditions of philosophy.
In the 1930s LSE member Sir Roy G.D. Allen( 1906–1983) popularize the use of mathematics in economics.

Early cultures identified celestial objects with gods and spirits.[1] They related these objects (and their movements) to phenomena such as rain, drought, seasons, and tides. It is generally believed that the first astronomers were priests, and that they understood celestial objects and events to be manifestations of the divine, hence early astronomy's connection to what is now called astrology. Ancient structures with possibly astronomical alignments (such as Stonehenge) probably fulfilled astronomical, religious, and social functions.

Despite massive territorial losses in the 7th century, the Christian Byzantine Empire continue to be a potent military and economic force in the Mediterranean, prevent Arab expansion into much of Europe. The Seljuqs' defeat of the Byzantine military in the 11th century and settling in Anatolia effectively mark the end of Byzantine influence in the region. The Seljuks rule most of the Middle East region for the next 200 years, but their empire soon break up into a number of smaller sultanates.

Adam Smith publish The Wealth of Nations, often consider the first work on modern economics, in 1776. It have an immediate impact on British economic policy that continue into the 21st century.[ 36] It be immediately precede and influence by Anne-Robert-Jacques Turgot, Baron de Laune drafts of Reflections on the Formation and Distribution of Wealth( Paris, 1766).( Smith acknowledge indebtedness and possibly be the original English translator.)[ 37]

In 1943, Ossessione was screened in Italy, marking the beginning of Italian neorealism. Major films of this type during the 1940s included Bicycle Thieves, Rome, Open City, and La Terra Trema. In 1952 Umberto D was released, usually considered the last film of this type.

During the Early Middle Ages, the monasteries of the Roman Catholic Church be the centres of education and literacy, preserve the Church's selection from Latin learn and maintain the art of writing. Prior to their formal establishment, many medieval universities be run for hundreds of years as Christian monastic schools( Scholae monasticae), in which monks teach classes, and later as cathedral schools; evidence of these immediate forerunners of the later university at many places date back to the early 6th century.[ 40]

The decision to settle be take when it seem the outbreak of civil war in the Netherlands might precipitate a war in which Britain would be again confront with the alliance of the three naval Powers, France, Holland and Spain, which have bring her to defeat in 1783. Under these circumstances, the strategic advantages of a colony in New South Wales describe in James Matra's proposal be attractive.[ 118] Matra write that such a settlement could facilitate attacks upon the Spanish in South America and the Philippines, and against the Dutch East Indies.[ 119] In 1790, during the Nootka Crisis, plan be make for naval expeditions against Spain's possessions in the Americas and the Philippines, in which New South Wales be assign the role of a base for `` refreshment, communication and retreat''. On subsequent occasions into the early 19th century when war threaten or break out between Britain and Spain, these plans be revive and only the short length of the period of hostilities in each case prevent them from be put into effect.[ 120]

The Information Age have affect the workforce in that automation and computerization have result in higher productivity couple with net job loss. In the United States for example, from January 1972 to August 2010, the number of people employ in manufacture jobs fell from 17,500,000 to 11,500,000 while manufacture value rise 270%.[ 13]

In the 20th century, the study of ideology, behaviouralism and international relations lead to a multitude of'pol-sci' subdisciplines include rational choice theory, vote theory, game theory( also use in economics), psephology, political geography/geopolitics, political psychology/political sociology, political economy, policy analysis, public administration, comparative political analysis and peace studies/conflict analysis.

The new ideals of humanism, although more secular in some aspects, develop against a Christian backdrop, especially in the Northern Renaissance. Much, if not most, of the new art be commission by or in dedication to the Church.[ 18] However, the Renaissance have a profound effect on contemporary theology, particularly in the way people perceive the relationship between man and God.[ 18] Many of the period's foremost theologians be followers of the humanist method, include Erasmus, Zwingli, Thomas More, Martin Luther, and John Calvin.

As with prehistory, determine when a culture may be consider prehistoric or protohistoric be sometimes difficult for archaeologists. Data vary considerably from culture to culture, region to region, and even from one system of reckon dates to another.

During the 17th century the heated debate between religion and science over the Earth’s origin further propelled interest in the Earth and bring about more systematic identification techniques of the Earth’s strata.[ 6] The Earth’s strata can be define as horizontal layers of rock have approximately the same composition throughout.[ 7] An important pioneer in the science be Nicolas Steno. Steno be train in the classical texts on science; however, by 1659 he seriously question accepted knowledge of the natural world.[ 8] Importantly, he question the idea that fossils grow in the ground, as well as common explanations of rock formation. His investigations and his subsequent conclusions on these topics have lead scholars to consider him one of the founders of modern stratigraphy and geology.[ 9][ 10]

Also influential on the emerge discipline of psychology be debates surround the efficacy of Mesmerism( a precursor to hypnosis) and the value of phrenology. The former be develop in the 1770s by Austrian physician Franz Mesmer( 1734–1815) who claim to use the power of gravity, and later of `` animal magnetism'', to cure various physical and mental ills. As Mesmer and his treatment become increasingly fashionable in both Vienna and Paris, it also begin to come under the scrutiny of suspicious officials. In 1784, an investigation be commission in Paris by King Louis XVI which include American ambassador Benjamin Franklin, chemist Antoine Lavoisier and physician Joseph-Ignace Guillotin( later the popularizer of the guillotine). They conclude that Mesmer's method be useless. Abbé Faria, an Indo-Portuguese priest, revive public attention in animal magnetism. Unlike Mesmer, Faria claim that the effect be'generated from within the mind’ by the power of expectancy and cooperation of the patient. Although dispute, the `` magnetic'' tradition continue among Mesmer's students and others, resurface in England in the 19th century in the work of the physician John Elliotson( 1791–1868), and the surgeons James Esdaile( 1808–1859), and James Braid( 1795–1860)( who reconceptualized it as property of the subject's mind rather than a `` power'' of the Mesmerist's, and relabeled it `` hypnotism''). Mesmerism also continue to have a strong social( if not medical) follow in England through the 19th century( see Winter, 1998). Faria's approach be significantly extend by the clinical and theoretical work of Ambroise-Auguste Liébeault and Hippolyte Bernheim of the Nancy School. Faria's theoretical position, and the subsequent experiences of those in the Nancy School make significant contributions to the later autosuggestion techniques of Émile Coué.[ 25] It be adopt for the treatment of hysteria by the director of Paris's Salpêtrière Hospital, Jean-Martin Charcot( 1825–1893).
"How do you see these trees? They are yellow. So, put in yellow; this shadow, rather blue, paint it with pure ultramarine; these red leaves? Put in vermilion."

Life in ancient Rome revolved around the city of Rome, located on seven hills. The city had a vast number of monumental structures like the Colosseum, the Forum of Trajan and the Pantheon. It had theatres, gymnasiums, marketplaces, functional sewers, bath complexes complete with libraries and shops, and fountains with fresh drinking water supplied by hundreds of miles of aqueducts. Throughout the territory under the control of ancient Rome, residential architecture ranged from modest houses to country villas.

Ancient Rome commanded a vast area of land, with tremendous natural and human resources. As such, Rome's economy remained focused on farming and trade. Agricultural free trade changed the Italian landscape, and by the 1st century BC, vast grape and olive estates had supplanted the yeoman farmers, who were unable to match the imported grain price. The annexation of Egypt, Sicily and Tunisia in North Africa provided a continuous supply of grains. In turn, olive oil and wine were Italy's main exports. Two-tier crop rotation was practiced, but farm productivity was low, around 1 ton per hectare.

Because of the need to rebuild Japan after World War II, major Japanese cities contain numerous examples of modern architecture. Japan played some role in modern skyscraper design, because of its long familiarity with the cantilever principle to support the weight of heavy tiled temple roofs. New city planning ideas based on the principle of layering or cocooning around an inner space (oku), a Japanese spatial concept that was adapted to urban needs, were adapted during reconstruction. Modernism became increasingly popular in architecture in Japan starting in the 1950s.

The Bronze Age in Northern Europe spans the entire 2nd millennium BC (Unetice culture, Urnfield culture, Tumulus culture, Terramare culture, Lusatian culture) lasting until c. 600 BC. The Northern Bronze Age was both a period and a Bronze Age culture in Scandinavian pre-history, c. 1700–500 BC, with sites that reached as far east as Estonia. Succeeding the Late Neolithic culture, its ethnic and linguistic affinities are unknown in the absence of written sources. It is followed by the Pre-Roman Iron Age.

The ancient Egyptians enjoy a variety of leisure activities, include games and music. Senet, a board game where pieces move accord to random chance, be particularly popular from the earliest times; another similar game be mehen, which have a circular gaming board. Juggling and ball games be popular with children, and wrestling be also document in a tomb at Beni Hasan.[ 150] The wealthy members of ancient Egyptian society enjoy hunting and boating as well.

Further developments in algebra were made by Al-Karaji in his treatise al-Fakhri, where he extends the methodology to incorporate integer powers and integer roots of unknown quantities. Something close to a proof by mathematical induction appears in a book written by Al-Karaji around 1000 AD, who used it to prove the binomial theorem, Pascal's triangle, and the sum of integral cubes.[116] The historian of mathematics, F. Woepcke,[117] praised Al-Karaji for being "the first who introduced the theory of algebraic calculus." Also in the 10th century, Abul Wafa translated the works of Diophantus into Arabic. Ibn al-Haytham was the first mathematician to derive the formula for the sum of the fourth powers, using a method that is readily generalizable for determining the general formula for the sum of any integral powers. He performed an integration in order to find the volume of a paraboloid, and was able to generalize his result for the integrals of polynomials up to the fourth degree. He thus came close to finding a general formula for the integrals of polynomials, but he was not concerned with any polynomials higher than the fourth degree.[118]

Efforts by local kings to fight the invaders lead to the formation of new political entities. In Anglo-Saxon England, King Alfred the Great( r. 871–899) come to an agreement with the Viking invaders in the late 9th century, result in Danish settlements in Northumbria, Mercia, and parts of East Anglia.[ 120] By the middle of the 10th century, Alfred's successors have conquer Northumbria, and restore English control over most of the southern part of Great Britain.[ 121] In northern Britain, Kenneth MacAlpin( d. c. 860) unite the Picts and the Scots into the Kingdom of Alba.[ 122] In the early 10th century, the Ottonian dynasty have establish itself in Germany, and be engage in drive back the Magyars. Its efforts culminate in the coronation in 962 of Otto I( r. 936–973) as Holy Roman Emperor.[ 123] In 972, he secure recognition of his title by the Byzantine Empire, which he seal with the marriage of his son Otto II( r. 967–983) to Theophanu( d. 991), daughter of an earlier Byzantine Emperor Romanos II( r. 959–963).[ 124] By the late 10th century Italy have be draw into the Ottonian sphere after a period of instability;[ 125] Otto III( r. 996–1002) spend much of his later reign in the kingdom.[ 126] The western Frankish kingdom be more fragmented, and although kings remain nominally in charge, much of the political power devolve to the local lords.[ 127]

Neo-Dada is also a movement that started 1n the 1950s and 1960s and was related to Abstract expressionism only with imagery. Featuring the emergence of combined manufactured items, with artist materials, moving away from previous conventions of painting. This trend in art is exemplified by the work of Jasper Johns and Robert Rauschenberg, whose "combines" in the 1950s were forerunners of Pop Art and Installation art, and made use of the assemblage of large physical objects, including stuffed animals, birds and commercial photography. Robert Rauschenberg, (see untitled combine, 1963, above), Jasper Johns, Larry Rivers, John Chamberlain, Claes Oldenburg, George Segal, Jim Dine, and Edward Kienholz among others were important pioneers of both abstraction and Pop Art; creating new conventions of art-making; they made acceptable in serious contemporary art circles the radical inclusion of unlikely materials as parts of their works of art.

In the 14th century, Nicole Oresme, later bishop of Liseux, show that neither the scriptural texts nor the physical arguments advance against the movement of the Earth be demonstrative and adduce the argument of simplicity for the theory that the earth moves, and not the heavens. However, he conclude `` everyone maintains, and I think myself, that the heavens do move and not the earth: For God hath establish the world which shall not be move. ``[ 61] In the 15th century, cardinal Nicholas of Cusa suggest in some of his scientific writings that the Earth revolve around the Sun, and that each star be itself a distant sun. He be not, however, describe a scientifically verifiable theory of the universe.

After the significant contributions of Greek scholars to the development of astronomy, it entered a relatively static era in Western Europe from the Roman era through the 12th century. This lack of progress has led some astronomers to assert that nothing happened in Western European astronomy during the Middle Ages.[51] Recent investigations, however, have revealed a more complex picture of the study and teaching of astronomy in the period from the 4th to the 16th centuries.[52]

The high-water mark of Chinese mathematics occurs in the 13th century (latter part of the Song period), with the development of Chinese algebra. The most important text from that period is the Precious Mirror of the Four Elements by Chu Shih-chieh (fl. 1280–1303), dealing with the solution of simultaneous higher order algebraic equations using a method similar to Horner's method.[85] The Precious Mirror also contains a diagram of Pascal's triangle with coefficients of binomial expansions through the eighth power, though both appear in Chinese works as early as 1100.[87] The Chinese also made use of the complex combinatorial diagram known as the magic square and magic circles, described in ancient times and perfected by Yang Hui (AD 1238–1298).[87]

The sociology and philosophy of science, as well as the entire field of science studies, have in the 20th century be occupy with the question of large-scale patterns and trends in the development of science, and ask questions about how science `` works'' both in a philosophical and practical sense.

In 1836, two ships of the South Australia Land Company leave to establish the first settlement on Kangaroo Island. The foundation of South Australia be now generally commemorate as Governor John Hindmarsh's Proclamation of the new Province at Glenelg, on the mainland, on 28 December 1836.[ 171] From 1843 to 1851, the Governor rule with the assistance of an appoint Executive Council of pay officials. Land development and settlement be the basis of the Wakefield vision, so land law and regulations govern it be fundamental to the foundation of the Province and allow for land to be buy at a uniform price per acre( regardless of quality), with auctions for land desire by more than one buyer, and leases make available on unused land. Proceeds from land be to fund the Emigration Fund to assist poor settlers to come as tradesmen and labourers.[ 172] Agitation for representative government quickly emerge.[ 173] Most other colonies have be found by Governors with near total authority, but in South Australia, power be initially divide between the Governor and the Resident Commissioner, so that government could not interfere with the business affairs or freedom of religion of the settlers. By 1851 the colony be experiment with a partially elect council.[ 174]

Along with the Egyptians the Babylonians introduce the practice of diagnosis, prognosis, physical examination, and remedies. In addition, the Diagnostic Handbook introduce the methods of therapy and etiology. The text contain a list of medical symptoms and often detailed empirical observations along with logical rules use in combine observed symptoms on the body of a patient with its diagnosis and prognosis.[ 14]

The history of sports may[ original research?] extend as far back as the beginnings of military training, with competition use as a means to determine whether individuals be fit and useful for service. Team sports may have develop to train and to prove the capability to fight and work together as a team( army). The history of sport can teach us about social changes and about the nature of sport itself,[ citation need] as sport seem[ original research?] involve in the development of basic human skills. Of course, as one go further back in history, dwindle evidence make theories of the origins and purposes of sport more and more difficult to support.

Special Relativity exerted another long-lasting effect on dynamics. Although initially it was credited with the "unification of mass and energy", it became evident that relativistic dynamics established a firm distinction between rest mass, which is an invariant (observer independent) property of a particle or system of particles, and the energy and momentum of a system. The latter two are separately conserved in all situations but not invariant with respect to different observers. The term mass in particle physics underwent a semantic change, and since the late 20th century it almost exclusively denotes the rest (or invariant) mass. See mass in special relativity for additional discussion.

Immediately after the war, American interest be rekindle with an explicitly geopolitical motive. Operation Highjump, from 1946-1947 be organize by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd Jr. and include 4,700 men, 13 ships, and multiple aircraft. The primary mission of Operation Highjump be to establish the Antarctic research base Little America IV,[ 79] for the purpose of training personnel and test equipment in frigid conditions and amplify exist stores of knowledge of hydrographic, geographic, geological, meteorological and electromagnetic propagation conditions in the area. The mission be also aim at consolidate and extend United States sovereignty over the largest practicable area of the Antarctic continent, although this be publicly deny as a goal even before the expedition end.

Emil Kraepelin (1856–1926) introduced new medical categories of mental illness, which eventually came into psychiatric usage despite their basis in behavior rather than pathology or etiology. Shell shock among frontline soldiers exposed to heavy artillery bombardment was first diagnosed by British Army doctors in 1915. By 1916, similar symptoms were also noted in soldiers not exposed to explosive shocks, leading to questions as to whether the disorder was physical or psychiatric.[143] In the 1920s surrealist opposition to psychiatry was expressed in a number of surrealist publications. In the 1930s several controversial medical practices were introduced including inducing seizures (by electroshock, insulin or other drugs) or cutting parts of the brain apart (leucotomy or lobotomy). Both came into widespread use by psychiatry, but there were grave concerns and much opposition on grounds of basic morality, harmful effects, or misuse.[144]

Early Modern architecture began with a number of building styles with similar characteristics, primarily the simplification of form and the elimination of ornament, that first arose around 1900. By the 1940s these styles had largely consolidated and been identified as the International Style.

Ravanahatha( ravanhatta, rawanhattha, ravanastron or ravana hasta veena) be a bowed fiddle popular in Western India. It be believe to have originate among the Hela civilisation of Sri Lanka in the time of King Ravana. This string instrument have be recognise as one of the oldest string instruments in world history.

In response to the Protestants, Catholics develop a counter-image to depict the High Middle Ages in particular as a period of social and religious harmony, and not'dark' at all.[ 19] The most important Catholic reply to the Magdeburg Centuries be the Annales Ecclesiastici by Cardinal Caesar Baronius. Baronius be a trained historian who produce a work that the Encyclopædia Britannica in 1911 describe as `` far surpass anything before''[ 20] and that Acton regard as `` the greatest history of the Church ever write''.[ 21] The Annales cover the first twelve centuries of Christianity to 1198, and be publish in twelve volumes between 1588 and 1607. It be in Volume X that Baronius coin the term'dark age' for the period between the end of the Carolingian Empire in 888[ 22] and the first stirrings of Gregorian Reform under Pope Clement II in 1046:

Dance may be performed in religious or shamanic rituals, for example in rain dance performed in times of drought. Shamans dancing for rain is mentioned in ancient Chinese texts. Dance is an important aspect of some religious rites in ancient Egypt,[2] similarly dance is also integral to many ceremonies and rites among African people.[3]

Similarly, in coastal Africa, local states supplied the appetite of European slave traders, changing the complexion of coastal African states and fundamentally altering the nature of African slavery, causing impacts on societies and economies deep inland. (See Atlantic slave trade).

Until the age of fourteen, the education of children be in the hands of their parents, but supervise by the authorities of their calpōlli. Part of this education involve learn a collection of sayings, call huēhuetlàtolli( `` sayings of the old''), that embody the Aztecs' ideals. Judged by their language, most of the huēhuetlàtolli seem to have evolve over several centuries, predate the Aztecs and most likely adopt from other Nahua cultures.

Following the rise of classical genetics, many biologists—including a new wave of physical scientists in biology—pursued the question of the gene and its physical nature. Warren Weaver—head of the science division of the Rockefeller Foundation—issued grants to promote research that applied the methods of physics and chemistry to basic biological problems, coining the term molecular biology for this approach in 1938; many of the significant biological breakthroughs of the 1930s and 1940s were funded by the Rockefeller Foundation.[65]
Between the 14th and 15th centuries, large Southeast African kingdoms and states emerge, such as the Buganda[ 160] and Karagwe[ 160] Kingdoms of Uganda and Tanzania.[ citation need]

With the help of a Tahitian name Tupaia, who have extensive knowledge of Pacific geography, Cook manage to reach New Zealand on 6 October 1769, lead only the second group of Europeans to do so( after Abel Tasman over a century earlier, in 1642). Cook map the complete New Zealand coastline, make only some minor errors( such as call Banks Peninsula an island, and think Stewart Island/Rakiura be a peninsula of the South Island). He also identify Cook Strait, which separate the North Island from the South Island, and which Tasman have not see.

Among develop countries, illiteracy and percentages without school in 2000 stood at about half the 1970 figures. Among developed countries, figures about illiteracy rates differ widely. Often it be say that they decrease from 6% to 1%. Illiteracy rates in less economically developed countries( LEDCs) surpass those of more economically developed countries( MEDCs) by a factor of 10 in 1970, and by a factor of about 20 in 2000. Illiteracy decrease greatly in LEDCs, and virtually disappear in MEDCs. Percentages without any schooling show similar patterns.

During this period, Spain experience the greatest epoch of cultural splendor in its history. This epoch be know as the Spanish Golden age and take place between the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.

The strongest contribution of the French Academies to the public sphere comes from the concours académiques (roughly translated as 'academic contests') they sponsored throughout France. These academic contests were perhaps the most public of any institution during the Enlightenment.[187] The practice of contests dated back to the Middle Ages, and was revived in the mid-17th century. The subject matter had previously been generally religious and/or monarchical, featuring essays, poetry, and painting. By roughly 1725, however, this subject matter had radically expanded and diversified, including "royal propaganda, philosophical battles, and critical ruminations on the social and political institutions of the Old Regime." Topics of public controversy were also discussed such as the theories of Newton and Descartes, the slave trade, women's education, and justice in France.[188]

Similarly, recent archaeological remains of iron work in the Ganges Valley in India have be tentatively date to 1800 BC. Tewari( 2003) conclude that `` knowledge of iron smelting and manufacturing of iron artifacts be well know in the Eastern Vindhyas and iron have be in use in the Central Ganga Plain, at least from the early second millennium BC''.[ 7] By the Middle Bronze Age, increase numbers of smelted iron objects( distinguishable from meteoric iron by the lack of nickel in the product) appear in the Middle East, Southeast Asia, and South Asia. African sites be turn up dates as early as 1200 BC.[ 8][ 9][ 10]

Kelvin and Clausius also state the second law of thermodynamics, which be originally formulate in terms of the fact that heat do not spontaneously flow from a colder body to a hotter. Other formulations follow quickly( for example, the second law be expound in Thomson and Peter Guthrie Tait's influential work Treatise on Natural Philosophy) and Kelvin in particular understood some of the law's general implications. The second Law be the idea that gas consist of molecules in motion have be discuss in some detail by Daniel Bernoulli in 1738, but have fall out of favor, and be revive by Clausius in 1857. In 1850, Hippolyte Fizeau and Léon Foucault measure the speed of light in water and find that it be slower than in air, in support of the wave model of light. In 1852, Joule and Thomson demonstrate that a rapidly expand gas cools, later name the Joule–Thomson effect or Joule–Kelvin effect. Hermann von Helmholtz put forward the idea of the heat death of the universe in 1854, the same year that Clausius establish the importance of dQ/T( Clausius's theorem)( though he do not yet name the quantity).

In Germany, there was a trend toward historic accuracy in costumes and settings, a revolution in theatre architecture, and the introduction of the theatrical form of German Romanticism. Influenced by trends in 19th-century philosophy and the visual arts, German writers were increasingly fascinated with their Teutonic past and had a growing sense of nationalism. The plays of Gotthold Ephraim Lessing, Johann Wolfgang von Goethe, Friedrich Schiller, and other Sturm und Drang playwrights, inspired a growing faith in feeling and instinct as guides to moral behavior.

In ancient India, the antecedents of politics can be trace back to the Rig-Veda, Samhitas, Brahmanas, the Mahabharata and Buddhist Pali Canon. Chanakya( c. 350–275 BC) be a political thinker in Takshashila. Chanakya write the Arthashastra, a treatise on political thought, economics and social order. It discuss monetary and fiscal policies, welfare, international relations, and war strategies in detail, among other topics. The Manusmriti, date to about two centuries after the time of Chanakya be another important Indian political treatise.

The Spanish colonies win their independence in the first quarter of the 19th century, in the Spanish American wars of independence. Simón Bolívar and José de San Martín, among others, lead their independence struggle. Although Bolivar attempt to keep the Spanish-speaking parts of the continent politically ally, they rapidly become independent of one another as well, and several further wars be fight, such as the Paraguayan War and the War of the Pacific.( See Latin American integration.) In the Portuguese colony Dom Pedro I( also Pedro IV of Portugal), son of the Portuguese king Dom João VI, proclaim the country's independence in 1822 and become Brazil's first Emperor. This be peacefully accept by the crown in Portugal, upon compensation.

At the same time, humanitarians and reformers were campaigning in Britain against the appalling conditions in British prisons and hulks. In 1777 prison reformer John Howard wrote The State of Prisons in England and Wales, exposing the harsh conditions of the prison system to "genteel society"."[111] Penal transportation was already well-established as a central plank of English criminal law and until the American Revolution about a thousand criminals per year were sent to Maryland and Virginia.[112] It served as a powerful deterrent to law-breaking. According to historian David Hill, "Europeans knew little about the geography of the globe" and to "convicts in England, transportation to Botany Bay was a frightening prospect." Echoing John Callander, he said Australia "might as well have been another planet."[113]

What is now China was inhabited by Homo erectus more than a million years ago.[7] Recent study shows that the stone tools found at Xiaochangliang site are magnetostratigraphically dated to 1.36 million years ago.[8] The archaeological site of Xihoudu in Shanxi Province is the earliest recorded use of fire by Homo erectus, which is dated 1.27 million years ago.[7] The excavations at Yuanmou and later Lantian show early habitation. Perhaps the most famous specimen of Homo erectus found in China is the so-called Peking Man discovered in 1923–27. Fossilised teeth of Homo sapiens dating to 125,000–80,000 BC have been discovered in Fuyan Cave in Dao County in Hunan.[9]
On 23 November 2007, the MS Explorer strike an iceberg and sank, but all on board be rescue by nearby ships, include a passing Norwegian cruise ship, the MS Nordnorge.

A combination of favorable geographical features contributed to the success of ancient Egyptian culture, the most important of which was the rich fertile soil resulting from annual inundations of the Nile River. The ancient Egyptians were thus able to produce an abundance of food, allowing the population to devote more time and resources to cultural, technological, and artistic pursuits. Land management was crucial in ancient Egypt because taxes were assessed based on the amount of land a person owned.[101]

It is often held that the roots of scientific ecology may be traced back to Darwin.[19] This contention may look convincing at first glance inasmuch as On the Origin of Species is full of observations and proposed mechanisms that clearly fit within the boundaries of modern ecology (e.g. the cat-to-clover chain – an ecological cascade) and because the term ecology was coined in 1866 by a strong proponent of Darwinism, Ernst Haeckel. However, Darwin never used the word in his writings after this year, not even in his most "ecological" writings such as the foreword to the English edition of Hermann Müller’s The Fertilization of Flowers (1883) or in his own treatise of earthworms and mull formation in forest soils (The formation of vegetable mould through the action of worms, 1881). Moreover, the pioneers founding ecology as a scientific discipline, such as Eugen Warming, A. F. W. Schimper, Gaston Bonnier, F.A. Forel, S.A. Forbes and Karl Möbius, made almost no reference to Darwin’s ideas in their works.[7] This was clearly not out of ignorance or because the works of Darwin were not widespread. Some such as S.A.Forbes studying intricate food webs asked questions as yet unanswered about the instability of food chains that might persist if dominant competitors were not adapted to have self-constraint.[20] Others focused on the dominant themes at the beginning, concern with the relationship between organism morphology and physiology on one side and environment on the other, mainly abiotic environment, hence environmental selection. Darwin’s concept of natural selection on the other hand focused primarily on competition.[21] The mechanisms other than competition that he described, primarily the divergence of character which can reduce competition and his statement that "struggle" as he used it was metaphorical and thus included environmental selection, were given less emphasis in the Origin than competition.[12] Despite most portrayals of Darwin conveying him as a non-aggressive recluse who let others fight his battles, Darwin remained all his life a man nearly obsessed with the ideas of competition, struggle and conquest – with all forms of human contact as confrontation.[12][22]
