In 1503, Binot Paulmier de Gonneville, challenging the Portuguese policy of mare clausum, led one of the earliest French Normand and Breton expeditions to Brazil. He intended to sail to the East Indies, but near the Cape of Good Hope his ship was diverted to west by a storm, and landed in the present day state of Santa Catarina (southern Brazil), on 5 January 1504.

Hip-hop dance started when Clive Campbell, aka Kool DJ Herc and the father of hip-hop, came to New York from Jamaica in 1967. Toting the seeds of reggae from his homeland, he is credited with being the first DJ to use two turntables and identical copies of the same record to create his jams. But it was his extension of the breaks in these songs—the musical section where the percussive beats were most aggressive—that allowed him to create and name a culture of break boys and break girls who laid it down when the breaks came up. Briefly termed b-boys and b-girls, these dancers founded breakdancing, which is now a cornerstone of hip-hop dance.[9]

The first of these, philosopher and physician Francisco Sanches, be lead by his medical training at Rome, 1571–73, to search for a true method of know( modus sciendi), as nothing clear can be know by the methods of Aristotle and his followers[ 55] — for example, 1) syllogism fail upon circular reasoning; 2) Aristotle's modal logic be not state clearly enough for use in medieval times, and remain a research problem to this day.[ 56] Following the physician Galen's method of medicine, Sanches list the methods of judgement and experience, which be faulty in the wrong hands,[ 57] and we be leave with the bleak statement That Nothing be Known( 1581, in Latin Quod Nihil Scitur). This challenge be take up by René Descartes in the next generation( 1637), but at the least, Sanches warn us that we ought to refrain from the methods, summaries, and commentaries on Aristotle, if we seek scientific knowledge. In this, he be echo by Francis Bacon who be influence by another prominent exponent of skepticism, Montaigne; Sanches cite the humanist Juan Luis Vives who seek a better educational system, as well as a statement of human rights as a pathway for improvement of the lot of the poor.

History of agricultural science looks at the scientific advancement of techniques and understanding of agriculture. Scientific study of fertilizer was advanced significantly in 1840 with the publication Die organische Chemie in ihrer Anwendung auf Agrikulturchemie und Physiologie (Organic Chemistry in Its Applications to Agriculture and Physiology) by Justus von Liebig.[1] One of Liebig's advances in agricultural science was the discovery of nitrogen as an essential plant nutrient.

Across cultures, the early history of linguistics be associate with a need to disambiguate discourse, especially for ritual texts or in arguments. This often lead to explorations of sound-meaning mappings, and the debate over conventional versus naturalistic origins for these symbols. Finally this lead to the processes by which larger structures be form from units.
In Mexico conflicts like the Reform War leave the state weak, and open to foreign influence. This lead to the Second French Empire to invade Mexico.

Construction of major railways connecting the larger cities and towns began in the 1830s but only gained momentum at the very end of the first Industrial Revolution. After many of the workers had completed the railways, they did not return to their rural lifestyles but instead remained in the cities, providing additional workers for the factories.

In the early 20th century, naturalists be face with increase pressure to add rigor and preferably experimentation to their methods, as the newly prominent laboratory-based biological disciplines have do. Ecology have emerge as a combination of biogeography with the biogeochemical cycle concept pioneer by chemists; field biologists develop quantitative methods such as the quadrat and adapted laboratory instruments and cameras for the field to further set their work apart from traditional natural history. Zoologists and botanists do what they could to mitigate the unpredictability of the living world, perform laboratory experiments and study semi-controlled natural environments such as gardens; new institutions like the Carnegie Station for Experimental Evolution and the Marine Biological Laboratory provide more controlled environments for study organisms through their entire life cycles.[ 51]

The Islamic civilization rise to primacy in medical science as its physicians contribute significantly to the field of medicine, include anatomy, ophthalmology, pharmacology, pharmacy, physiology, surgery, and the pharmaceutical sciences. The Arabs be influence by ancient Indian, Greek, Roman and Byzantine medical practices, and develop these further.[ 49] Galen& Hippocrates be pre-eminent authorities. The translation of 129 of Galen's works into Arabic by the Nestorian Christian Hunayn ibn Ishaq and his assistants, and in particular Galen's insistence on a rational systematic approach to medicine, set the template for Islamic medicine, which rapidly spread throughout the Arab Empire.[ 50]

By 2005, President George W. Bush's Road map for peace between Israel and the Palestinians be stall, although this situation have begin to change with Yasser Arafat's death in 2004. In response, Israel move towards a unilateral solution, push ahead with the Israeli West Bank barrier to protect Israel from Palestinian suicide bombers and propose unilateral withdrawal from Gaza. The barrier if complete would amount to a de facto annexation of areas of the West Bank by Israel. In 2006 a new conflict erupt between Israel and Hezbollah Shi’a militia in southern Lebanon, further set back any `` prospects for peace''.

In chemistry, one central issue was the distinction between organic and inorganic substances, especially in the context of organic transformations such as fermentation and putrefaction. Since Aristotle these had been considered essentially biological (vital) processes. However, Friedrich Wöhler, Justus Liebig and other pioneers of the rising field of organic chemistry—building on the work of Lavoisier—showed that the organic world could often be analyzed by physical and chemical methods. In 1828 Wöhler showed that the organic substance urea could be created by chemical means that do not involve life, providing a powerful challenge to vitalism. Cell extracts ("ferments") that could effect chemical transformations were discovered, beginning with diastase in 1833. By the end of the 19th century the concept of enzymes was well established, though equations of chemical kinetics would not be applied to enzymatic reactions until the early 20th century.[48]

In addition to lithic analysis, the field prehistorian utilize a wide range of techniques derive from multiple fields. The work of the archaeologist in determine the paleocontext and relative sequence of the layers be supplement by the efforts of the geologic specialist in identify layers of rock over geologic time, of the paleontological specialist in identify bones and animals, of the palynologist in discover and identify plant species, of the physicist and chemist in laboratories determine dates by the carbon-14, potassium-argon and other methods. Study of the Stone Age have never be mainly about stone tools and archaeology, which be only one form of evidence. The chief focus have always be on the society and the physical people who belong to it.

There be several problems with alchemy, as see from today's standpoint. There be no systematic naming scheme for new compounds, and the language be esoteric and vague to the point that the terminologies mean different things to different people. In fact, accord to The Fontana History of Chemistry( Brock, 1992):

De Magnete be influential not only because of the inherent interest of its subject matter, but also for the rigorous way in which Gilbert describe his experiments and his rejection of ancient theories of magnetism.[ 40] According to Thomas Thomson, `` Gilbert['s] ... book on magnetism publish in 1600, be one of the finest examples of inductive philosophy that have ever be present to the world. It be the more remarkable, because it precede the Novum Organum of Bacon, in which the inductive method of philosophizing be first explain. ``[ 41]

The willingness to question previously held truths and search for new answers resulted in a period of major scientific advancements, now known as the Scientific Revolution. The Scientific Revolution is traditionally held by most historians to have begun in 1543, when the books De humani corporis fabrica (On the Workings of the Human Body) by Andreas Vesalius, and also De Revolutionibus, by the astronomer Nicolaus Copernicus, were first printed. The thesis of Copernicus' book was that the Earth moved around the Sun. The period culminated with the publication of the Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica in 1687 by Isaac Newton, representative of the unprecedented growth of scientific publications throughout Europe.

Inevitably, the domination of politics and concomitant aggregation of wealth by small groups of families was apt to cause social unrest in many poleis. In many cities a tyrant (not in the modern sense of repressive autocracies), would at some point seize control and govern according to their own will; often a populist agenda would help sustain them in power. In a system wracked with class conflict, government by a 'strongman' was often the best solution.

The Zhou initially move their capital west to an area near modern Xi'an, on the Wei River, a tributary of the Yellow River, but they would preside over a series of expansions into the Yangtze River valley. This would be the first of many population migrations from north to south in Chinese history.

Teotihuacan( `` The City of the Gods'' in Nahuatl) originate toward the end of the Preclassic period, circa 100 CE. Very little be know about its founders, but it be believe that the Otomí have an important role in the city's development, as they do in the ancient culture of the Valley of Mexico, represent by Tlatilco. Teotihuacan initially compete with Cuicuilco for hegemony in the area. In this political and economic battle, Teotihuacan be aid by its control of the obsidian deposits in the Navaja mountains in Hidalgo. The decline of Cuicuilco be still a mystery, but it be know that a large part of the former inhabitants resettle in Teotihuacan some years before the eruption of Xitle, which cover the southern town in lava.
In the classical era, several flourish Somali city-states such as Opone, Mosylon, Cape Guardafui, and Malao compete with the Sabaeans, Parthians and Axumites for the rich Indo-Greco-Roman trade.[ 51]

Onto this turbulent scene emerge Gaius Julius Caesar, from an aristocratic family of limited wealth. His aunt Julia be Marius' wife,[ 50] and Caesar identify with the populares. To achieve power, Caesar reconcile the two most powerful men in Rome: Marcus Licinius Crassus, who have finance much of his earlier career, and Crassus' rival, Gnaeus Pompeius Magnus( anglicize as Pompey), to whom he marry his daughter. He form them into a new informal alliance include himself, the First Triumvirate( `` three men''). This satisfy the interests of all three: Crassus, the richest man in Rome, become richer and ultimately achieve high military command; Pompey exert more influence in the Senate; and Caesar obtain the consulship and military command in Gaul.[ 51] So long as they could agree, the three be in effect the rulers of Rome.

After some exploration, Tasman have intend to proceed in a northerly direction but as the wind be unfavourable he steer east. On 13 December they sight land on the north-west coast of the South Island, New Zealand, become the first Europeans to do so.[ 60] Tasman name it Staten Landt on the assumption that it be connect to an island( Staten Island, Argentina) at the south of the tip of South America. Proceeding north and then east, he stop to gather water, but one of his boats be attack by Māori in a double hull waka( canoes) and four of his men be attack and kill by mere. As Tasman sail out of the bay he be again attack, this time by 11 waka. The waka approach the Zeehan which fire and hit one Māori who fell down. Canister shot hit the side of a waka.[ 61] Archeological research have show the Dutch have try to land at a major agricultural area, which the Māori may have be try to protect.[ 62] Tasman name the bay Murderers' Bay( now know as Golden Bay) and sail north, but mistake Cook Strait for a bight( name it Zeehaen's Bight). Two names he give to New Zealand landmarks still endure, Cape Maria van Diemen and Three Kings Islands, but Kaap Pieter Boreels be rename by Cook 125 years later to Cape Egmont.

After the voyages of Christopher Columbus in 1492, Spanish, Portuguese and later English, French and Dutch colonial expeditions arrived in the New World, conquering and settling the discovered lands, which led to a transformation of the cultural and physical landscape in the Americas. Spain colonized most of the American continent from present-day Southwestern United States, Florida and the Caribbean to the southern tip of South America. Portugal settled in what is mostly present-day Brazil while England established colonies in the Eastern coast of the United States, as well as the North Pacific coast and most of Canada. France settled in Quebec and other parts of Eastern Canada and claimed an area in what is today the central United States. The Netherlands settled New Netherlands (administrative centre New Amsterdam - now New York), some Caribbean islands and parts of Northern South America.

China also developed a large body of traditional medicine. Much of the philosophy of traditional Chinese medicine derived from empirical observations of disease and illness by Taoist physicians and reflects the classical Chinese belief that individual human experiences express causative principles effective in the environment at all scales. These causative principles, whether material, essential, or mystical, correlate as the expression of the natural order of the universe.

The most popular forms of theatre in the medieval Islamic world were puppet theatre (which included hand puppets, shadow plays and marionette productions) and live passion plays known as ta'ziya, in which actors re-enact episodes from Muslim history. In particular, Shia Islamic plays revolved around the shaheed (martyrdom) of Ali's sons Hasan ibn Ali and Husayn ibn Ali. Secular plays known as akhraja were recorded in medieval adab literature, though they were less common than puppetry and ta'ziya theatre.[109]

In the Termit region of eastern Niger, its ancient inhabitants are now thought to have become the first iron smelting people in West Africa and among the first in the world at around 1500 BC. Iron and copper working then continued to spread southward to Nigeria, and then moved elsewhere in the continent, reaching South Africa around AD 200. The widespread use of iron revolutionized the Bantu-speaking farming communities who adopted it, driving out and absorbing the rock tool using hunter-gatherer societies they encountered as they expanded to farm wider areas of savannah. The technologically superior Bantu-speakers spread across southern Africa and became wealthy and powerful, producing iron for tools and weapons in large, industrial quantities.[dubious – discuss][citation needed]

The Paleo-Indian( less frequently, Lithic) period or era be that which span from the first signs of human presence in the region, to the establishment of agriculture and other practices( e.g. pottery, permanent settlements) and subsistence techniques characteristic of proto-civilizations. In Mesoamerica, the termination of this phase and its transition into the succeed Archaic period may generally be reckon at between 10,000 and 8000 BCE, although this dating be approximate only and different timescales may be use between fields and sub-regions.

From 1917 to 1923, the American Red Cross move into Europe with a battery of long-term child health projects. It build and operated hospitals and clinics, and organize antituberculosis and antityphus campaigns. A high priority involve child health programs such as clinics, better baby shows, playgrounds, fresh air camps, and courses for women on infant hygiene. Hundreds of U.S. doctors, nurses, and welfare professionals administer these programs, which aim to reform the health of European youth and to reshape European public health and welfare along American lines.[ 151]

The Protestant Reformation also lead to a strong reform movement in the Catholic Church call the Counter-Reformation, which aim to reduce corruption as well as to improve and strengthen Catholic Dogma. Two important groups in the Catholic Church who emerge from this movement be the Jesuits, who help keep Spain, Portugal, Poland and other European countries within the Catholic fold, and the Oratorians of St Philip Neri, who minister to the faithful in Rome, restore their confidence in the Church of Jesus Christ that subsist substantially in the Church of Rome. Still, the Catholic Church be somewhat weaken by the Reformation, portions of Europe be no longer under its sway and kings in the remain Catholic countries begin to take control of the Church institutions within their kingdoms.

In 1591, Morocco invade the Songhai Empire under Ahmad al-Mansur of the Saadi Dynasty in order to secure the goldfields of the Sahel. At the Battle of Tondibi, the Songhai army be defeat. The Moroccans capture Djenne, Gao, and Timbuktu, but they be unable to secure the whole region. Askiya Nuhu and the Songhay army regroup at Dendi in the heart of Songhai territory where a spirited guerrilla resistance sap the resources of the Moroccans, who be dependent upon constant resupply from Morocco. Songhai split into several states during the 17th century.

The first significant renewal of learn in the West come when Charlemagne, advise by Peter of Pisa and Alcuin of York, attract the scholars of England and Ireland, and by imperial decree in 787 AD establish schools in every abbey in his empire. These schools, from which the name Scholasticism be derive, become centres of medieval learning.

By study the evidence give by all available sources, and by correlate the relevant facts, we obtain some idea of the origin and development of the units. We find that they have change more or less gradually with the passing of time in a complex manner because of a great variety of modify influences.[ citation need] It be possible to group official measurement systems for large societies into historical systems that be relatively stable over time, include: the Babylonian system, the Egyptian system, the Phileterian system of the Ptolemaic age, the Olympic system of Greece, the Roman system, the British system, and the metric system.

The Lakhmid Kingdom was founded by the Lakhum tribe that immigrated out of Yemen in the 2nd century and ruled by the Banu Lakhm, hence the name given it. It was formed of a group of Arab Christians who lived in Southern Iraq, and made al-Hirah their capital in (266). The founder of the dynasty was 'Amr and the son Imru' al-Qais converted to Christianity. Gradually the whole city converted to that faith. Imru' al-Qais dreamt of a unified and independent Arab kingdom and, following that dream, he seized many cities in Arabia.

Max Ernst whose 1920 painting Murdering Airplane, studied philosophy and psychology in Bonn and was interested in the alternative realities experienced by the insane. His paintings may have been inspired by the psychoanalyst Sigmund Freud's study of the delusions of a paranoiac, Daniel Paul Schreber. Freud identified Schreber's fantasy of becoming a woman as a castration complex. The central image of two pairs of legs refers to Schreber's hermaphroditic desires. Ernst's inscription on the back of the painting reads: The picture is curious because of its symmetry. The two sexes balance one another.[53]

Van Diemen's Land, now known as Tasmania, was settled in 1803, following a failed attempt to settle at Sullivan Bay in what is now Victoria. Other British settlements followed, at various points around the continent, many of them unsuccessful. The East India Trade Committee recommended in 1823 that a settlement be established on the coast of northern Australia to forestall the Dutch, and Captain J.J.G. Bremer, RN, was commissioned to form a settlement between Bathurst Island and the Cobourg Peninsula. Bremer fixed the site of his settlement at Fort Dundas on Melville Island in 1824 and, because this was well to the west of the boundary proclaimed in 1788, proclaimed British sovereignty over all the territory as far west as longitude 129° East.[140]

Diocletian abdicate in 305 AD together with Maximian, thus, he be the first Roman emperor to resign. His reign end the traditional form of imperial rule, the Principate( from princeps) and start the Dominate( from Dominus, `` Master'').

Similar atomist ideas emerged independently among ancient Indian philosophers of the Nyaya, Vaisesika and Buddhist schools.[11] In particular,like the Nyaya, Vaisesika, and Buddhist schools, the Cārvāka epistemology was also materialist, and skeptical enough to admit only perception as the basis for unconditionally true knowledge, while cautioning that if one could only infer a truth, then one must also harbor a doubt about that truth; an inferred truth could not be unconditional.[12]
In 1884, a groundbreaking education conference was held in London at the International Health Exhibition, attracting specialists from all over Europe.[65]

The germ theory of disease in the 19th century led to cures for many infectious diseases. Military doctors advanced the methods of trauma treatment and surgery. Public health measures were developed especially in the 19th century as the rapid growth of cities required systematic sanitary measures. Advanced research centers opened in the early 20th century, often connected with major hospitals. The mid-20th century was characterized by new biological treatments, such as antibiotics. These advancements, along with developments in chemistry, genetics, and lab technology (such as the x-ray) led to modern medicine. Medicine was heavily professionalized in the 20th century, and new careers opened to women as nurses (from the 1870s) and as physicians (especially after 1970). The 21st century is characterized by highly advanced research involving numerous fields of science.

By 1227, the Mongols had conquered the Western Xia kingdom northwest of China. Soon the Mongols incurred upon the Jin empire of the Jurchens. Chinese cities were soon besieged by the Mongol hordes that showed little mercy for those who resisted and the Southern Song Chinese were quickly losing territory. In 1271 the current great khan, Kublai Khan, claimed himself Emperor of China and officially established the Yuan Dynasty. By 1290, all of China was under control of the Mongols, marking the first time they were ever completely conquered by a foreign invader; the new capital was established at Khanbaliq (modern-day Beijing). Kublai Khan segregated Mongol culture from Chinese culture by discouraging interactions between the two peoples, separating living spaces and places of worship, and reserving top administrative positions to Mongols, thus preventing Confucian scholars to continue the bureaucratic system. Nevertheless, Kublai remained fascinated with Chinese thinking, surrounding himself with Chinese Buddhist, Taoist, or Confucian advisors.

The Feast of Fools be especially important in the development of comedy. The festival invert the status of the lesser clergy and allow them to ridicule their superiors and the routine of church life. Sometimes plays be stag as part of the occasion and a certain amount of burlesque and comedy crept into these performances. Although comic episodes have to truly wait until the separation of drama from the liturgy, the Feast of Fools undoubtedly have a profound effect on the development of comedy in both religious and secular plays.[ 37]

Herophilus of Chalcedon, work at the medical school of Alexandria place intelligence in the brain, and connect the nervous system to motion and sensation. Herophilus also distinguish between veins and arteries, note that the latter pulse while the former do not. He and his contemporary, Erasistratus of Chios, research the role of veins and nerves, map their courses across the body. Erasistratus connect the increased complexity of the surface of the human brain compare to other animals to its superior intelligence. He sometimes employ experiments to further his research, at one time repeatedly weigh a caged bird, and note its weight loss between feed times. In Erasistratus' physiology, air enters the body, be then draw by the lungs into the heart, where it be transform into vital spirit, and be then pump by the arteries throughout the body. Some of this vital spirit reach the brain, where it be transform into animal spirit, which be then distribute by the nerves.[ 39]

Terra Australis Ignota( Latin, `` the unknown land of the south'') be a hypothetical continent appear on European maps from the 15th to the 18th centuries, with roots in a notion introduce by Aristotle. It be depict on the mid-16th-century Dieppe maps, where its coastline appear just south of the islands of the East Indies; it be often elaborately chart, with a wealth of fictitious detail. The discoveries reduce the area where the continent could be find; however, many cartographers hold to Aristotle's opinion, like Gerardus Mercator( 1569) and Alexander Dalrymple even so late as 1767[ 131] argue for its existence, with such arguments as that there should be a large landmass in the Southern Hemisphere as a counterweight to the know landmasses in the Northern Hemisphere. As new lands be discover, they be often assume to be parts of this hypothetical continent.

Conflict in the Hawkesbury Nepean river district near the settlement at Sydney continued from 1795–1816.[citation needed] Pemulwuy's War (1795–1802), Tedbury's War (1808–1809) and the Nepean War (1814–1816) as well as the interwar violence of the 1804–1805 Conflict. It was fought using mostly guerrilla-warfare tactics; however, several conventional battles also took place. The wars resulted in the defeat of the Hawkesbury and Nepean Indigenous clans who were subsequently dispossessed of their lands.[citation needed]

Aside from Carthage, urbanization in North Africa came in part with the establishment of settlements of veterans under the Roman emperors Claudius (reigned 41-54), Nerva (96-98), and Trajan (98-117). In Algeria such settlements included Tipasa, Cuicul or Curculum (modern Djemila, northeast of Sétif), Thamugadi (modern Timgad, southeast of Sétif), and Sitifis (modern Sétif). The prosperity of most towns depended on agriculture. Called the "granary of the empire", North Africa became one of the largest exporters of grain in the empire, shipping to the provinces which did not produce cereals, like Italy and Greece. Other crops included fruit, figs, grapes, and beans. By the 2nd century CE, olive oil rivaled cereals as an export item.[citation needed]

In several nations, rulers welcomed leaders of the Enlightenment at court and asked them to help design laws and programs to reform the system, typically to build stronger national states. These rulers are called "enlightened despots" by historians.[51] They included Frederick the Great of Prussia, Catherine the Great of Russia, Leopold II of Tuscany, and Joseph II of Austria. Joseph was over-enthusiastic, announcing many reforms that had little support, so that revolts broke out and his regime became a comedy of errors, and nearly all his programs were reversed.[52] Senior ministers Pombal in Portugal and Struensee in Denmark also governed according to Enlightenment ideals. In Poland, the model constitution of 1791 expressed Enlightenment ideals, but was in effect for only one year before the nation was partitioned among its neighbors. More enduring were the cultural achievements, which created a nationalist spirit in Poland.[53]

Maize and manioc were introduced into Africa in the 16th century by the Portuguese.[142] They are now important staple foods, replacing native African crops.[143][144] Alfred W. Crosby speculated that increased production of maize, manioc, and other New World crops led to heavier concentrations of population in the areas from which slavers captured their victims.[145]

The Medieval and Early Modern periods in India be define by the disruption to native Indian elites by Muslim Central Asian nomadic clans;[ 4][ 5] lead to the Rajput resistance to Muslim conquests, and growth of Hindu, Muslim, and Sikh, dynasties and empires, build upon new military technology and techniques;[ 258] the rise of theistic devotional trend of the Bhakti movement, the cultural synthesis of Hindu and Muslim elements reflect in Indo-Islamic architecture;[ 259][ 260] and come to an end with the British Raj.

The Renaissance be certainly underway before Lorenzo de' Medici come to power – indeed, before the Medici family itself achieve hegemony in Florentine society. Some historians have postulate that Florence be the birthplace of the Renaissance as a result of luck, i.e. because `` Great Men'' be bear there by chance:[ 43] Leonardo da Vinci, Botticelli and Michelangelo be all bear in Tuscany. Arguing that such chance seem improbable, other historians have contend that these `` Great Men'' be only able to rise to prominence because of the prevailing cultural conditions at the time.[ 44]

Heraclitus of Ephesus( about 535–475 BC), then maintain that change, rather than any substance be fundamental, although the element fire seem to play a central role in this process.[ 8] Finally, Empedocles of Acragas( 490–430 BC), seem to have combine the views of his predecessors, assert that there be four elements( Earth, Water, Air and Fire) which produce change by mix and separate under the influence of two oppose `` forces'' that he call Love and Strife.[ 9]

The Italian artist and critic Giorgio Vasari( 1511–1574) first use the term rinascita retrospectively in his book The Lives of the Artists( publish 1550). In the book Vasari attempt to define what he describe as a break with the barbarities of gothic art: the arts( he hold) have fall into decay with the collapse of the Roman Empire and only the Tuscan artists, begin with Cimabue( 1240–1301) and Giotto( 1267–1337) begin to reverse this decline in the arts. Vasari saw antique art as central to the rebirth of Italian art.[ 100]

As of 2016, 400 million people speak English as their first language, and 1.1 billion speak it as a secondary language.[ 59] English be probably the third largest language by number of native speakers, after Mandarin and Spanish.[ 8] However, when combine native and non-native speakers it may, depend on the estimate use, be the most commonly spoken language in the world.[ 53][ 60][ 61][ 62] English be speak by communities on every continent and on oceanic islands in all the major oceans.[ 63] The countries in which English be speak can be group into different categories by how English be use in each country. The `` inner circle''[ 64] countries with many native speakers of English share an international standard of write English and jointly influence speech norms of English around the world. English do not belong to just one country, and it do not belong solely to descendants of English settlers. English be an official language of countries populate by few descendants of native speakers of English. It have also become by far the most important language of international communication when people who share no native language meet anywhere in the world.

The Shunga Empire be an ancient Indian dynasty from Magadha that control vast areas of the Indian subcontinent from around 187 to 78 BCE. The dynasty be establish by Pushyamitra Shunga, after the fall of the Maurya Empire. Its capital be Pataliputra, but later emperors such as Bhagabhadra also hold court at Besnagar, modern Vidisha in Eastern Malwa.[ 141] Pushyamitra Shunga rule for 36 years and be succeed by his son Agnimitra. There be ten Shunga rulers. The empire be note for its numerous wars with both foreign and indigenous powers. They fight battles with the Kalingas, Satavahanas, the Indo-Greeks, and possibly the Panchalas and Mathuras. Art, education, philosophy, and other forms of learn flower during this period include small terracotta images, larger stone sculptures, and architectural monuments such as the Stupa at Bharhut, and the renowned Great Stupa at Sanchi. The Shunga rulers help to establish the tradition of royal sponsorship of learning and art. The script use by the empire be a variant of Brahmi and be use to write the Sanskrit language. The Shunga Empire play an imperative role in patronise Indian culture at a time when some of the most important developments in Hindu thought be take place. This help the empire flourish and gain power.

Indeed, when John Napier discover logarithms for computational purposes in the early 17th century, there follow a period of considerable progress by inventors and scientists in make calculating tools. The apex of this early era of formal computing can be see in the difference engine and its successor the analytical engine( which be never completely construct but be design in detail), both by Charles Babbage. The analytical engine combine concepts from his work and that of others to create a device that if construct as design would have possess many properties of a modern electronic computer. These properties include such features as an internal `` scratch memory'' equivalent to RAM, multiple forms of output include a bell, a graph-plotter, and simple printer, and a programmable input-output `` hard'' memory of punch cards which it could modify as well as read. The key advancement which Babbage's devices possess beyond those create before his be that each component of the device be independent of the rest of the machine, much like the components of a modern electronic computer. This be a fundamental shift in thought; previous computational devices serve only a single purpose, but have to be at best disassembled and reconfigured to solve a new problem. Babbage's devices could be reprogramed to solve new problems by the entry of new data, and act upon previous calculations within the same series of instructions. Ada Lovelace take this concept one step further, by create a program for the analytical engine to calculate Bernoulli numbers, a complex calculation require a recursive algorithm. This be consider to be the first example of a true computer program, a series of instructions that act upon data not know in full until the program be run.

In 1643 Kurbat Ivanov lead a group of Cossacks from Yakutsk to the south of the Baikal Mountains and discover Lake Baikal, visit its Olkhon Island. Later Ivanov make the first chart and description of Baikal.[ 137]

Trading relations be establish with Malacca in the 15th century,[ 95] with cloth, ambergris, and porcelain be the main commodities of the trade.[ 96] Giraffes, zebras, and incense be export to the Ming Empire of China, which establish Somali merchants as leaders in the commerce between the Asia and Africa[ 97] and influence the Chinese language with borrowings from the Somali language in the process. Hindu merchants from Surat and southeast African merchants from Pate, seek to bypass both the Portuguese blockade and Omani meddling, use the Somali ports of Merca and Barawa( which be out of the two powers' jurisdiction) to conduct their trade in safety and without any problems.[ 98]

Eventually abstract painting in America evolve into movements such as Neo-Dada, Color Field painting, Post painterly abstraction, Op art, hard-edge painting, Minimal art, shape canvas painting, Lyrical Abstraction, Neo-expressionism and the continuation of Abstract expressionism. As a response to the tendency toward abstraction imagery emerge through various new movements, notably Pop art.

By 1000 CE, numerous states had arisen on the Lake Plateau among the Great Lakes of East Africa. Cattle herding, cereal growing, and banana cultivation were the economic mainstays of these states. The Ntusi and Bigo earthworks are representative of one of the first states, the Bunyoro kingdom, which oral tradition stipulates was part of the Empire of Kitara that dominated the whole Lakes region. A Luo ethnic elite, from the Bito clan, ruled over the Bantu-speaking Nyoro people. The society was essentially Nyoro in its culture, based on the evidence from pottery, settlement patterns, and economic specialization.[161]

The Indian early medieval age, 600 to 1200, be define by regional kingdoms and cultural diversity. When Harsha of Kannauj, who rule much of the Indo-Gangetic Plain from 606 to 647, attempt to expand southwards, he be defeat by the Chalukya ruler of the Deccan. When his successor attempt to expand eastwards, he be defeat by the Pala king of Bengal. When the Chalukyas attempt to expand southwards, they be defeat by the Pallavas from farther south, who in turn be oppose by the Pandyas and the Cholas from still farther south. No ruler of this period be able to create an empire and consistently control land much beyond his core region. During this time, pastoral peoples whose land have be clear to make way for the grow agricultural economy be accommodate within caste society, as be new non-traditional ruling classes.[ 18]

Laparoscopic surgery be broadly introduce in the 1990s. Natural orifice surgery have follow. Remote surgery be another recent development, with the Lindbergh operation in 2001 as a groundbreaking example.

Modern theatre in Ghana emerged in the early 20th century.[84] It emerged first as literary comment on the colonization of Africa by Europe.[84] Among the earliest work in which this can be seen is The Blinkards written by Kobina Sekyi in 1915. The Blinkards is a blatant satire about the Africans who embraced the European culture that was brought to them. In it Sekyi demeans three groups of individuals: anyone European, anyone who imitates the Europeans, and the rich African cocoa farmer. This sudden rebellion though was just the beginning spark of Ghanaian literary theater.[84]

Romanesque, prevalent in medieval Europe during the 11th and 12th centuries, be the first pan-European style since Roman Imperial architecture and examples be find in every part of the continent. The term be not contemporary with the art it describe, but rather, be an invention of modern scholarship base on its similarity to Roman architecture in forms and materials. Romanesque be characterize by a use of round or slightly pointed arches, barrel vaults, and cruciform piers support vaults.

The coronation of Charlemagne as emperor on Christmas Day 800 be regard as a turn point in medieval history, mark a return of the Western Roman Empire, since the new emperor rule over much of the area previously control by the western emperors.[ 104] It also mark a change in Charlemagne's relationship with the Byzantine Empire, as the assumption of the imperial title by the Carolingians assert their equivalence to the Byzantine state.[ 105] There be several differences between the newly establish Carolingian Empire and both the older Western Roman Empire and the concurrent Byzantine Empire. The Frankish lands be rural in character, with only a few small cities. Most of the people be peasants settle on small farms. Little trade exist and much of that be with the British Isles and Scandinavia, in contrast to the older Roman Empire with its trading networks centre on the Mediterranean.[ 104] The empire be administer by an itinerant court that travel with the emperor, as well as approximately 300 imperial officials call counts, who administer the counties the empire have be divide into. Clergy and local bishops serve as officials, as well as the imperial officials call missi dominici, who serve as roving inspectors and troubleshooters.[ 106]

While earlier research point to edible domestic plants such as squash, beans, lucuma, guava, pacay, and camote at Caral, publications by Haas and colleagues have add avocado, achira, and corn( Zea Mays) to the list of foods consume in the region. In 2013, Haas and colleagues report that maize be a primary component of the diet throughout the period of 3000 to 1800 BC.[ 18]
Maya history span 3,000 years. The Classic Maya may have collapse due to change climate in the end of the 10th century.

Subsequently, Plato and Aristotle produced the first systematic discussions of natural philosophy, which did much to shape later investigations of nature. Their development of deductive reasoning was of particular importance and usefulness to later scientific inquiry. Plato founded the Platonic Academy in 387 BC, whose motto was "Let none unversed in geometry enter here", and turned out many notable philosophers. Plato's student Aristotle introduced empiricism and the notion that universal truths can be arrived at via observation and induction, thereby laying the foundations of the scientific method.[23] Aristotle also produced many biological writings that were empirical in nature, focusing on biological causation and the diversity of life. He made countless observations of nature, especially the habits and attributes of plants and animals in the world around him, classified more than 540 animal species, and dissected at least 50. Aristotle's writings profoundly influenced subsequent Islamic and European scholarship, though they were eventually superseded in the Scientific Revolution.

The beginning of the 1st millennium BC saw extensive developments in iron metallurgy in India. Technological advancement and mastery of iron metallurgy was achieved during this period of peaceful settlements. One iron working centre in east India has been dated to the first millennium BC.[28] In Southern India (present day Mysore) iron appeared as early as 12th to 11th centuries BC; these developments were too early for any significant close contact with the northwest of the country.[28] The Indian Upanishads mention metallurgy.[29] and the Indian Mauryan period saw advances in metallurgy.[30] As early as 300 BC, certainly by 200 AD, high quality steel was produced in southern India, by what would later be called the crucible technique. In this system, high-purity wrought iron, charcoal, and glass were mixed in crucible and heated until the iron melted and absorbed the carbon.[31]

The Terramare be an early Indo-European civilization in the area of what be now Pianura Padana( northern Italy) before the arrival of the Celts, and in other parts of Europe. They live in square villages of wooden stilt houses. These villages be build on land, but generally near a stream, with roads that cross each other at right angles. The whole complex denote the nature of a fortified settlement. Terramare be widespread in the Pianura Padana( specially along the Panaro river, between Modena and Bologna) and in the rest of Europe. The civilization develop in the Middle and Late Bronze Age, between the 17th and the 13th centuries BC.

Further changes were set afoot with a redivision of power in Europe. William the Conqueror, a Duke of Normandy invaded England in 1066. The Norman Conquest was a pivotal event in English history for several reasons. This linked England more closely with continental Europe through the introduction of a Norman aristocracy, thereby lessening Scandinavian influence. It created one of the most powerful monarchies in Europe and engendered a sophisticated governmental system. Being based on an island, moreover, England was to develop a powerful navy and trade relationships that would come to constitute a vast part of the world including India, Australia, New Zealand, Canada and many key naval strategic points like Bermuda, Suez, Hong Kong and especially Gibraltar. These strategic advantages grew and were to prove decisive until after the Second World War.

The bitter struggle between the KMT and the CPC continue, openly or clandestinely, through the 14-year-long Japanese occupation of various parts of the country( 1931–1945). The two Chinese parties nominally form a united front to oppose the Japanese in 1937, during the Second Sino-Japanese War( 1937–1945), which become a part of World War II. Japanese forces commit numerous war atrocities against the civilian population, include biological warfare( see Unit 731) and the Three Alls Policy( Sankō Sakusen), the three alls be: `` Kill All, Burn All and Loot All''.[ 47]

The Iron Age in the Ancient Near East be believe to have begin with the discovery of iron smelting and smithing techniques in Anatolia or the Caucasus and Balkans in the late 2nd millennium BC( c. 1300 BC).[ 17] However, this theory have be challenge by the emergence of those place the transition in price and availability issues rather than the development of technology on its own. The earliest bloomery smelting of iron be find at Tell Hammeh, Jordan around 930 BC( C14 date).

Hipparchus( 190–120 BCE), focus on astronomy and mathematics, use sophisticated geometrical techniques to map the motion of the stars and planets, even predict the times that Solar eclipses would happen. In addition, he add calculations of the distance of the Sun and Moon from the Earth, base upon his improvements to the observational instruments use at that time. Another of the most famous of the early physicists be Ptolemy( 90–168 CE), one of the lead minds during the time of the Roman Empire. Ptolemy be the author of several scientific treatises, at least three of which be of continue importance to later Islamic and European science. The first be the astronomical treatise now know as the Almagest( in Greek, Ἡ Μεγάλη Σύνταξις, `` The Great Treatise'', originally Μαθηματικὴ Σύνταξις, `` Mathematical Treatise''). The second be the Geography, which be a thorough discussion of the geographic knowledge of the Greco-Roman world.

Commodus was killed by a conspiracy involving Quintus Aemilius Laetus and his wife Marcia in late 192 AD. The following year is known as the Year of the Five Emperors, during which Helvius Pertinax, Didius Julianus, Pescennius Niger, Clodius Albinus and Septimius Severus held the imperial dignity. Pertinax, a member of the senate who had been one of Marcus Aurelius's right hand men, was the choice of Laetus, and he ruled vigorously and judiciously. Laetus soon became jealous and instigated Pertinax's murder by the Praetorian Guard, who then auctioned the empire to the highest bidder, Didius Julianus, for 25,000 sesterces per man.[109] The people of Rome were appalled and appealed to the frontier legions to save them. The legions of three frontier provinces—Britain, Pannonia Superior, and Syria—resented being excluded from the "donative" and replied by declaring their individual generals to be emperor. Lucius Septimius Severus Geta, the Pannonian commander, bribed the opposing forces, pardoned the Praetorian Guards and installed himself as emperor. He and his successors governed with the legions' support. The changes on coinage and military expenditures were the root of the financial crisis that marked the Crisis of the Third Century.

In the 7th century CE, Kumārila Bhaṭṭa formulate his school of Mimamsa philosophy and defend the position on Vedic rituals against Buddhist attacks. Scholars note Bhaṭṭa's contribution to the decline of Buddhism in India.[ 201] His dialectical success against the Buddhists be confirm by Buddhist historian Tathagata, who report that Kumārila defeat disciples of Buddhapalkita, Bhavya, Dharmadasa, Dignaga and others.[ 202]
It be the religious and philosophical framework of the Chinese intellectuals which make them unable to believe in the ideas of laws of nature:

The synthesis of urea by Friedrich Wöhler open a new research field, organic chemistry, and by the end of the 19th century, scientists be able to synthesize hundreds of organic compounds. The later part of the 19th century saw the exploitation of the Earth's petrochemicals, after the exhaustion of the oil supply from whale. By the 20th century, systematic production of refined materials provide a ready supply of products which provide not only energy, but also synthetic materials for clothing, medicine, and everyday disposable resources. Application of the techniques of organic chemistry to live organisms result in physiological chemistry, the precursor to biochemistry. The 20th century also saw the integration of physics and chemistry, with chemical properties explain as the result of the electronic structure of the atom. Linus Pauling's book on The Nature of the Chemical Bond use the principles of quantum mechanics to deduce bond angles in ever-more complicated molecules. Pauling's work culminate in the physical modelling of DNA, the secret of life( in the words of Francis Crick, 1953). In the same year, the Miller–Urey experiment demonstrate in a simulation of primordial processes, that basic constituents of proteins, simple amino acids, could themselves be build up from simpler molecules.

In 1460 Pedro de Sintra reached Sierra Leone. Prince Henry died in November that year after which, given the meager revenues, exploration was granted to Lisbon merchant Fernão Gomes in 1469, who in exchange for the monopoly of trade in the Gulf of Guinea had to explore 100 miles (161 kilometres) each year for five years.[55] With his sponsorship, explorers João de Santarém, Pedro Escobar, Lopo Gonçalves, Fernão do Pó, and Pedro de Sintra made it even beyond those goals. They reached the Southern Hemisphere and the islands of the Gulf of Guinea, including São Tomé and Príncipe and Elmina on the Gold Coast in 1471. (In the Southern Hemisphere, they used the Southern Cross as the reference for celestial navigation.) There, in what came to be called the "Gold Coast" in what is today Ghana, a thriving alluvial gold trade was found among the natives and Arab and Berber traders.

In 1513, about 40 miles (64 kilometres) south of Acandí, in present-day Colombia, Spanish Vasco Núñez de Balboa heard unexpected news of an "other sea" rich in gold, which he received with great interest.[92] With few resources and using information given by caciques, he journeyed across the Isthmus of Panama with 190 Spaniards, a few native guides, and a pack of dogs.

In the USA during the period between World War I and World War II painters tended to go to Europe for recognition. Artists like Marsden Hartley, Patrick Henry Bruce, Gerald Murphy and Stuart Davis, created reputations abroad. In New York City, Albert Pinkham Ryder and Ralph Blakelock were influential and important figures in advanced American painting between 1900 and 1920. During the 1920s photographer Alfred Stieglitz exhibited Georgia O'Keeffe, Arthur Dove, Alfred Henry Maurer, Charles Demuth, John Marin and other artists including European Masters Henri Matisse, Auguste Rodin, Henri Rousseau, Paul Cézanne, and Pablo Picasso, at his gallery the 291.

John Napier introduced logarithms as a powerful mathematical tool. With the help of the prominent mathematician Henry Briggs their logarithmic tables embodied a computational advance that made calculations by hand much quicker.[97] His Napier's bones used a set of numbered rods as a multiplication tool using the system of lattice multiplication. The way was opened to later scientific advances, particularly in astronomy and dynamics.

For a long time it be think that the Amazon rainforest be only ever sparsely populated, as it be impossible to sustain a large population through agriculture give the poor soil. Archaeologist Betty Meggers be a prominent proponent of this idea, as describe in her book Amazonia: Man and Culture in a Counterfeit Paradise. She claim that a population density of 0.2 inhabitants per square kilometre( 0.52/sq mi) be the maximum that can be sustain in the rainforest through hunting, with agriculture need to support a larger population.[ 12] However, recent archaeological findings have suggest that the region be actually densely populated. From the 1970s, numerous geoglyphs have be discover on deforested land date between 0–1250 CE, lead to claims about Pre-Columbian civilisations.[ 13] The BBC's Unnatural Histories claim that the Amazon rainforest, rather than be a pristine wilderness, have be shape by man for at least 11,000 years through practices such as forest gardening.[ 14] Recent anthropological findings have suggest that the region be actually densely populate. Some 5 million people may have live in the Amazon region in 1500 CE, divide between dense coastal settlements, such as that at Marajó, and inland dwellers.[ 15]

Enver Bey's alliance with Germany, which he saw as the most advanced military power in Europe, was enabled by the British demands that the Ottoman Empire cede their formal capital Edirne (Adrianople) to the Bulgarians after losing the First Balkan War, which the Turks saw as a betrayal by Britain.[17] These demands cost Britain the support of the Turks, as the pro-British Freedom and Accord Party was now repressed under the pro-German Committee for, in Enver's words, "shamefully delivering the country to the enemy [Britain]" after agreeing to the demands to give up Edirne.[18]

During the 1160s, Fatimid Egypt came under threat from European crusaders. Out of this threat, a Kurdish general named Ṣalāḥ ad-Dīn Yūsuf ibn Ayyūb (Saladin), with a small band of professional soldiers, emerged as an outstanding Muslim defender. Saladin defeated the Christian crusaders at Egypt's borders and recaptured Jerusalem in 1187. On the death of Al-Adid, the last Fatimid caliph, in 1171, Saladin became the ruler of Egypt, ushering in the Ayyubid Dynasty. Under his rule, Egypt returned to Sunni Islam, Cairo became an important center of Arab Islamic learning, and Mamluk slaves were increasingly recruited from Turkey and southern Russia for military service. Support for the military was tied to the iqta, a form of land taxation in which soldiers were given ownership in return for military service.[116]

There be a tendency in late eighteenth century Enlightenment think to understand human society as natural phenomena that behave accord to certain principles and that could be observe empirically. In some ways, study the language, culture, physiology, and artifacts of European colonies be not unlike study the flora and fauna of those places.
Cahokia was a major regional chiefdom, with trade and tributary chiefdoms located in a range of areas from bordering the Great Lakes to the Gulf of Mexico.

In 1497, newly crown King Manuel I of Portugal send an exploratory fleet eastwards, fulfil his predecessor's project of find a route to the Indies. In July 1499 news spread that the Portuguese have reach the `` true indies'', as a letter be dispatch by the Portuguese king to the Spanish Catholic Monarchs one day after the celebrated return of the fleet.[ 68]

The Society's first Secretary be Henry Oldenburg. Its early meetings include experiments perform first by Robert Hooke and then by Denis Papin, who be appoint in 1684. These experiments vary in their subject area, and be both important in some cases and trivial in others.[ 64] The society begin publication of Philosophical Transactions from 1665, the oldest and longest-running scientific journal in the world, which establish the important principles of scientific priority and peer review.[ 65]
Chanakya (born 350 BC) wrote the Arthashastra, a treatise on statecraft, economic policy and military strategy.[citation needed]
Other important topics include the histories of families,[ 435] demography,[ 436] education,[ 437] and childhood.[ 438][ 439][ 440]

The cities of this era be characterize by their multi-ethnic composition, which entail the cohabitation in the same population centers of people with different languages, cultural practices, and places of origin. During this period the alliances between the regional political elites be strengthen, especially for those ally with Teotihuacan. Also, social differentiation become more pronounced: a small dominant group rule over the majority of the population. This majority be force to pay tribute and to participate in the building of public structures such as irrigation systems, religious edifices, and means of communication. The growth of the cities could not have happen without advances in agricultural methods and the strengthening of trade networks involve not only the peoples of Mesoamerica, but also the distant cultures of Oasisamerica.

The architecture of Indonesia reflect both the cultural diversity of the region and its rich historical inheritance. The geographic position of Indonesia mean a transition between the culture of Asian Hindu-Buddhism architecture and animistic architecture of Oceania. Indonesian wide range of vernacular styles be the legacy of an Austronesian architectural tradition characterize by wooden pile dwellings, high pitch roofs and extend roof ridges. The temples of Java, on the other hand, share an Indian Hindu-Buddhist ancestry, typical of Southeast Asia; though indigenous influences have lead to the creation of a distinctly Indonesian style of monumental architecture. Gradual spread of Islam through the region from the 12th century onwards create an Islamic architecture which betray a mixture of local and exotic elements. Arrival of the European merchant, especially the Dutch, show incorporation of many Indonesian features into the architecture of the native Netherlands to produce an eclectic synthesis of Eastern and Western forms apparent in the early 18th-century Indies Style and modern New Indies Style. The years that follow independence saw the adoption of Modernist agenda on the part of Indonesian architects apparent in the architecture of the 1970s and 1980s.

The beginning of write materials( and so the beginning of local `` historic times'') varies; in many cultures, especially outside Eurasia, it follow conquest by a culture with writing, and often the earliest write sources on pre-literate cultures come from their literate neighbours. The period when a culture be write about by others, but have not develop its own writing be often know as the protohistory of the culture.

These “researches” have been considered anthropological since at least as early as the late 19th century. The title, “Father of History,” (pater historiae) had been conferred on him probably by Cicero.[23] Pointing out that John Myres in 1908 had believed that Herodotus was an anthropologist on a par with those of his own day, James M. Redfield asserts: “Herodotus, as we know, was both Father of History and Father of Anthropology.”[24] Herodotus calls his method of travelling around taking notes “theorizing.” Redfield translates it as “tourism” with a scientific intent. He identifies three terms of Herodotus as overlapping on culture: diaitia, material goods such as houses and consumables; ethea, the mores or customs; and nomoi, the authoritative precedents or laws.

The Antebellum Age be a period of increase division in the country base on the growth of slavery in the American South and in the western territories of Kansas and Nebraska that eventually lead to the Civil War in 1861. The Antebellum Period be often consider to have begin with the Kansas–Nebraska Act of 1854,[ citation need] although it may have begin as early as 1812. This period be also significant because it mark the transition of American manufacturing to the industrial revolution.[ citation need]

In Politics Book 1:9[ 1]( c.350 B.C.) the Greek philosopher Aristotle contemplate on the nature of money. He consider that every object have two uses, the first be the original purpose for which the object be design, and the second possibility be to conceive of the object as an item to sell or barter.[ 2] The assignment of monetary value to an otherwise insignificant object such as a coin or promissory note arise as people and their trading associate evolve a psychological capacity to place trust in each other and in external authority within barter exchange.[ 3][ 4]

Classical studies( Classics for short) – earliest branch of the humanities, which cover the languages, literature, history, art, and other cultural aspects of the ancient Mediterranean world. The field focus primarily on, but be not limit to, Ancient Greece and Ancient Rome during classical antiquity, the era spanning from the late Bronze Age of Ancient Greece during the Minoan and Mycenaean periods( c. 1600-1100 BCE) through the period know as Late Antiquity to the fall of the Western Roman Empire, c. 500 CE. The word classics be also use to refer to the literature of the period.

The first European to travel the length of the Amazon River was Francisco de Orellana in 1542.[35] The BBC documentary Unnatural Histories presents evidence that Francisco de Orellana, rather than exaggerating his claims as previously thought, was correct in his observations that an advanced civilization was flourishing along the Amazon in the 1540s. It is believed that the civilization was later devastated by the spread of infectious diseases from Europe, such as smallpox, to which the natives had no immunity.[34] Some 5 million people may have lived in the Amazon region in 1500, divided between dense coastal settlements, such as that at Marajó, and inland dwellers.[15] By 1900 the population had fallen to 1 million, and by the early 1980s, it was less than 200,000.[15]

Marie Boas Hall coin the term Scientific Renaissance to designate the early phase of the Scientific Revolution, 1450–1630. More recently, Peter Dear have argue for a two-phase model of early modern science: a Scientific Renaissance of the 15th and 16th centuries, focus on the restoration of the natural knowledge of the ancients; and a Scientific Revolution of the 17th century, when scientists shift from recovery to innovation.

The Americas be think to have be first inhabit by people from eastern Asia who cross the Bering Land Bridge to present-day Alaska; the land separate and the continents be divide by the Bering Strait. Over the course of millennia, three waves of migrants spread to all parts of the Americas.[ citation need] Genetic and linguistic evidence have show that the last wave of migrant peoples settle across the northern tier, and do not reach South America.

In 1764 in the village of Stanhill, Lancashire, James Hargreaves invent the spinning jenny, which he patent in 1770. It be the first practical spinning frame with multiple spindles.[ 31] The jenny work in a similar manner to the spin wheel, by first clamp down on the fibres, then by draw them out, follow by twist.[ 32] It be a simple, wooden frame machine that only cost about £6 for a 40-spindle model in 1792,[ 33] and be use mainly by home spinners. The jenny produce a lightly twist yarn only suitable for weft, not warp.[ 30] :825–27

Amrita Sher-Gil be an Indian painter, sometimes know as India's Frida Kahlo,[ 25] and today consider an important woman painter of 20th-century India, whose legacy stand at par with that of the Masters of Bengal Renaissance;[ 26][ 27] she be also the'most expensive' woman painter of India.[ 28]

Abel Tasman's voyage of 1642 be the first know European expedition to reach Van Diemen's Land( later Tasmania) and New Zealand, and to sight Fiji. On his second voyage of 1644, he also contribute significantly to the mapping of Australia proper, make observations on the land and people of the north coast below New Guinea.[ 86]

Agnes Martin, Robert Mangold (see above), Brice Marden, Jo Baer, Robert Ryman, Richard Tuttle, Neil Williams, David Novros, Paul Mogenson, Charles Hinman are examples of artists associated with Minimalism and (exceptions of Martin, Baer and Marden) the use of the shaped canvas also during the period beginning in the early 1960s. Many Geometric abstract artists, minimalists, and hard-edge painters elected to use the edges of the image to define the shape of the painting rather than accepting the rectangular format. In fact, the use of the shaped canvas is primarily associated with paintings of the 1960s and 1970s that are coolly abstract, formalistic, geometrical, objective, rationalistic, clean-lined, brashly sharp-edged, or minimalist in character. The Bykert Gallery, and the Park Place Gallery were important showcases for Minimalism and shaped canvas painting in New York City during the 1960s.
As early as 9000 BCE both grain and cattle be use as money or as barter( Davies)( the first grain remain find, consider to be evidence of pre-agricultural practice date to 17,000 BCE).[ 15][ 16][ 17]

Ancient Egypt was a long-lived civilization geographically located in north-eastern Africa. It was concentrated along the middle to lower reaches of the Nile River reaching its greatest extension during the 2nd millennium BC, which is referred to as the New Kingdom period. It reached broadly from the Nile Delta in the north, as far south as Jebel Barkal at the Fourth Cataract of the Nile. Extensions to the geographical range of ancient Egyptian civilization included, at different times, areas of the southern Levant, the Eastern Desert and the Red Sea coastline, the Sinai Peninsula and the Western Desert (focused on the several oases).

The 10th millennium BC be the earliest give date for the invention of agriculture and the beginning of the ancient era. Göbekli Tepe be erect by hunter-gatherers in the 10th millennium BC( c. 11,500 years ago), before the advent of sedentism. Together with Nevalı Çori, it have revolutionize understanding of the Eurasian Neolithic. In the 7th millennium BC, Jiahu culture begin in China. By the 5th millennium BC, the late Neolithic civilizations saw the invention of the wheel and the spread of proto-writing. In the 4th millennium BC, the Cucuteni-Trypillian culture in the Ukraine-Moldova-Romania region develops. By 3400 BC, `` proto-literate'' cuneiform be spread in the Middle East.[ 33] The 30th century BC, refer to as the Early Bronze Age II, saw the beginning of the literate period in Mesopotamia and Ancient Egypt. Around the 27th century BC, the Old Kingdom of Egypt and the First Dynasty of Uruk be found, accord to the earliest reliable regnal eras.

The study of mathematics as a demonstrative discipline begins in the 6th century BC with the Pythagoreans, who coined the term "mathematics" from the ancient Greek μάθημα (mathema), meaning "subject of instruction".[4] Greek mathematics greatly refined the methods (especially through the introduction of deductive reasoning and mathematical rigor in proofs) and expanded the subject matter of mathematics.[5] Chinese mathematics made early contributions, including a place value system.[6][7] The Hindu–Arabic numeral system and the rules for the use of its operations, in use throughout the world today, likely evolved over the course of the first millennium AD in India and were transmitted to the west via Islamic mathematics through the work of Muḥammad ibn Mūsā al-Khwārizmī.[8][9] Islamic mathematics, in turn, developed and expanded the mathematics known to these civilizations.[10] Many Greek and Arabic texts on mathematics were then translated into Latin, which led to further development of mathematics in medieval Europe.

When the Central Junta fell to the French, numerous new Juntas appear all across the Americas, eventually result in a chain of newly independent countries stretch from Argentina and Chile in the south, to Mexico in the north. After the death of the king Ferdinand VII, in 1833, only Cuba and Puerto Rico remain under Spanish rule, until the Spanish–American War in 1898. Unlike the Spanish, the Portuguese do not divide their colonial territory in America. The captaincies they create be subdue to a centralized administration in Salvador( later relocate to Rio de Janeiro) which report directly to the Portuguese Crown until its independence in 1822, become the Empire of Brazil.

All dates are approximate and conjectural, obtained through research in the fields of anthropology, archaeology, genetics, geology, or linguistics. They are all subject to revision due to new discoveries or improved calculations. BP stands for "Before Present (1950)." BCE stands for Before Common Era".

The Ancient Near East be consider the cradle of civilization. It be the first to practice intensive year-round agriculture; create the first coherent write system, invent the potter's wheel and then the vehicular- and mill wheel, create the first centralized governments, law codes and empires, as well as introduce social stratification, slavery and organize warfare, and it lay the foundation for the fields of astronomy and mathematics.

Ancient history be the aggregate of past events[ 1] from the beginning of recorded human history and extending as far as the Early Middle Ages or the Postclassical Era. The span of recorded history be roughly 5,000 years, begin with Sumerian Cuneiform script, the oldest discovered form of coherent write from the protoliterate period around the 30th century BC.[ 2]

The growth of modern industry since the late 18th century lead to massive urbanisation and the rise of new great cities, first in Europe and then in other regions, as new opportunities bring huge numbers of migrants from rural communities into urban areas. In 1800, only 3% of the world's population live in cities,[ 116] compare to nearly 50% today( the beginning of the 21st century).[ 117] Manchester have a population of 10,000 in 1717, but by 1911 it have burgeon to 2.3 million.[ 118]

The account leave room for doubt regard the nature and extent of Aristotle's empiricism. In particular, it seem that Aristotle consider sense-perception only as a vehicle for knowledge through intuition. He restrict his investigations in natural history to their natural settings,[ 18] such as at the Pyrrha lagoon,[ 19] now call Kalloni, at Lesbos. Aristotle and Theophrastus together formulate the new science of biology,[ 20] inductively, case by case, for two years before Aristotle be call to tutor Alexander. Aristotle perform no modern-style experiments in the form in which they appear in today's physics and chemistry laboratories.[ 21] Induction be not afford the status of scientific reasoning, and so it be leave to intuition to provide a solid foundation for Aristotle’s science. With that say, Aristotle bring us somewhat closer an empirical science than his predecessors.

Several thousand years after the first migrations, the first complex civilizations arise as hunter-gatherers settle into semi-agricultural communities. Identifiable sedentary settlements begin to emerge in the so-called Middle Archaic period around 6000 BCE. Particular archaeological cultures can be identify and easily classify throughout the Archaic period.

At Oxford University, Edmund Gunter built the first analog device to aid computation. The 'Gunter's scale' was a large plane scale, engraved with various scales, or lines. Natural lines, such as the line of chords, the line of sines and tangents are placed on one side of the scale and the corresponding artificial or logarithmic ones were on the other side. This calculating aid was a predecessor of the slide rule. It was William Oughtred (1575–1660) who first used two such scales sliding by one another to perform direct multiplication and division, and thus is credited as the inventor of the slide rule in 1622.

Science in the Roman Empire period was concerned with systematizing knowledge gained in the preceding Hellenistic period and the knowledge from the vast areas the Romans had conquered. It was largely their work that would be passed on to later civilizations. Of especial importance is the Naturalis Historia of Pliny the Elder published in 77 AD, one of the most extensive compilations of the natural world that survived the Dark Ages.

By the mid-19th century, the Ottoman Empire have decline enough to become a target for other global powers( see History of the Balkans). This instigate the Crimean War in 1854 and begin a tenser period of minor clashes among the globe-spanning empires of Europe that eventually set the stage for the First World War. In the second half of the 19th century, the Kingdom of Sardinia and the Kingdom of Prussia carry out a series of wars that result in the creation of Italy and Germany as nation-states, significantly change the balance of power in Europe. From 1870, Otto von Bismarck engineer a German hegemony of Europe that put France in a critical situation. It slowly rebuild its relationships, seek alliances with Russia and Britain to control the grow power of Germany. In this way, two oppose sides—the Triple Alliance of 1882( Germany, Austria-Hungary and Italy) and the Triple Entente of 1907( Britain, France and Russia) —formed in Europe, improve their military forces and alliances year-by-year.

Aristotle's emphasis upon causes fundamentally shaped the later development of science by insisting that scientific knowledge, what the Greeks called episteme and the Romans scientia, is knowledge of necessary causes. He and his followers would not accept mere description or prediction as science. In view of this disagreement with Plato, Aristotle established his own school, the Lyceum, which further developed and transmitted his approach to the investigation of nature.

Johann Friedrich Herbart( 1776–1841) take issue with what he view as Kant's conclusion and attempt to develop a mathematical basis for a scientific psychology. Although he be unable to empirically realize the terms of his psychological theory, his efforts do lead scientists such as Ernst Heinrich Weber( 1795–18 78) and Gustav Theodor Fechner( 1801–1887) to attempt to measure the mathematical relationships between the physical magnitudes of external stimuli and the psychological intensities of the resulting sensations. Fechner( 1860) be the originator of the term psychophysics.

The Dutch, follow shipping routes to the Dutch East Indies, or in search of gold, spices or Christian converts proceed to contribute a great deal to Europe's knowledge of Australia's coast.[ 83] In 1616, Dirk Hartog, sail off course, en route from the Cape of Good Hope to Batavia, land on an island off Shark Bay, West Australia.[ 83] In 1622–23 the Leeuwin make the first record rounding of the south west corner of the continent, and give her name to Cape Leeuwin.[ 84]

In 1951 English economist James E. Meade (1907–1995) published The Balance of Payments, volume 1 of "The Theory of International Economic Policy", which proposed the theory of domestic divergence (internal and external balance), and promoted policy tools for governments. In 1955 he published volume 2 Trade and Welfare, which proposed the theory of the "second-best", and promoted protectionism. He shared the 1977 Nobel Economic Prize with Bertil Ohlin.

Contemporary philosophy is the present period in the history of Western philosophy beginning at the end of the 19th century with the professionalization of the discipline and the rise of analytic and continental philosophy.
`` What Style Shall We Build In?''- Heinrich Huebsch.

The Bantu expansion was a critical movement of people in African history and the settling of the continent. People speaking Bantu languages (a branch of the Niger–Congo family) began in the second millennium BCE to spread from Cameroon eastward to the Great Lakes region. In the first millennium BCE, Bantu languages spread from the Great Lakes to southern and east Africa. An early expansion was south to the upper Zambezi valley in the 2nd century BCE. Then, Bantu speakers pushed westward to the savannahs of present-day Angola and eastward into Malawi, Zambia, and Zimbabwe in the 1st century CE. The second thrust from the Great Lakes was eastward, 2,000 years ago, expanding to the Indian Ocean coast, Kenya and Tanzania. The eastern group eventually met the southern migrants from the Great Lakes in Malawi, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. Both groups continued southward, with eastern groups continuing to Mozambique and reaching Maputo in the 2nd century CE, and expanding as far as Durban. By the later first millennium CE, the expansion had reached the Great Ke River of South Africa. Sorghum, a major Bantu crop, could not thrive under the winter rainfall of Namibia and the western Cape. Khoisan people inhabited the remaining parts of southern Africa.[61]

It be not until after 9500 BC that the eight so-called founder crops of agriculture appear: first emmer and einkorn wheat, then hull barley, peas, lentils, bitter vetch, chick peas and flax. These eight crops occur more or less simultaneously on Pre-Pottery Neolithic B( PPNB) sit in the Levant, although wheat be the first to be grow and harvest on a significant scale. At around the same time( 9400 BC), parthenocarpic fig trees be domesticate.[ 17][ 18]
Among the most notable developments to pseudoscience in the 20th century are the rise of Creationism, the demise of Spiritualism, and the first formulation of ancient astronaut theories.

Athens fell under a tyranny in the second half of the 6th century. When this tyranny was ended, the Athenians founded the world's first democracy as a radical solution to prevent the aristocracy regaining power. A citizens' assembly (the Ecclesia), for the discussion of city policy, had existed since the reforms of Draco in 621 BC; all citizens were permitted to attend after the reforms of Solon (early 6th century), but the poorest citizens could not address the assembly or run for office. With the establishment of the democracy, the assembly became the de jure mechanism of government; all citizens had equal privileges in the assembly. However, non-citizens, such as metics (foreigners living in Athens) or slaves, had no political rights at all.

During the second World War, Leonard Bloomfield, William Mandeville Austin[ 15] and several of his students and colleagues develop teach materials for a variety of languages whose knowledge be need for the war effort. This work lead to an increase prominence of the field of linguistics, which become a recognize discipline in most American universities only after the war.

The important legacy of this period include substantial advances in factual knowledge, especially in anatomy, zoology, botany, mineralogy, geography, mathematics and astronomy; an awareness of the importance of certain scientific problems, especially those relate to the problem of change and its causes; and a recognition of the methodological importance of apply mathematics to natural phenomena and of undertake empirical research.[ 14] In the Hellenistic age scholars frequently employ the principles develop in earlier Greek thought: the application of mathematics and deliberate empirical research, in their scientific investigations.[ 15] Thus, clear unbroken lines of influence lead from ancient Greek and Hellenistic philosophers, to medieval Muslim philosophers and scientists, to the European Renaissance and Enlightenment, to the secular sciences of the modern day. Neither reason nor inquiry begin with the Ancient Greeks, but the Socratic method do, along with the idea of Forms, great advances in geometry, logic, and the natural sciences.
