Hot blast, patent by James Beaumont Neilson in 1828, be the most important development of the 19th century for save energy in make pig iron. By use waste exhaust heat to preheat combustion air, the amount of fuel to make a unit of pig iron be reduce at first by between one-third use coal or two-thirds use coke;[ 39] however, the efficiency gains continue as the technology improve.[ 40] Hot blast also raise the operating temperature of furnaces, increase their capacity. Using less coal or coke mean introduce fewer impurities into the pig iron. This meant that lower quality coal or anthracite could be use in areas where coke coal be unavailable or too expensive;[ 41] however, by the end of the 19th century transportation costs fell considerably.

The European Revolutions of 1848, known in some countries as the Spring of Nations or the Year of Revolution, were a series of political upheavals throughout the European continent. Described as a revolutionary wave, the period of unrest began in France and then, further propelled by the French Revolution of 1848, soon spread to the rest of Europe.[60][61] Although most of the revolutions were quickly put down, there was a significant amount of violence in many areas, with tens of thousands of people tortured and killed. While the immediate political effects of the revolutions were reversed, the long-term reverberations of the events were far-reaching.

Indian Ocean trade routes were sailed by Arab traders. Between 1405 and 1421, the Yongle Emperor of Ming China sponsored a series of long range tributary missions under the command of Zheng He (Cheng Ho).[13] The fleets visited Arabia, East Africa, India, Maritime Southeast Asia and Thailand. But the journeys, reported by Ma Huan, a Muslim voyager and translator, were halted abruptly after the emperor's death[14] and were not followed up, as the Chinese Ming Dynasty retreated in the haijin, a policy of isolationism, having limited maritime trade.

In 1885 the American Economic Association (AEA) was founded by Richard T. Ely (1854–1943) et al., publishing the American Economic Review starting in 1911. In 1918 Ely published Private Colonization of Land, founding Lambda Alpha International in 1930 to promote Land Economics.[40]

American mathematical physicist J. Willard Gibbs's work on the applications of thermodynamics be instrumental in transform physical chemistry into a rigorous deductive science. During the years from 1876 to 1878, Gibbs work on the principles of thermodynamics, apply them to the complex processes involve in chemical reactions. He discover the concept of chemical potential, or the `` fuel'' that make chemical reactions work. In 1876 he publish his most famous contribution, `` On the Equilibrium of Heterogeneous Substances'', a compilation of his work on thermodynamics and physical chemistry which lay out the concept of free energy to explain the physical basis of chemical equilibria.[ 80] In these essays be the beginnings of Gibbs’ theories of phases of matter: he consider each state of matter a phase, and each substance a component. Gibbs take all of the variables involve in a chemical reaction- temperature, pressure, energy, volume, and entropy- and include them in one simple equation know as Gibbs' phase rule.

By the 15th century, writers, artists, and architects in Italy were well aware of the transformations that were taking place and were using phrases such as modi antichi (in the antique manner) or alle romana et alla antica (in the manner of the Romans and the ancients) to describe their work. In the 1330s Petrarch referred to pre-Christian times as antiqua (ancient) and to the Christian period as nova (new).[69] From Petrarch's Italian perspective, this new period (which included his own time) was an age of national eclipse.[69] Leonardo Bruni was the first to use tripartite periodization in his History of the Florentine People (1442).[70] Bruni's first two periods were based on those of Petrarch, but he added a third period because he believed that Italy was no longer in a state of decline. Flavio Biondo used a similar framework in Decades of History from the Deterioration of the Roman Empire (1439–1453).

In the late 10th century, a huge observatory be build near Tehran, Iran, by the astronomer Abu-Mahmud al-Khujandi who observe a series of meridian transits of the Sun, which allow him to calculate the tilt of the Earth's axis relative to the Sun. He note that measurements by earlier( Indian, then Greek) astronomers have find higher values for this angle, possible evidence that the axial tilt be not constant but be in fact decreasing.[ 43][ 44] In 11th-century Persia, Omar Khayyám compile many tables and perform a reformation of the calendar that be more accurate than the Julian and come close to the Gregorian.

In the 19th century, Thomas Johann Seebeck invent the thermocouple, Joseph Aspin invents Portland cement, Hans Christian Ørsted produce metallic aluminium, Charles Goodyear invents vulcanize rubber, Louis Daguerre and William Fox Talbot invent silver-based photographic processes, James Clerk Maxwell demonstrate color photography, and Charles Fritts make the first solar cells use selenium waffles.

This be a common scenario in wars from time immemorial, and conditions face by the Confederate army be even worse. The Union respond by build army hospitals in every state. Mexico experience an era of huge economic growth after World War II, a heavy industrialization process and a growth of its middle class, a period know in Mexican history as the `` El Milagro Mexicano''( Mexican miracle).

German theoretical physicist Werner Heisenberg be one of the key creators of quantum mechanics. In 1925, Heisenberg discover a way to formulate quantum mechanics in terms of matrices. For that discovery, he be award the Nobel Prize for Physics for 1932. In 1927 he publish his uncertainty principle, upon which he build his philosophy and for which he be best know. Heisenberg be able to demonstrate that if you be study an electron in an atom you could say where it be( the electron's location) or where it be go( the electron's velocity), but it be impossible to express both at the same time. He also make important contributions to the theories of the hydrodynamics of turbulent flows, the atomic nucleus, ferromagnetism, cosmic rays, and subatomic particles, and he be instrumental in plan the first West German nuclear reactor at Karlsruhe, together with a research reactor in Munich, in 1957. Considerable controversy surround his work on atomic research during World War II.

These physicians and natural philosophers be influence by the `` new science'', as promote by Francis Bacon in his New Atlantis, from approximately 1645 onwards. A group know as The Philosophical Society of Oxford be run under a set of rules still retain by the Bodleian Library.[ 62]

Functionalist systems theorists such as Niklas Luhmann remained dominant forces in sociology up to the end of the century. In 1994, Robert K. Merton won the National Medal of Science for his contributions to the sociology of science.[65] The positivist tradition is popular to this day, particularly in the United States.[66] The discipline's two most widely cited American journals, the American Journal of Sociology and the American Sociological Review, primarily publish research in the positivist tradition, with ASR exhibiting greater diversity (the British Journal of Sociology, on the other hand, publishes primarily non-positivist articles).[66] The twentieth century saw improvements to the quantitative methodologies employed in sociology. The development of longitudinal studies that follow the same population over the course of years or decades enabled researchers to study long-term phenomena and increased the researchers' ability to infer causality. The increase in the size of data sets produced by the new survey methods was followed by the invention of new statistical techniques for analyzing this data. Analysis of this sort is usually performed with statistical software packages such as SAS, Stata, or SPSS.

The Mongols of Genghis Khan be the Menggu sub-tribe of the Shiwei Xianbei. The first survive Mongolian text be the Stele of Yisüngge, a report on sports in Mongolian script on stone, that be most often date at the verge of 1224 and 1225.[ 179] Other early sources be write in Mongolian, Phagspa( decrets), Chinese( the Secret history), Arabic( dictionaries) and a few other western scripts.[ 180]

The term "Enlightenment" emerged in English in the later part of the 19th century,[96] with particular reference to French philosophy, as the equivalent of the French term 'Lumières' (used first by Dubos in 1733 and already well established by 1751). From Immanuel Kant's 1784 essay "Beantwortung der Frage: Was ist Aufklärung?" ("Answering the Question: What is Enlightenment?") the German term became 'Aufklärung' (aufklären = to illuminate; sich aufklären = to clear up). However, scholars have never agreed on a definition of the Enlightenment, or on its chronological or geographical extent. Terms like "les Lumières" (French), "illuminismo" (Italian), "ilustración" (Spanish) and "Aufklärung" (German) referred to partly overlapping movements. Not until the late nineteenth century did English scholars agree they were talking about "the Enlightenment."[95][97]

During its Golden Age, roughly from 1590 to 1681,[ 44] Spain saw a monumental increase in the production of live theatre as well as the in importance of theatre within Spanish society. It be an accessible art form for all participants in Renaissance Spain, be both highly sponsor by the aristocratic class and highly attend by the lower classes.[ 45] The volume and variety of Spanish plays during the Golden Age be unprecedented in the history of world theatre, surpassing, for example, the dramatic production of the English Renaissance by a factor of at least four.[ 44][ 45][ 46] Although this volume have be as much a source of criticism as praise for Spanish Golden Age theatre, for emphasize quantity before quality,[ 47] a large number of the 10,000[ 45] to 30,000[ 47] plays of this period be still consider masterpieces.[ 48][ 49]

Der Blaue Reiter lacked a central artistic manifesto, but was centered around Kandinsky and Marc. Artists Gabriele Münter and Paul Klee were also involved.

This period is not to be identified with "Old Stone Age", a translation of Paleolithic, or with Paleolithic, or with the "Earlier Stone Age" that originally meant what became the Paleolithic and Mesolithic. In the initial decades of its definition by the Pan-African Congress of Prehistory, it was parallel in Africa to the Upper and Middle Paleolithic. However, since then Radiocarbon dating has shown that the Middle Stone Age is in fact contemporaneous with the Middle Paleolithic.[60] The Early Stone Age therefore is contemporaneous with the Lower Paleolithic and happens to include the same main technologies, Oldowan and Acheulean, which produced Mode 1 and Mode 2 stone tools respectively. A distinct regional term is warranted, however, by the location and chronology of the sites and the exact typology.

Renaissance painting reflect the revolution of ideas and science( astronomy, geography) that occur in this period, the Reformation, and the invention of the printing press. Dürer, consider one of the greatest of printmakers, states that painters be not mere artisans but thinkers as well. With the development of easel painting in the Renaissance, painting gain independence from architecture. Following centuries dominate by religious imagery, secular subject matter slowly return to Western painting. Artists include visions of the world around them, or the products of their own imaginations in their paintings. Those who could afford the expense could become patrons and commission portraits of themselves or their family.

The Maravi claimed descent from Karonga (kalonga), who took that title as king. The Maravi connected Central Africa to the east coastal trade, with Swahili Kilwa. By the 17th century, the Maravi Empire encompassed all the area between Lake Malawi and the mouth of the Zambezi River. The karonga was Mzura, who did much to extend the empire. Mzura made a pact with the Portuguese to establish a 4,000-man army to attack the Shona in return for aid in defeating his rival Lundi, a chief of the Zimba. In 1623, he turned on the Portuguese and assisted the Shona. In 1640, he welcome back the Portuguese for trade. The Maravi Empire did not long survive the death of Mzura. By the 18th century, it had broken into its previous polities.[165]

The 17th and early 20th centuries roughly mark the beginning and the end of modern philosophy. How much if any of the Renaissance should be include be a matter for dispute; likewise modernity may or may not have end in the twentieth century and be replace by postmodernity. How one decide these questions will determine the scope of one's use of `` modern philosophy.''

The depression have devastating effects in virtually every country, rich or poor. International trade plunge by half to two-thirds, as do personal income, tax revenue, prices and profits. Cities all around the world be hit hard, especially those dependent on heavy industry. Construction be virtually halt in many countries. Farming and rural areas suffer as crop prices fell by roughly 60 percent.[ 108][ 109][ 110] Facing plummet demand with few alternate sources of jobs, areas dependent on primary sector industries suffer the most.

The history of education in Japan dates back at least to the 6th century, when Chinese learning was introduced at the Yamato court. Foreign civilizations have often provided new ideas for the development of Japan's own culture.

The most significant event between the 7th and 11th century was the Tripartite struggle centred on Kannauj that lasted for more than two centuries between the Pala Empire, Rashtrakuta Empire, and Gurjara Pratihara Empire. Southern India saw the rise of multiple imperial powers from the middle of the fifth century, most notable being the Chalukya, Chola, Pallava, Chera, Pandyan, and Western Chalukya Empires. Emmy Noether has been described by many as the most important woman in the history of mathematics.[143] She studied the theories of rings, fields, and algebras.

On lose the 1883 rivalry in Alexandria, Pasteur switch research direction, and introduce his third vaccine—rabies vaccine—the first vaccine for humans since Jenner's for smallpox.[ 94] From across the globe, donations pour in, fund the founding of Pasteur Institute, the globe's first biomedical institute, which open in 1888.[ 94] Along with Koch's bacteriologists, Pasteur's group—which prefer the term microbiology—led medicine into the new era of `` scientific medicine'' upon bacteriology and germ theory.[ 94] Accepted from Jakob Henle, Koch's steps to confirm a species' pathogenicity become famed as `` Koch's postulates''. Although his propose tuberculosis treatment, tuberculin, seemingly fail, it soon be use to test for infection with the involved species. In 1905, Koch be award the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, and remain renowned as the founder of medical microbiology.[ 96]

Stress play an important role in English. Certain syllables be stress, while others be unstressed. Stress be a combination of duration, intensity, vowel quality, and sometimes changes in pitch. Stressed syllables be pronounce longer and louder than unstressed syllables, and vowels in unstressed syllables be frequently reduce while vowels in stressed syllables be not.[ 147] Some words, primarily short function words but also some modal verbs such as can, have weak and strong forms depend on whether they occur in stressed or non-stressed position within a sentence.

In modern-day Germany, the Holy Roman Empire continue to rule, but the elective nature of the imperial crown meant there be no endure dynasty around which a strong state could form.[ 284] Further east, the kingdoms of Poland, Hungary, and Bohemia grow powerful.[ 285] In Iberia, the Christian kingdoms continue to gain land from the Muslim kingdoms of the peninsula;[ 286] Portugal concentrate on expand overseas during the 15th century, while the other kingdoms be rive by difficulties over royal succession and other concerns.[ 287][ 288] After lose the Hundred Years' War, England go on to suffer a long civil war know as the Wars of the Roses, which last into the 1490s[ 288] and only end when Henry Tudor( r. 1485–1509 as Henry VII) become king and consolidated power with his victory over Richard III( r. 1483–85) at Bosworth in 1485.[ 289] In Scandinavia, Margaret I of Denmark( r. in Denmark 1387–1412) consolidate Norway, Denmark, and Sweden in the Union of Kalmar, which continue until 1523. The major power around the Baltic Sea be the Hanseatic League, a commercial confederation of city states that trade from Western Europe to Russia.[ 290] Scotland emerge from English domination under Robert the Bruce( r. 1306–29), who secure papal recognition of his kingship in 1328.[ 291]

Among the last islands in Oceania to be colonise be Niue( 1900). The offer be not accept until 1900. Niue be a British protectorate, but the UK's direct involvement end in 1901 when New Zealand annex the island.

The history of metallurgy in the Indian subcontinent begin during the 2nd millennium BC. Archaeological sit in India, such as Malhar, Dadupur, Raja Nala Ka Tila and Lahuradewa in present-day Uttar Pradesh show iron implements in the period 1800 BC – 1200 BC.[ 7] Archaeological excavations in Hyderabad show an Iron Age burial site.[ 26] Rakesh Tewari[ 27] believe that around the beginning of the Indian Iron Age( 13th century BC), iron smelting be widely practice in India. Such use suggest that the date of the technology's inception may be around the 16th century BC.[ 7]

Egyptian mathematics refers to mathematics written in the Egyptian language. From the Hellenistic period, Greek replaced Egyptian as the written language of Egyptian scholars. Mathematical study in Egypt later continued under the Arab Empire as part of Islamic mathematics, when Arabic became the written language of Egyptian scholars.

The fleet sail further and further south, avoid the Portuguese territories in Brazil, and become the first to reach Tierra del Fuego at the tip of the Americas. On October 21, start in Cape Virgenes, they begin an arduous trip through a 373-mile( 600 km) long strait that Magellan name Estrecho de Todos los Santos, the modern Strait of Magellan. On November 28, three ships enter the Pacific Ocean—then name Mar Pacífico because of its apparent stillness.[ 97] The expedition manage to cross the Pacific. Magellan die in the battle of Mactan in the Philippines, leave the Spaniard Juan Sebastián Elcano the task of complete the voyage, reach the Spice Islands in 1521. On September 6, 1522 Victoria return to Spain, thus complete the first circumnavigation of the globe. Of the men who set out on five ships, only 18 complete the circumnavigation and manage to return to Spain in this single vessel lead by Elcano. Seventeen others arrive later in Spain: twelve capture by the Portuguese in Cape Verde some weeks earlier, and between 1525 and 1527, and five survivors of the Trinidad. Antonio Pigafetta, a Venetian scholar and traveler who have ask to be on board and become a strict assistant of Magellan, keep an accurate journal that become the main source for much of what we know about this voyage.

Roman civil engineering and military engineering constituted a large part of Rome's technological superiority and legacy, and contributed to the construction of hundreds of roads, bridges, aqueducts, baths, theaters and arenas. Many monuments, such as the Colosseum, Pont du Gard, and Pantheon, remain as testaments to Roman engineering and culture.

In 1515–1516, the Spanish fleet lead by Juan Díaz de Solís sail down the east coast of South America as far as Río de la Plata, which Solís name shortly before he die, while try to find a passage to the `` South Sea''.

Ibn Sina( Avicenna, 981-1037), a Persian polymath, make significant contributions to geology and the natural sciences( which he call Attabieyat) along with other natural philosophers such as Ikhwan AI-Safa and many others. Ibn Sina write an encyclopaedic work entitle “Kitab al-Shifa”( the Book of Cure, Healing or Remedy from ignorance), in which Part 2, Section 5, contain his commentary on Aristotle's Mineralogy and Meteorology, in six chapters: Formation of mountains, The advantages of mountains in the formation of clouds; Sources of water; Origin of earthquakes; Formation of minerals; The diversity of earth’s terrain.

The Hongwu emperor, perhaps for his sympathy of the common-folk, have build many irrigation systems and other public projects that provide help for the peasant farmers.[ 26] They be also allow to cultivate and claim unoccupied land without have to pay any taxes and labor demands be lower.[ 26] However, none of this be able to stop the rise landlord class that gain many privileges from the government and slowly gain control of the peasantry. Moneylenders foreclose on peasant debt in exchange for mortgages and buy up farmer land, force them to become the landlords' tenants or to wander elsewhere for work.[ 27] Also during this time, Neo-Confucianism intensify even more than the previous two dynasties( the Song and Yuan). Focus on the superiority of elders over youth, men over women, and teachers over students result in minor discrimination of the `` inferior'' classes. The fine arts grow in the Ming era, with improve techniques in brush painting that depict scenes of court, city or country life; people such as scholars or travelers; or the beauty of mountains, lakes, or marshes. The Maratha states, follow the Anglo-Maratha wars, eventually lose to the British East India Company in 1818 with the Third Anglo-Maratha War. The rule last until 1858, when, after the Indian rebellion of 1857 and consequent of the Government of India Act 1858, the British government assume the task of directly administer India in the new British Raj.[ 48] In 1819 Stamford Raffles establish Singapore as a key trading post for Britain in their rivalry with the Dutch. However, their rivalry cool in 1824 when an Anglo-Dutch treaty demarcate their respective interests in Southeast Asia. From the 1850s onwards, the pace of colonization shift to a significantly higher gear.

At its peak, in the 19th century, the empire extended from the Khyber Pass in the west, to Kashmir in the north, to Sindh in the south, running along Sutlej river to Himachal in the east. After the death of Ranjit Singh, the empire weakened, leading to the conflict with the British East India Company. The hard-fought first Anglo-Sikh war and second Anglo-Sikh war marked the downfall of the Sikh Empire; making it among the last areas of the Indian subcontinent to be conquered by the British.

The origins of distinctly Australian painting is often associated with this period and the Heidelberg School of the 1880s–1890s.[211] Artists such as Arthur Streeton, Frederick McCubbin and Tom Roberts applied themselves to recreating in their art a truer sense of light and colour as seen in Australian landscape. Like the European Impressionists, they painted in the open air. These artists found inspiration in the unique light and colour which characterises the Australian bush. Their most recognised work involves scenes of pastoral and wild Australia, featuring the vibrant, even harsh colours of Australian summers.[212]

On December 7, 1941, Japan attack the United States at Pearl Harbor, bring it too into the war on the Allied side. China also join the Allies, as eventually do most of the rest of the world. China be in turmoil at the time, and attack Japanese armies through guerilla-type warfare. In 1831 John Herschel( 1792–1871) publish A Preliminary Discourse on the study of Natural Philosophy, set out the principles of science. Measuring and compare observations be to be use to find generalisations in `` empirical laws'', which describe regularities in phenomena, then natural philosophers be to work towards the higher aim of find a universal `` law of nature'' which explain the causes and effects produce such regularities. An explanatory hypothesis be to be find by evaluate true causes( Newton's `` vera causae'') derive from experience, for example evidence of past climate change could be due to changes in the shape of continents, or to changes in Earth's orbit. Possible causes could be infer by analogy to known causes of similar phenomena.[ 83][ 84] It be essential to evaluate the importance of a hypothesis; `` our next step in the verification of an induction must therefore consist in extend its application to cases not originally contemplate; in studiously vary the circumstances under which our causes act, with a view to ascertain whether their effect be general; and in push the application of our laws to extreme cases. ``[ 85]

Evangelista Torricelli( 1607–1647) be best know for his invention of the mercury barometer. The motivation for the invention be to improve on the suction pumps that be use to raise water out of the mines. Torricelli construct a sealed tube fill with mercury, set vertically into a basin of the same substance. The column of mercury fell downwards, leave a Torricellian vacuum above.[ 118]

The first successful English settlements were at Jamestown (1607) (along with its satellite, Bermuda in 1609) and Plymouth (1620), in what are today Virginia and Massachusetts respectively. The first French settlements were Port Royal (1604) and Quebec City (1608) in what is now Nova Scotia and Quebec. English do not have a morphologised future tense.[ 178] Futurity of action be express periphrastically with one of the auxiliary verbs will or shall.[ 179] Many varieties also use a near future construct with the phrasal verb be go to.[ 180]

John Locke, one of the most influential Enlightenment thinkers,[44] based his governance philosophy in social contract theory, a subject that permeated Enlightenment political thought. The English philosopher Thomas Hobbes ushered in this new debate with his work Leviathan in 1651. Hobbes also developed some of the fundamentals of European liberal thought: the right of the individual; the natural equality of all men; the artificial character of the political order (which led to the later distinction between civil society and the state); the view that all legitimate political power must be "representative" and based on the consent of the people; and a liberal interpretation of law which leaves people free to do whatever the law does not explicitly forbid.[45]

The earliest civilization on the Indian subcontinent be the Indus Valley Civilization( mature phase: 2600 to 1900 BC) that flourish in the Indus river basin. Their cities be lay out with geometric regularity, but no known mathematical documents survive from this civilization.[ 88]

Global exploration start with the Portuguese discoveries of the Atlantic archipelagos of Madeira and the Azores, the coast of Africa, and the discovery of the sea route to India in 1498; and, on behalf of the Crown of Castile( Spain), the trans-Atlantic Voyages of Christopher Columbus between 1492 and 1502, and the first circumnavigation of the globe in 1519–1522. These discoveries lead to numerous naval expeditions across the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific oceans, and land expeditions in the Americas, Asia, Africa, and Australia that continue into the late 19th century, and end with the exploration of the polar regions in the 20th century.

Small sacral kingdoms continue to dot the Nubian portion of the Nile for centuries after 3000 BCE. Around the latter part of the third millennium, there be further consolidation of the sacral kingdoms. Two kingdoms in particular emerge: the Sai kingdom, immediately south of Egypt, and the Kingdom of Kerma at the third cataract. Sometime around the 18th century BCE, the Kingdom of Kerma conquer the Kingdom of Sai, become a serious rival to Egypt. Kerma occupy a territory from the first cataract to the confluences of the Blue Nile, White Nile, and Atbarah River. About 1575 to 1550 BCE, during the latter part of the Seventeenth Dynasty, the Kingdom of Kerma invade Egypt.[ 42] The Kingdom of Kerma ally itself with the Hyksos invasion of Egypt.[ 43]

In the late 1770s, popular debating societies began to move into more "genteel" rooms, a change which helped establish a new standard of sociability.[202] The backdrop to these developments was "an explosion of interest in the theory and practice of public elocution". The debating societies were commercial enterprises that responded to this demand, sometimes very successfully. Some societies welcomed from 800 to 1200 spectators a night.[203]

Coffeehouses be especially important to the spread of knowledge during the Enlightenment because they create a unique environment in which people from many different walks of life gather and share ideas. They be frequently criticize by nobles who fear the possibility of an environment in which class and its accompanying titles and privileges be disregard. Such an environment be especially intimidate to monarchs who derive much of their power from the disparity between classes of people. If classes be to join together under the influence of Enlightenment think, they might recognize the all-encompassing oppression and abuses of their monarchs and, because of their size, might be able to carry out successful revolts. Monarchs also resent the idea of their subjects convene as one to discuss political matters, especially those concern foreign affairs- rulers think political affairs to be their business only, a result of their suppose divine right to rule.[ 195]

Whereas Diocletian severely persecuted Christianity, Constantine declared an official end to state-sponsored persecution of Christians in 313 with the Edict of Milan, thus setting the stage for the Church to become the state church of the Roman Empire in about 380.

Chronic hunger and malnutrition be the norm for the majority of the population of the world include Britain and France, until the late 19th century. During this period, the Eastern world empires continued to expand through trade, migration and conquests of neighboring areas. Gunpowder was widely used as early as the 11th century and they were using moveable type printing five hundred years before Gutenberg created his press. Buddhism, Taoism, Confucianism were the dominant philosophies of the Far East during the Middle Ages. Marco Polo was not the first Westerner to travel to the Orient and return with amazing stories of this different culture, but his accounts published in the late 13th and early 14th centuries were the first to be widely read throughout Europe.

The Hindu Renaissance refers to a social reform movement during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries in the Bengal region of British India during the period of British rule dominated by English educated Bengali Hindus. The Bengal Renaissance can be said to have started with Raja Ram Mohan Roy (1772–1833) and ended with Rabindranath Tagore (1861–1941), although many stalwarts thereafter continued to embody particular aspects of the unique intellectual and creative output of the region.[360] Nineteenth century Bengal was a unique blend of religious and social reformers, scholars, literary giants, journalists, patriotic orators, and scientists, all merging to form the image of a renaissance, and marked the transition from the 'medieval' to the 'modern'.[361]

The Mesolithic is characterized in most areas by small composite flint tools — microliths and microburins. Fishing tackle, stone adzes and wooden objects, e.g. canoes and bows, have been found at some sites. These technologies first occur in Africa, associated with the Azilian cultures, before spreading to Europe through the Ibero-Maurusian culture of Northern Africa and the Kebaran culture of the Levant. Independent discovery is not always ruled out.

The underlying principle of most medieval medicine be Galen's theory of humours. This be derive from the ancient medical works, and dominate all western medicine until the 19th century. The theory state that within every individual there be four humours, or principal fluids- black bile, yellow bile, phlegm, and blood, these be produce by various organs in the body, and they have to be in balance for a person to remain healthy. Too much phlegm in the body, for example, cause lung problems; and the body try to cough up the phlegm to restore a balance. The balance of humours in humans could be achieve by diet, medicines, and by blood-letting, use leeches. The four humours be also associate with the four seasons, black bile-autumn, yellow bile-summer, phlegm-winter and blood-spring.[ 55]

Ancient Egypt make significant advances in astronomy, mathematics and medicine.[ 13] Their development of geometry be a necessary outgrowth of survey to preserve the layout and ownership of farmland, which be flood annually by the Nile river. The 3-4-5 right triangle and other rules of geometry be use to build rectilinear structures, and the post and lintel architecture of Egypt. Egypt be also a center of alchemy research for much of the Mediterranean.The Edwin Smith papyrus be one of the first medical documents still extant, and perhaps the earliest document that attempt to describe and analyse the brain: it might be see as the very beginnings of modern neuroscience. However, while Egyptian medicine have some effective practices, it be not without its ineffective and sometimes harmful practices. Medical historians believe that ancient Egyptian pharmacology, for example, be largely ineffective.[ 14] Nevertheless, it apply the following components to the treatment of disease: examination, diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis,[ 15] which display strong parallels to the basic empirical method of science and accord to G. E. R. Lloyd[ 16] play a significant role in the development of this methodology. The Ebers papyrus( c. 1550 BC) also contain evidence of traditional empiricism.

Although the Romans had a more hostile attitude than the Greeks towards the Egyptians, some traditions such as mummification and worship of the traditional gods continued.[83] The art of mummy portraiture flourished, and some Roman emperors had themselves depicted as pharaohs, though not to the extent that the Ptolemies had. The former lived outside Egypt and did not perform the ceremonial functions of Egyptian kingship. Local administration became Roman in style and closed to native Egyptians.[83]

By the mid-19th century, there was a strong desire for representative and responsible government in the colonies of Australia, fed by the democratic spirit of the goldfields evident at the Eureka Stockade and the ideas of the great reform movements sweeping Europe, the United States and the British Empire. The end of convict transportation accelerated reform in the 1840s and 1850s. The Australian Colonies Government Act [1850] was a landmark development which granted representative constitutions to New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Tasmania and the colonies enthusiastically set about writing constitutions which produced democratically progressive parliaments—though the constitutions generally maintained the role of the colonial upper houses as representative of social and economic "interests" and all established constitutional monarchies with the British monarch as the symbolic head of state.[204]

Bronze artifacts have been found at the Majiayao culture site (between 3100 and 2700 BC),[18][19] The Bronze Age is also represented at the Lower Xiajiadian culture (2200–1600 BC[20]) site in northeast China. Sanxingdui located in what is now Sichuan province is believed to be the site of a major ancient city, of a previously unknown Bronze Age culture (between 2000 and 1200 BC). The site was first discovered in in 1929 and then re-discovered in 1986. Chinese archaeologists have identified the Sanxingdui culture to be part of the ancient kingdom of Shu, linking the artifacts found at the site to its early legendary kings.[21][22]

Later, the Abbasids have take control, move the capital to Baghdad. The Berber people, be independent in spirit and hostile to outside interference in their affairs and to Arab exclusivity in orthodox Islam, adopt Shi'ite and Kharijite Islam, both consider unorthodox and hostile to the authority of the Abbasid Caliphate. Numerous Kharijite kingdoms come and fell during the 8th and 9th centuries, assert their independence from Baghdad. In the early 10th century, Shi'ite groups from Syria, claim descent from Muhammad's daughter Fatimah, found the Fatimid Dynasty in the Maghreb. By 950, they have conquer all of the Maghreb and by 969 all of Egypt. They have immediately break away from Baghdad.[ 108]

The Renaissance be say by many to be the golden age of painting. Roughly span the 14th through the mid-17th century. In Italy artists like Paolo Uccello, Fra Angelico, Masaccio, Piero della Francesca, Andrea Mantegna, Filippo Lippi, Giorgione, Tintoretto, Sandro Botticelli, Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo Buonarroti, Raphael, Giovanni Bellini, and Titian take paint to a higher level through the use of perspective, the study of human anatomy and proportion, and through their development of an unprecedented refinement in draw and paint techniques.

For example, the domestication of maize for agriculture have be date to about 9,000 years ago in southern Mexico, before the development of write systems.[ 6][ 7][ 8] Similarly, archaeological evidence indicate the development of astronomical knowledge in preliterate societies.[ 9][ 10] The development of write enable knowledge to be store and communicate across generations with much greater fidelity.

Piero della Francesca (c.1415–1492) wrote books on solid geometry and linear perspective, including De Prospectiva Pingendi (On Perspective for Painting), Trattato d’Abaco (Abacus Treatise), and De corporibus regularibus (Regular Solids).[134][135][136]

Classical music be a broad, imprecise category, include music produce in, or root in the traditions of art, ecclesiastical and concert music. A music be classical if it include some of the following features: a learned tradition, support from the church or government, or greater cultural capital. Classical music be also describe as complex, lasting, transcendent, and abstract. In many cultures a classical tradition coexist with traditional or popular music, occasionally for thousands of years, and with different levels of mutual borrowing with the parallel tradition.

Steam locomotives began being built after the introduction of high pressure steam engines after the expiration of the Boulton and Watt patent in 1800. High pressure engines exhausted used steam to the atmosphere, doing away with the condenser and cooling water. They were also much lighter weight and smaller in size for a given horsepower than the stationary condensing engines. A few of these early locomotives were used in mines. Steam-hauled public railways began with the Stockton and Darlington Railway in 1825.

Across continental Europe, but in France especially, booksellers and publishers had to negotiate censorship laws of varying strictness. The Encyclopédie, for example, narrowly escaped seizure and had to be saved by Malesherbes, the man in charge of the French censure. Indeed, many publishing companies were conveniently located outside France so as to avoid overzealous French censors. They would smuggle their merchandise across the border, where it would then be transported to clandestine booksellers or small-time peddlers.[151] The records of clandestine booksellers may give a better representation of what literate Frenchmen might have truly read, since their clandestine nature provided a less restrictive product choice.[152] In one case, political books were the most popular category, primarily libels and pamphlets. Readers were more interested in sensationalist stories about criminals and political corruption than they were in political theory itself. The second most popular category, "general works" (those books "that did not have a dominant motif and that contained something to offend almost everyone in authority") demonstrated a high demand for generally low-brow subversive literature. However, these works never became part of literary canon, and are largely forgotten today as a result.[152]

By AD 900, developments in iron smelting allowed for increased production in Europe, leading to developments in the production of agricultural implements such as ploughs, hand tools and horse shoes. The carruca plough improved on the earlier scratch plough, with the adoption of the Chinese mouldboard plough to turn over the heavy, wet soils of northern Europe. This led to the clearing of northern European forests and an increase in agricultural production, which in turn led to an increase in population.[91] At the same time, farmers in Europe moved from a two field crop rotation to a three field crop rotation in which one field of three was left fallow every year. This resulted in increased productivity and nutrition, as the change in rotations permitted nitrogen-fixing legumes such as peas, lentils and beans. Improved horse harnesses and the whippletree further improved cultivation.[91] Watermills were introduced by the Romans, but were improved throughout the Middle Ages, along with windmills, and used to grind grains into flour, to cut wood and to process flax and wool.[92]

In other words, the Iron Age refers to the advent of ferrous metallurgy. Historical developments in ferrous metallurgy can be find in a wide variety of past cultures and civilizations. This include the ancient and medieval kingdoms and empires of the Middle East and Near East, ancient Iran, ancient Egypt, ancient Nubia, and Anatolia( Turkey), Ancient Nok, Carthage, the Greeks and Romans of ancient Europe, medieval Europe, ancient and medieval China, ancient and medieval India, ancient and medieval Japan, amongst others. Many applications, practices, and devices associate or involve in metallurgy be establish in ancient China, such as the innovation of the blast furnace, cast iron, hydraulic-powered trip hammers, and double act piston bellows.[ 9][ 10]

The cinema of South Korea also experienced a 'Golden Age' in the 1950s, beginning with director Lee Kyu-hwan's tremendously successful remake of Chunhyang-jon (1955).[53] That year also saw the release of Yangsan Province by the renowned director, Kim Ki-young, marking the beginning of his productive career. Both the quality and quantity of filmmaking had increased rapidly by the end of the 1950s. In the 11th century, the Seljuk Turks take over much of the Middle East, occupy Persia during the 1040s, Armenia in the 1060s, and Jerusalem in 1070. In 1071, the Turkish army defeat the Byzantine army at the Battle of Manzikert and capture the Byzantine Emperor Romanus IV( r. 1068–71). The Turks be then free to invade Asia Minor, which deal a dangerous blow to the Byzantine Empire by seize a large part of its population and its economic heartland. Although the Byzantines regroup and recover somewhat, they never fully regain Asia Minor and be often on the defensive. The Turks also have difficulties, lose control of Jerusalem to the Fatimids of Egypt and suffer from a series of internal civil wars.[ 206] The Byzantines also face a revive Bulgaria, which in the late 12th and 13th centuries spread throughout the Balkans.[ 207]

Anthropology can best be understood as an outgrowth of the Age of Enlightenment. It was during this period that Europeans attempted systematically to study human behaviour. Traditions of jurisprudence, history, philology and sociology developed during this time and informed the development of the social sciences of which anthropology was a part.

In the 4th century BC, Rome had come under attack by the Gauls, who now extended their power in the Italian peninsula beyond the Po Valley and through Etruria. On 16 July 390 BC, a Gallic army under the leadership of a tribal chieftain named Brennus, met the Romans on the banks of the Allia River just ten miles north of Rome. Brennus defeated the Romans, and the Gauls marched directly to Rome. Most Romans had fled the city, but some barricaded themselves upon the Capitoline Hill for a last stand. The Gauls looted and burned the city, then laid siege to the Capitoline Hill. The siege lasted seven months, the Gauls then agreed to give the Romans peace in exchange for 1,000 pounds (450 kg) of gold.[28] (According to later legend, the Roman supervising the weighing noticed that the Gauls were using false scales. The Romans then took up arms and defeated the Gauls; their victorious general Camillus remarked "With iron, not with gold, Rome buys her freedom.")[29]

Panel paint becomes more common during the Romanesque period, under the heavy influence of Byzantine icons. Towards the middle of the 13th century, Medieval art and Gothic painting become more realistic, with the beginnings of interest in the depiction of volume and perspective in Italy with Cimabue and then his pupil Giotto. From Giotto on, the treatment of composition by the best painters also become much more free and innovative. They be consider to be the two great medieval masters of paint in western culture. Cimabue, within the Byzantine tradition, use a more realistic and dramatic approach to his art. His pupil, Giotto, take these innovations to a higher level which in turn set the foundations for the western painting tradition. Both artists be pioneers in the move towards naturalism.

James Cook be aware of la Roché's discovery when surveying and map the island in 1775.[ 3]

The West respond with the Crusades, eventually result in the Sack of Constantinople by participants of the Fourth Crusade. The conquest of Constantinople in 1204 fragment what remain of the Empire into successor states; the ultimate victor be the Empire of Nicaea.[ 152] After the recapture of Constantinople by Imperial forces, the Empire be little more than a Greek state confine to the Aegean coast. The Byzantine Empire collapse when Mehmed the Conqueror conquer Constantinople on 29 May, 1453.[ 153]

Important contributions were made by Ibn al-Haytham (965–1040), a mathematician from Basra (in present-day Iraq) considered one of the founders of modern optics. Ptolemy and Aristotle theorised that light either shone from the eye to illuminate objects or that light emanated from objects themselves, whereas al-Haytham (known by the Latin name Alhazen) suggested that light travels to the eye in rays from different points on an object. The works of Ibn al-Haytham and Abū Rayhān Bīrūnī, a Persian scientist, eventually passed on to Western Europe where they were studied by scholars such as Roger Bacon and Witelo.[9][note 2] Omar Khayyám (1048–1131), a Persian scientist, calculated the length of a solar year and was only out by a fraction of a second when compared to our modern day calculations. He used this to compose a calendar considered more accurate than the Gregorian calendar that came along 500 years later. He is classified as one of the world's first great science communicators, said, for example to have convinced a Sufi theologian that the world turns on an axis.

In many cases different cultures leave their materials as the only records which anthropologists can use to define the existence of such cultures. The progressive use of more sophisticated materials allows archeologists to characterize and distinguish between peoples. This is partially due to the major material of use in a culture and to its associated benefits and drawbacks. Stone-Age cultures were limited by which rocks they could find locally and by which they could acquire by trading. The use of flint around 300,000 BCE is sometimes[when?] considered the beginning of the use of ceramics. The use of polished stone axes marks a significant advance because a much wider variety of rocks could serve as tools.

Rational mechanics deal primarily with the development of elaborate mathematical treatments of observed motions, use Newtonian principles as a basis, and emphasize improve the tractability of complex calculations and develop of legitimate means of analytical approximation. A representative contemporary textbook be publish by Johann Baptiste Horvath. By the end of the century analytical treatments be rigorous enough to verify the stability of the solar system solely on the basis of Newton's laws without reference to divine intervention—even as deterministic treatments of systems as simple as the three body problem in gravitation remain intractable.[ 29] In 1705, Edmond Halley predict the periodicity of Halley's Comet, William Herschel discover Uranus in 1781, and Henry Cavendish measure the gravitational constant and determine the mass of the Earth in 1798. In 1783, John Michell suggest that some objects might be so massive that not even light could escape from them.

Writing about cricket in particular, John Leech( 2005a) have explain the role of Puritan power, the English Civil War, and the Restoration of the monarchy in England. The Long Parliament in 1642 `` ban theatres, which have meet with Puritan disapproval. Although similar action would be take against certain sports, it be not clear if cricket be in any way prohibit, except that players must not break the Sabbath''. In 1660, `` the Restoration of the monarchy in England be immediately follow by the reopening of the theatres and so any sanctions that have be impose by the Puritans on cricket would also have be lift. ``[ 21] He go on to make the key point that political, social and economic conditions in the aftermath of the Restoration encourage excessive gambling, so much so that a Gambling Act be deem necessary in 1664. It be certain that cricket, horse racing and boxing( i.e., prizefight) be finance by gamble interests. Leech explain that it be the habit of cricket patrons, all of whom be gamblers, to form strong teams through the 18th century to represent their interests. He define a strong team as one representative of more than one parish and he be certain that such teams be first assemble in or immediately after 1660. Prior to the English Civil War and the Commonwealth, all available evidence concludes that cricket have evolve to the level of village cricket only where teams that be strictly representative of individual parishes compete. The `` strong teams'' of the post-Restoration mark the evolution of cricket( and, indeed of professional team sport, for cricket be the oldest professional team sport) from the parish standard to the county standard. This be the point of origin for major, or first-class, cricket. The year 1660 also mark the origin of professional team sport.

Ancient Rome be an Italic civilization that begin on the Italian Peninsula as early as the 8th century BC. Located along the Mediterranean Sea and center on the city of Rome, it expand to become one of the largest empires in the ancient world with an estimate 50 to 90 million inhabitants( roughly 20% of the world's population[ 1]) and cover 5.0 million square kilometers at its height in AD 117.[ 2]

The earliest known uniform systems of weights and measures seem all to have be create at some time in the 4th and 3rd millennia BC among the ancient peoples of Egypt, Mesopotamia and the Indus Valley, and perhaps also Elam( in Iran) as well.
The U.S. Army learn many lessons and in August 1886, it establish the Hospital Corps.

The spin–statistics theorem establish that any particle in quantum mechanics may be either a boson( statistically Bose–Einstein) or a fermion( statistically Fermi–Dirac). It be later find that all fundamental bosons transmit forces, such as the photon that transmit electromagnetism.

Technically Surrealism was an important predecessor for abstract expressionism with its emphasis on spontaneous, automatic or subconscious creation. Jackson Pollock's dripping paint onto a canvas laid on the floor is a technique that has its roots in the work of André Masson. Another important early manifestation of what came to be abstract expressionism is the work of American Northwest artist Mark Tobey, especially his "white writing" canvases, which, though generally not large in scale, anticipate the "all over" look of Pollock's drip paintings.

The final expansion in this period began during the reign of Ying Zheng, the king of Qin. His unification of the other six powers, and further annexations in the modern regions of Zhejiang, Fujian, Guangdong and Guangxi in 214 BC, enabled him to proclaim himself the First Emperor (Qin Shi Huang).

As a cultural movement, the Renaissance encompass innovative flowering of Latin and vernacular literatures, begin with the 14th-century resurgence of learn base on classical sources, which contemporaries credit to Petrarch; the development of linear perspective and other techniques of render a more natural reality in painting; and gradual but widespread educational reform. In politics, the Renaissance contribute to the development of the customs and conventions of diplomacy, and in science to an increase reliance on observation and inductive reasoning. Although the Renaissance saw revolutions in many intellectual pursuits, as well as social and political upheaval, it be perhaps best know for its artistic developments and the contributions of such polymaths as Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo, who inspire the term `` Renaissance man''.[ 2][ 3]

These theories clashed with the evidence of explorers, however, Hanno the Navigator had traveled as far south as Sierra Leone, and it is possible other Phoenicians had circumnavigated Africa[citation needed]. In the 4th century BC the Greek explorer Pytheas traveled through northeast Europe, and circled the British Isles. He found that the region was considerably more habitable than theory expected, but his discoveries were largely dismissed by his contemporaries because of this. Conquerors also carried out exploration, for example, Caesar's invasions of Britain and Germany, expeditions/invasions sent by Augustus to Arabia Felix and Ethiopia (Res Gestae 26), and perhaps the greatest Ancient Greek explorer of all, Alexander the Great, who deliberately set out to learn more about the east through his military expeditions and so took a large number of geographers and writers with his army who recorded their observations as they moved east.

The oldest known civilization of the Americas be establish in the Norte Chico region of modern Peru. Complex society emerge in the group of coastal valleys, between 3000 and 1800 BCE. The Quipu, a distinctive recording device among Andean civilizations, apparently date from the era of Norte Chico's prominence.

In the past few centuries, some statistical methods have be develop, for reason in the face of uncertainty, as an outgrowth of methods for eliminate error. This be an echo of the program of Francis Bacon's Novum Organum of 1620. Bayesian inference acknowledge one's ability to alter one's beliefs in the face of evidence. This have be call belief revision, or defeasible reasoning: the models in play during the phases of scientific method can be review, revisit and revise, in the light of further evidence. This arose from the work of Frank P. Ramsey[ 98]( 1903–1930), of John Maynard Keynes[ 99]( 1883–1946), and earlier, of William Stanley Jevons[ 100][ 101]( 1835–1882) in economics.

In 1859, James Clerk Maxwell discover the distribution law of molecular velocities. Maxwell show that electric and magnetic fields be propagate outward from their source at a speed equal to that of light and that light be one of several kinds of electromagnetic radiation, differ only in frequency and wavelength from the others. In 1859, Maxwell work out the mathematics of the distribution of velocities of the molecules of a gas. The wave theory of light be widely accept by the time of Maxwell's work on the electromagnetic field, and afterward the study of light and that of electricity and magnetism be closely relate. In 1864 James Maxwell publish his papers on a dynamical theory of the electromagnetic field, and state that light be an electromagnetic phenomenon in the 1873 publication of Maxwell's Treatise on Electricity and Magnetism. This work draw upon theoretical work by German theoreticians such as Carl Friedrich Gauss and Wilhelm Weber. The encapsulation of heat in particulate motion, and the addition of electromagnetic forces to Newtonian dynamics establish an enormously robust theoretical underpinning to physical observations.

By 1644, the northern Manchu people had conquered China and established a foreign dynasty—the Qing Dynasty—once more. The Manchu Qing emperors, especially Confucian scholar Kangxi, remained largely conservative—retaining the bureaucracy and the scholars within it, as well as the Confucian ideals present in Chinese society. However, changes in the economy and new attempts at resolving certain issues occurred too. These included increased trade with Western countries that brought large amounts of silver into the Chinese economy in exchange for tea, porcelain, and silk textiles. This allowed for a new merchant-class, the compradors, to develop. In addition, repairs were done on existing dikes, canals, roadways, and irrigation works. This, combined with the lowering of taxes and government-assigned labor, was supposed to calm peasant unrest. However, the Qing failed to control the growing landlord class which had begun to exploit the peasantry and abuse their position.

Charlemagne's reign marked the beginning of a new Germanic Roman Empire in the west, the Holy Roman Empire. Outside his borders, new forces were gathering. The Kievan Rus' were marking out their territory, a Great Moravia was growing, while the Angles and the Saxons were securing their borders.

Ancient warfare is war as conducted from the beginnings of recorded history to the end of the ancient period. In Europe, the end of antiquity is often equated with the fall of Rome in 476. In China, it can also be seen as ending in the 5th century, with the growing role of mounted warriors needed to counter the ever-growing threat from the north.

The invention of printing had an immense influence on the dissemination of musical styles, and along with the movement of the Franco-Flemish musicians, contributed to the establishment of the first truly international style in European music since the unification of Gregorian chant under Charlemagne. Composers of the middle generation of the Franco-Flemish school included Johannes Ockeghem, who wrote music in a contrapuntally complex style, with varied texture and an elaborate use of canonical devices; Jacob Obrecht, one of the most famous composers of masses in the last decades of the 15th century; and Josquin des Prez, probably the most famous composer in Europe before Palestrina, and who during the 16th century was renowned as one of the greatest artists in any form. Music in the generation after Josquin explored increasing complexity of counterpoint; possibly the most extreme expression is in the music of Nicolas Gombert, whose contrapuntal complexities influenced early instrumental music, such as the canzona and the ricercar, ultimately culminating in Baroque fugal forms.

In 1954, Gamal Abdel Nasser deposed the monarchy of Egypt in the Egyptian Revolution of 1952 and came to power as Prime Minister of Egypt.[229] Muammar Gaddafi led the 1969 Libyan coup d'état which deposed Idris of Libya. Gaddafi remained in power until his death in Libyan Civil War of 2011.[230]

Railways were made practical by the widespread introduction of inexpensive puddled iron after 1800, the rolling mill for making rails, and the development of the high pressure steam engine also around 1800.
