The studio system produce frenetic activity in the local film industry as many films be make annually and several local talents start to earn recognition abroad. The premiere Philippine directors of the era include Gerardo de Leon, Gregorio Fernández, Eddie Romero, Lamberto Avellana, and Cirio Santiago.[ 55][ 56]

Creationism, in the form of Intelligent Design, suffered a major legal defeat in the Kitzmiller v. Dover Area School District trial. Judge John E. Jones III ruled that Intelligent Design is inseparable from Creationism, and its teaching in public schools violates the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment. The trial sparked much interest, and was the subject of several documentaries including the award winning NOVA production Judgment Day: Intelligent Design on Trial (2007).

31 kings reign over the Shang dynasty. During their reign, accord to the Records of the Grand Historian, the capital city be move six times.[ citation need] The final( and most important) move be to Yin in 1350 BC which lead to the dynasty's golden age.[ citation need] The term Yin dynasty have be synonymous with the Shang dynasty in history, although it have lately be use to refer specifically to the latter half of the Shang dynasty.[ citation need]

Although the archives of chemical research draw upon work from ancient Babylonia, Egypt, and especially the Arabs and Persians after Islam, modern chemistry flourish from the time of Antoine-Laurent de Lavoisier, a French chemist who be celebrate as the `` father of modern chemistry''. Lavoisier demonstrate with careful measurements that transmutation of water to earth be not possible, but that the sediment observe from boil water come from the container. He burn phosphorus and sulfur in air, and prove that the products weigh more than the original. Nevertheless, the weight gain be lose from the air. Thus, in 1789, he establish the Law of Conservation of Mass, which be also call `` Lavoisier's Law. ``[ 54]

Catholic women played large roles in health and healing in medieval and early modern Europe.[69] A life as a nun was a prestigious role; wealthy families provided dowries for their daughters, and these funded the convents, while the nuns provided free nursing care for the poor.[70]

The visit to South Georgia by the English merchant Anthony de la Roché in 1675 was the first ever discovery of land south of the Antarctic Convergence.[1][2] Soon after the voyage cartographers started to depict ‘Roché Island’, honouring the discoverer.

Meanwhile, in North Africa, the Axis Powers have drive Allies back in to Egypt. A turn point come between July and November 1942, when Australia's 9th Division play a crucial role in some of the heaviest fighting of the First and Second Battle of El Alamein, which turn the North Africa Campaign in favour of the Allies.[ 317]

The Great Vowel Shift affected the stressed long vowels of Middle English. It was a chain shift, meaning that each shift triggered a subsequent shift in the vowel system. Mid and open vowels were raised, and close vowels were broken into diphthongs. For example, the word bite was originally pronounced as the word beet is today, and the second vowel in the word about was pronounced as the word boot is today. The Great Vowel Shift explains many irregularities in spelling, since English retains many spellings from Middle English, and it also explains why English vowel letters have very different pronunciations from the same letters in other languages.[41][42]

On the return, a storm force him to dock in Lisbon, on 4 March 1493. After a week in Portugal, he set sail for Spain and on 15 March 1493 arrive in Barcelona, where he report to Queen Isabella and King Ferdinand. Word of his discovery of new lands rapidly spread throughout Europe.[ 62]

Archaeological findings providing evidence for the existence of the Shang dynasty, c. 1600–1046 BC, are divided into two sets. The first set, from the earlier Shang period, comes from sources at Erligang, Zhengzhou, and Shangcheng. The second set, from the later Shang or Yin (殷) period, is at Anyang, in modern-day Henan, which has been confirmed as the last of the Shang's nine capitals (c. 1300–1046 BC).[citation needed] The findings at Anyang include the earliest written record of Chinese past so far discovered: inscriptions of divination records in ancient Chinese writing on the bones or shells of animals — the so-called "oracle bones", dating from around 1500 BC.[1]

Muslim chemists and alchemists played an important role in the foundation of modern chemistry. Scholars such as Will Durant[64] and Fielding H. Garrison[65] considered Muslim chemists to be the founders of chemistry. In particular, Jābir ibn Hayyān is "considered by many to be the father of chemistry".[66][67] The works of Arabic scientists influenced Roger Bacon (who introduced the empirical method to Europe, strongly influenced by his reading of Persians writers),[68] and later Isaac Newton.[69]

The Olmec are also known for their small carvings made of jade and other greenstones. So many of the Olmec figurines and sculptures contain representations of the were-jaguar, that, according to José María Covarrubias, they could be forerunners of the worship of the rain god, or maybe a predecessor of the future Tezcatlipoca in his manifestation as Tepeyolohtli, the "Heart of the Mountain"

Cotton be another widespread crop in Norte Chico, essential to the production of fish nets and textiles. Jonathan Haas note a mutual dependency, whereby `` The prehistoric residents of the Norte Chico need the fish resources for their protein and the fishermen need the cotton to make the nets to catch the fish.''

The dynasty was founded by Mayurasharma in 345 CE which at later times showed the potential of developing into imperial proportions, an indication to which is provided by the titles and epithets assumed by its rulers. King Mayurasharma defeated the armies of Pallavas of Kanchi possibly with help of some native tribes. The Kadamba fame reached its peak during the rule of Kakusthavarma, a notable ruler with whom even the kings of Gupta Dynasty of northern India cultivated marital alliances. The Kadambas were contemporaries of the Western Ganga Dynasty and together they formed the earliest native kingdoms to rule the land with absolute autonomy. The dynasty later continued to rule as a feudatory of larger Kannada empires, the Chalukya and the Rashtrakuta empires, for over five hundred years during which time they branched into minor dynasties known as the Kadambas of Goa, Kadambas of Halasi and Kadambas of Hangal.

After Rococo there arose in the late 18th century, in architecture, and then in paint severe neo-classicism, best represent by such artists as David and his heir Ingres. Ingres' work already contain much of the sensuality, but none of the spontaneity, that be to characterize Romanticism. This movement turn its attention toward landscape and nature as well as the human figure and the supremacy of natural order above mankind's will. There be a pantheist philosophy( see Spinoza and Hegel) within this conception that oppose Enlightenment ideals by see mankind's destiny in a more tragic or pessimistic light. The idea that human beings be not above the forces of Nature be in contradiction to Ancient Greek and Renaissance ideals where mankind be above all things and own his fate. This thinking lead romantic artists to depict the sublime, ruin churches, shipwrecks, massacres and madness.

With the Renaissance came an increase in experimental investigation, principally in the field of dissection and body examination, thus advancing our knowledge of human anatomy.[1] The development of modern neurology began in the 16th century with Vesalius, who described the anatomy of the brain and other organs; he had little knowledge of the brain's function, thinking that it resided mainly in the ventricles. Understanding of medical sciences and diagnosis improved, but with little direct benefit to health care. Few effective drugs existed, beyond opium and quinine. William Harvey provided a refined and complete description of the circulatory system. The most useful tomes in medicine, used both by students and expert physicians, were materiae medicae and pharmacopoeiae.

Since 1900, agriculture in the developed nations, and to a lesser extent in the developing world, has seen large rises in productivity as human labour has been replaced by mechanization, and assisted by synthetic fertilizers, pesticides, and selective breeding. The Haber-Bosch process allowed the synthesis of ammonium nitrate fertilizer on an industrial scale, greatly increasing crop yields. Modern agriculture has raised social, political, and environmental issues including water pollution, biofuels, genetically modified organisms, tariffs and farm subsidies.

Although letters and speech sounds do not have a one-to-one correspondence in standard English spelling, spell rules that take into account syllable structure, phonetic changes in derived words, and word accent be reliable for most English words.[ 222] Moreover, standard English spelling shows etymological relationships between related words that would be obscure by a closer correspondence between pronunciation and spelling, for example the words photograph, photography, and photographic,[ 222] or the words electricity and electrical. While few scholars agree with Chomsky and Halle( 1968) that conventional English orthography be `` near-optimal'',[ 219] there be a rationale for current English spelling patterns.[ 223] The standard orthography of English be the most widely use writing system in the world.[ 224] Standard English spelling be base on a graphomorphemic segmentation of words into write clues of what meaningful units make up each word.[ 225]

The High Middle Ages of the 11th, 12th, and 13th centuries show a rapidly increase population of Europe, which cause great social and political change from the precede era. By 1250, the robust population increase greatly benefit the economy, reach levels it would not see again in some areas until the 19th century. From about the year 1000 onwards, Western Europe saw the last of the barbarian invasions and become more politically organize. The Vikings have settle in Britain, Ireland, France and elsewhere, whilst Norse Christian kingdoms be develop in their Scandinavian homelands. The Magyars have cease their expansion in the 10th century, and by the year 1000, the Roman Catholic Apostolic Kingdom of Hungary be recognise in central Europe. With the brief exception of the Mongol invasions, major barbarian incursions cease.

Other depictions of the Stone Age include the best-selling Earth's Children series of books by Jean M. Auel, which be set in the Paleolithic and be loosely base on archaeological and anthropological findings. The 1981 film Quest for Fire by Jean-Jacques Annaud tell the story of a group of neanderthals search for their lose fire. A 21st-century series, Chronicles of Ancient Darkness by Michelle Paver tells of two New Stone Age children fight to fulfil a prophecy and save their clan.

The medical problems of the ancient Egyptians stemmed directly from their environment. Living and working close to the Nile brought hazards from malaria and debilitating schistosomiasis parasites, which caused liver and intestinal damage. Dangerous wildlife such as crocodiles and hippos were also a common threat. The lifelong labors of farming and building put stress on the spine and joints, and traumatic injuries from construction and warfare all took a significant toll on the body. The grit and sand from stone-ground flour abraded teeth, leaving them susceptible to abscesses (though caries were rare).[185]

Public education expenditures in the late 19th and early 20th centuries vary dramatically across regions with the western and southern provinces spend three to four times as much as the eastern provinces. Much of the inter-regional differential be due to historical differences in land taxes, the major source of revenue.[ 78]

Since the sixteenth century there were some movements of discontent to Spanish and Portuguese colonial system. Among these movements, the most famous being that of the Maroons, slaves who escaped their masters and in the shelter of the forest communities organized free communities. Attempts to subject them by the royal army was unsuccessful, because the Maroons had learned to master the South American jungles. In a royal decree of 1713, the king gave legality to the first free population of the continent: Palenque de San Basilio in Colombia today, led by Benkos Bioho. Brazil saw the formation of a genuine African kingdom on their soil, with the Quilombo of Palmares.[citation needed]

By the twentieth century, the industrial revolution have lead to an exponential increase in the human consumption of resources. The increase in health, wealth and population be perceive as a simple path of progress. However, in the 1930s economists begin develop models of non-renewable resource management( see Hotelling's rule) and the sustainability of welfare in an economy that use non-renewable resources.

Focus constructions emphasise a particular piece of new or salient information within a sentence, generally through allocating the main sentence level stress on the focal constituent. For example, the girl was stung by a bee (emphasising it was a bee and not for example a wasp that stung her), or The girl was stung by a bee (contrasting with another possibility, for example that it was the boy).[195] Topic and focus can also be established through syntactic dislocation, either preposing or postposing the item to be focused on relative to the main clause. For example, That girl over there, she was stung by a bee, emphasises the girl by preposition, but a similar effect could be achieved by postposition, she was stung by a bee, that girl over there, where reference to the girl is established as an "afterthought".[196]

In 1511, Afonso de Albuquerque conquered Malacca for Portugal, then the center of Asian trade. East of Malacca, Albuquerque sent several diplomatic missions: Duarte Fernandes as the first European envoy to the Kingdom of Siam (modern Thailand).

Politically, Robert Menzies and the Liberal Party of Australia dominate much of the immediate post war era, defeat the Labor government of Ben Chifley in 1949, in part over a Labor proposal to nationalise banks[ 335] and follow a crippling coal strike lead by the Australian Communist Party. Menzies become the country's longest-serving Prime Minister and the Liberal party, in coalition with the rural base Country Party, win every federal election until 1972.

Oswald Avery show in 1943 that DNA be likely the genetic material of the chromosome, not its protein; the issue be settle decisively with the 1952 Hershey–Chase experiment—one of many contributions from the so-called phage group center around physicist-turned-biologist Max Delbrück. In 1953 James Watson and Francis Crick, building on the work of Maurice Wilkins and Rosalind Franklin, suggest that the structure of DNA be a double helix. In their famous paper `` Molecular structure of Nucleic Acids'', Watson and Crick note coyly, `` It have not escape our notice that the specific pairing we have postulate immediately suggest a possible copying mechanism for the genetic material. ``[ 69] After the 1958 Meselson–Stahl experiment confirm the semiconservative replication of DNA, it be clear to most biologists that nucleic acid sequence must somehow determine amino acid sequence in proteins; physicist George Gamow propose that a fixed genetic code connect proteins and DNA. Between 1953 and 1961, there be few known biological sequences—either DNA or protein—but an abundance of proposed code systems, a situation make even more complicated by expand knowledge of the intermediate role of RNA. To actually decipher the code, it take an extensive series of experiments in biochemistry and bacterial genetics, between 1961 and 1966—most importantly the work of Nirenberg and Khorana.[ 70]

Locke be know for his statement that individuals have a right to `` Life, Liberty and Property'', and his belief that the natural right to property be derive from labor. Tutored by Locke, Anthony Ashley-Cooper, 3rd Earl of Shaftesbury write in 1706: `` There be a mighty Light which spread its self over the world especially in those two free Nations of England and Holland; on whom the Affairs of Europe now turn''.[ 48] Locke's theory of natural rights have influence many political documents, include the United States Declaration of Independence and the French National Constituent Assembly's Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen.

The Mulifanua site, where 4,288 pottery shards have be find and study, have a `` true'' age of c. 1000 BC base on C14 date.[ 7] A 2010 study place the beginning of the human archaeological sequences of Polynesia in Tonga at 900 B.C.,[ 8] the small differences in dates with Samoa be due to differences in radiocarbon date technologies between 1989 and 2010, the Tongan site apparently predate the Samoan site by some few decades in real time.

Grammarians follow Pāṇini include Kātyāyana( c. 3rd century BCE), who write aphorisms on Pāṇini( the Varttika) and advanced mathematics; Patañjali( 2nd century BCE), know for his commentary on select topics in Pāṇini's grammar( the Mahabhasya) and on Kātyāyana's aphorisms, as well as, accord to some, the author of the Yoga Sutras, and Pingala, with his mathematical approach to prosody. Several debates range over centuries, for example, on whether word-meaning mappings be conventional( Vaisheshika-Nyaya) or eternal( Kātyāyana-Patañjali-Mīmāṃsā).

In astronomy, Al-Battani improved the measurements of Hipparchus, preserved in the translation of Ptolemy's Hè Megalè Syntaxis (The great treatise) translated as Almagest. Al-Battani also improved the precision of the measurement of the precession of the Earth's axis. The corrections made to the geocentric model by al-Battani, Ibn al-Haytham,[58] Averroes and the Maragha astronomers such as Nasir al-Din al-Tusi, Mo'ayyeduddin Urdi and Ibn al-Shatir are similar to Copernican heliocentric model.[59][60] Heliocentric theories may have also been discussed by several other Muslim astronomers such as Ja'far ibn Muhammad Abu Ma'shar al-Balkhi,[61] Abu-Rayhan Biruni, Abu Said al-Sijzi,[62] Qutb al-Din al-Shirazi, and Najm al-Dīn al-Qazwīnī al-Kātibī.[63]

Written mostly in the form of pamphlets, the libelles `` slander the court, the Church, the aristocracy, the academies, the salons, everything elevate and respectable, include the monarchy itself''.[ 140] Le Gazetier cuirassé by Charles Théveneau de Morande be a prototype of the genre. It be Grub Street literature that be most read by the public during the Enlightenment.[ 141] More importantly, accord to Darnton, the Grub Street hacks inherit the `` revolutionary spirit'' once display by the philosophes, and pave the way for the French Revolution by desacralize figures of political, moral and religious authority in France.[ 142]
Japanese architecture has as long a history as any other aspect of Japanese culture. it also shows a number of important differences and aspects which are uniquely Japanese.

Despite these qualifications, the standard theory of the history of the scientific revolution claims that the 17th century be a period of revolutionary scientific changes. Not only be there revolutionary theoretical and experimental developments, but that even more importantly, the way in which scientists work be radically change. For instance, although intimations of the concept of inertia be suggest sporadically in ancient discussion of motion,[ 30][ 31] the salient point be that Newton's theory differ from ancient understandings in key ways, such as an external force be a requirement for violent motion in Aristotle's theory.[ 32]

In the 5th century AD, Aryabhata write the Aryabhatiya, a slim volume, write in verse, intend to supplement the rules of calculation use in astronomy and mathematical mensuration, though with no feeling for logic or deductive methodology.[ 100] Though about half of the entries be wrong, it be in the Aryabhatiya that the decimal place-value system first appear. Several centuries later, the Muslim mathematician Abu Rayhan Biruni describe the Aryabhatiya as a `` mix of common pebbles and costly crystals''.[ 101]

Particularly along the north coast of New Guinea and in the islands north and east of New Guinea, the Austronesian people, who have migrate into the area somewhat more than 3,000 years ago,[ 46] come into contact with these pre-existing populations of Papuan-speaking peoples. In the late 20th century, some scholars theorize a long period of interaction, which result in many complex changes in genetics, languages, and culture among the peoples.[ 48] Kayser, et al. propose that, from this area, a very small group of people( speak an Austronesian language) depart to the east to become the forebears of the Polynesian people.[ 49]
The first publish work devote to the concept of method be Jodocus Willichius, De methodo omnium artium et disciplinarum informanda opusculum( 1550).[ citation need]

Professionalization is the social process by which any trade or occupation establishes the group norms of conduct, acceptable qualifications for membership of the profession, a professional body or association to oversee the conduct of members of the profession, and some degree of demarcation of the qualified from unqualified amateurs.[1] The transformation into a profession brings about many subtle changes to a field of inquiry, but one more readily identifiable component of professionalization is the increasing irrelevance of "the book" to the field: "research communiqués will begin to change in ways [...] whose modern end products are obvious to all and oppressive to many. No longer will [a member's] researches usually be embodied in books addressed [...] to anyone who might be interested in the subject matter of the field. Instead they will usually appear as brief articles addressed only to professional colleagues, the men whose knowledge of a shared paradigm can be assumed and who prove to be the only one able to read the papers addressed to them."[2] Philosophy underwent this process toward the end of the 19th century, and it is one of the key distinguishing features of the contemporary philosophy era in Western philosophy.

During the Han Dynasty( 206 BC- 221 AD), boys be think ready at age seven to start learn basic skills in reading, write and calculation.[ 28] In 124 BC, the Emperor Wudi establish the Imperial Academy, the curriculum of which be the Five Classics of Confucius. By the end of the Han Dynasty( 220 AD) the Academy enrol more than 30,000 students, boys between the ages of fourteen and seventeen years. However education through this period be a luxury.[ 29]

The greatest impact come of course in France itself. In addition to effects similar to those in Italy and Switzerland, France saw the introduction of the principle of legal equality, and the downgrading of the once powerful and rich Catholic Church to just a bureau control by the government. Power become centralize in Paris, with its strong bureaucracy and an army supply by conscript all young men. French politics be permanently polarize — new names be give, `` leave'' and `` right'' for the supporters and opponents of the principles of the Revolution.

As a reaction to the decadence of Charles II era productions, sentimental comedy grow in popularity. This genre focus on encourage virtuous behavior by show middle class characters overcome a series of moral trials. Playwrights like Colley Cibber and Richard Steele believe that humans be inherently good but capable of be lead astray. Through plays such as The Conscious Lovers and Love's Last Shift they strive to appeal to an audience's noble sentiments in order that viewers could be reform.[ 67][ 68]

Contemporary continental philosophy begin with the work of Franz Brentano, Edmund Husserl, Adolf Reinach, and Martin Heidegger and the development of the philosophical method of phenomenology. This development be roughly contemporaneous with work by Gottlob Frege and Bertrand Russell inaugurate a new philosophical method base on the analysis of language via modern logic( hence the term `` analytic philosophy'').[ 17]
Theatre in the 19th century be divide into two parts: early and late. The early period be dominate by melodrama and Romanticism.

Punishment for minor crimes involve either imposition of fines, beatings, facial mutilation, or exile, depend on the severity of the offense. Serious crimes such as murder and tomb robbery be punish by execution, carry out by decapitation, drown, or impale the criminal on a stake. Punishment could also be extend to the criminal's family.[ 88] Beginning in the New Kingdom, oracles play a major role in the legal system, dispense justice in both civil and criminal cases. The procedure be to ask the god a `` yes'' or `` no'' question concern the right or wrong of an issue. The god, carry by a number of priests, render judgment by choose one or the other, move forward or backward, or point to one of the answers write on a piece of papyrus or an ostracon.[ 100]

The Republic had no fixed bureaucracy, and collected taxes through the practice of tax farming. Government positions such as quaestor, aedile, or praefect were funded by the office-holder. To prevent any citizen from gaining too much power, new magistrates were elected annually and had to share power with a colleague. For example, under normal conditions, the highest authority was held by two consuls. In an emergency, a temporary dictator could be appointed. Throughout the Republic, the administrative system was revised several times to comply with new demands. In the end, it proved inefficient for controlling the ever-expanding dominion of Rome, contributing to the establishment of the Roman Empire.

Further groundbreaking work be carry out by William Harvey, who publish De Motu Cordis in 1628. Harvey make a detailed analysis of the overall structure of the heart, go on to an analysis of the arteries, show how their pulsation depend upon the contraction of the left ventricle, while the contraction of the right ventricle propel its charge of blood into the pulmonary artery. He notice that the two ventricles move together almost simultaneously and not independently like have be think previously by his predecessors.[ 78]

Other Muslim advances in astronomy include the collection and correction of previous astronomical data, resolve significant problems in the Ptolemaic model, the development of the universal latitude-independent astrolabe by Arzachel,[ 45] the invention of numerous other astronomical instruments, Ja'far Muhammad ibn Mūsā ibn Shākir's belief that the heavenly bodies and celestial spheres be subject to the same physical laws as Earth,[ 46] the first elaborate experiments relate to astronomical phenomena, the introduction of exact empirical observations and experimental techniques,[ 47] and the introduction of empirical testing by Ibn al-Shatir, who produce the first model of lunar motion which match physical observations.[ 48]

Industrial chemistry be be practise in the mid 1800s, but it be not until the 1880s that the engineering elements require to control chemical processes be be recognize as a distinct professional activity. Chemical engineering be first establish as a profession in the United Kingdom when the first chemical engineering course be give at the University of Manchester in 1887 by George E. Davis in the form of twelve lectures cover various aspects of industrial chemical practice.[ 1] As a consequence George E. Davis be regard as the world's first chemical engineer. Today, chemical engineering be a highly regarded profession. Chemical engineers with experience can become licensed Professional Engineers in the United States, aid by the National Society of Professional Engineers, or gain `` Chartered'' chemical-engineer status through the UK-based Institution of Chemical Engineers.

The Swiss historian Jacob Burckhardt (1818–1897) in his The Civilization of the Renaissance in Italy (1860), by contrast, defined the Renaissance as the period between Giotto and Michelangelo in Italy, that is, the 14th to mid-16th centuries. He saw in the Renaissance the emergence of the modern spirit of individuality, which the Middle Ages had stifled.[101] His book was widely read and became influential in the development of the modern interpretation of the Italian Renaissance.[102] However, Buckhardt has been accused[by whom?] of setting forth a linear Whiggish view of history in seeing the Renaissance as the origin of the modern world.[13]

Most Caribbean varieties are based on British English and consequently most are non-rhotic, except for formal styles of Jamaican English which are often rhotic. Jamaican English differs from RP in its vowel inventory, which has a distinction between long and short vowels rather than tense and lax vowels as in Standard English. The diphthongs /ei/ and /ou/ are monophthongs [eː] and [oː] or even the reverse diphthongs [ie] and [uo] (e.g. bay and boat pronounced [bʲeː] and [bʷoːt]). Often word final consonant clusters are simplified so that "child" is pronounced [t͡ʃail] and "wind" [win].[271][272][273]

In 1880, the first attempt be make to form a Society of Chemical Engineers in London. This eventually result in the formation of the Society of Chemical Industry in 1881. The American Institute of Chemical Engineers( AIChE) be found in 1908, and the UK Institution of Chemical Engineers( IChemE) in 1922.[ 2] These both now have substantial international membership. Some other countries now have chemical engineering societies or sections within chemical or engineering societies, but the AIChE and IChemE remain the major ones in numbers and international spread: they be both open to suitably qualified professionals or students of chemical engineering anywhere in the world.

Gimmicks also proliferate to lure in audiences. The fad for 3-D film would last for only two years, 1952–1954, and help sell House of Wax and Creature from the Black Lagoon. Producer William Castle would tout films feature `` Emergo'' `` Percepto'', the first of a series of gimmicks that would remain popular marketing tools for Castle and others throughout the 1960s.

At its economic height, in the 5th and 4th centuries BC, ancient Greece be the most advanced economy in the world. According to some economic historians, it be one of the most advanced preindustrial economies. This be demonstrate by the average daily wage of the Greek worker which be, in terms of wheat, about 12 kg. This be more than 3 times the average daily wage of an Egyptian worker during the Roman period, about 3.75 kg.[ 30]

In the late eighteenth century Immanuel Kant set forth a groundbreaking philosophical system which claim to bring unity to rationalism and empiricism. Whether or not he be right, he do not entirely succeed in end philosophical dispute. Kant spark a storm of philosophical work in Germany in the early nineteenth century, begin with German idealism. The characteristic theme of idealism be that the world and the mind equally must be understood accord to the same categories; it culminate in the work of Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel, who among many other things say that `` The real be rational; the rational be real.''

Most films of this period be what come to be call `` chase films''. These be inspire by James Williamson's Stop Thief! of 1901, which show a tramp steal a leg of mutton from a butcher's boy in the first shot, then be chase through the second shot by the butcher's boy and assorted dogs, and finally be catch by the dogs in the third shot. Several British films make in the first half of 1903 extend the chase method of film construction. These include An Elopement à la Mode and The Pickpocket: A Chase Through London, make by Alf Collins for the British branch of the French Gaumont company, Daring Daylight Burglary, make by Frank Mottershaw at the Sheffield Photographic Company, and Desperate Poaching Affray, make by William Haggar. Haggar in particular innovate the first extant pan shots; the poachers be chase by gamekeepers and police officers and the camera pan along, create a sense of urgency and speed.[ 17] His films be also recognise for their intelligent use of depth of stag and screen edges, while film academic Noël Burch praise Haggar's effective use of off-screen space.[ 18] He be also one of the first film makers to purposefully introduce violence for entertainment; in Desperate Poaching Affray the villains be see fire guns at their pursuers.

Moroccan nationalism develop during the 1930s; the Istiqlal Party be form, push for independence. In 1953 sultan Mohammed V of Morocco call for independence. On March 2, 1956, Morocco become independent of France. Mohammed V become ruler of independent Morocco.[ 226]

Ancient Egyptian has 25 consonants similar to those of other Afro-Asiatic languages. These include pharyngeal and emphatic consonants, voiced and voiceless stops, voiceless fricatives and voiced and voiceless affricates. It has three long and three short vowels, which expanded in Later Egyptian to about nine.[128] The basic word in Egyptian, similar to Semitic and Berber, is a triliteral or biliteral root of consonants and semiconsonants. Suffixes are added to form words. The verb conjugation corresponds to the person. For example, the triconsonantal skeleton S-Ḏ-M is the semantic core of the word 'hear'; its basic conjugation is sḏm, 'he hears'. If the subject is a noun, suffixes are not added to the verb:[129] sḏm ḥmt, 'the woman hears'.

Eriksen and Nielsen use the term proto-anthropology to refer to near-anthropological writings, which contain some of the criteria for be anthropology, but not all. They classify proto-anthropology as be `` travel writing or social philosophy,'' go on to assert `` It be only when these aspects ... be fuse, that be, when data and theory be bring together, that anthropology appear. ``[ 21] This process begin to occur in the 18th century of the Age of Enlightenment.

In a gift economy, valuable goods and services be regularly give without any explicit agreement for immediate or future rewards( i.e. there be no formal quid pro quo).[ 7] Ideally, simultaneous or recur give serves to circulate and redistribute valuables within the community.

Revolutionary movements and right-wing military dictatorships become common after World War II, but since the 1980s, a wave of democratisation come through the continent, and democratic rule be widespread now.[ 50] Nonetheless, allegations of corruption be still very common, and several countries have develop crises which have force the resignation of their governments, although, in most occasions, regular civilian succession have continue.

Bala argue that by ignore such multicultural impacts we have be lead to a Eurocentric conception of the scientific revolution.[ 126] However he clearly state: `` The makers of the revolution – Copernicus, Kepler, Galileo, Descartes, Newton, and many others – have to selectively appropriate relevant ideas, transform them, and create new auxiliary concepts in order to complete their task ... In the ultimate analysis, even if the revolution be root upon a multicultural base it be the accomplishment of Europeans in Europe. ``[ 127] Critics note that lack documentary evidence of transmission of specific scientific ideas, Bala's model will remain `` a working hypothesis, not a conclusion''.[ 128]

Negation is done with the adverb not, which precedes the main verb and follows an auxiliary verb. A contracted form of not -n't can be used as an enclitic attaching to auxiliary verbs and to the copula verb to be. Just as with questions, many negative constructions require the negation to occur with do-support, thus in Modern English I don't know him is the correct answer to the question Do you know him?, but not *I know him not, although this construction may be found in older English.[191]

Medicine provide another example of practically orient investigation of nature among the Ancient Greeks. It have be point out that Greek medicine be not the province of a single trained profession and there be no accepted method of qualification of licensing. Physicians in the Hippocratic tradition, temple healers associate with the cult of Asclepius, herb collectors, drug sellers, midwives, and gymnastic trainers all claim to be qualify as healers in specific contexts and compete actively for patients.[ 3] This rivalry among these compete traditions contribute to an active public debate about the causes and proper treatment of disease, and about the general methodological approaches of their rivals. In the Hippocratic text, On the Sacred Disease, which deal with the nature of epilepsy, the author attack his rivals( temple healers) for their ignorance and for their love of gain. The author of this text seem modern and progressive when he insist that epilepsy have a natural cause, yet when he come to explain what that cause be and what the proper treatment would be, his explanation be as short on specific evidence and his treatment as vague as that of his rivals.[ 4]

Until the late 1930s, defence be not a significant issue for Australians. At the 1937 elections, both political parties advocate increase defence spending, in the context of increase Japanese aggression in China and Germany's aggression in Europe. There be a difference in opinion over how the defence spending should be allocate however. The United Australia Party government emphasise co-operation with Britain in `` a policy of imperial defence.'' The lynchpin of this be the British naval base at Singapore and the Royal Navy battle fleet `` which, it be hop, would use it in time of need. ``[ 302] Defence spending in the inter-war years reflect this priority. In the period 1921–1936 total £40 million on the Royal Australian Navy, £20 million on the Australian Army and £6 million on the Royal Australian Air Force( establish in 1921, the `` youngest'' of the three services). In 1939, the Navy, which include two heavy cruisers and four light cruisers, be the service best equip for war.[ 303]

During the 14th century, there be small companies of actors in Japan who perform short, sometimes vulgar comedies. A director of one of these companies, Kan'ami( 1333–1384), have a son, Zeami Motokiyo( 1363–1443) who be consider one of the finest child actors in Japan. When Kan'ami's company perform for Ashikaga Yoshimitsu( 1358–1408), the Shogun of Japan, he implore Zeami to have a court education for his arts. After Zeami succeed his father, he continue to perform and adapt his style into what be today Noh. A mixture of pantomime and vocal acrobatics, this style have fascinate the Japanese for hundreds of years.

Extraordinary sporting successes did something to alleviate the spirits of Australians during the economic downturn. In a Sheffield Shield cricket match at the Sydney Cricket Ground in 1930, Don Bradman, a young New South Welshman of just 21 years of age wrote his name into the record books by smashing the previous highest batting score in first-class cricket with 452 runs not out in just 415 minutes.[298] The rising star's world beating cricketing exploits were to provide Australians with much needed joy through the emerging Great Depression and post-World War II recovery. Between 1929 and 1931 the racehorse Phar Lap dominated Australia's racing industry, at one stage winning fourteen races in a row.[299] Famous victories included the 1930 Melbourne Cup, following an assassination attempt and carrying 9 stone 12 pounds weight.[300] Phar Lap sailed for the United States in 1931, going on to win North America's richest race, the Agua Caliente Handicap in 1932. Soon after, on the cusp of US success, Phar Lap developed suspicious symptoms and died. Theories swirled that the champion race horse had been poisoned and a devoted Australian public went in to shock.[301] The 1938 British Empire Games were held in Sydney from 5–12 February, timed to coincide with Sydney's sesqui-centenary (150 years since the foundation of British settlement in Australia).

In 1828, Shaka be assassinate by his half brother Dingane, who lack the military genius and leadership skills of Shaka. Voortrekkers try to occupy Zulu land in 1838. In the early months they be defeat, but the survivors regroup at the Ncome River and soundly defeat the Zulu. However, the Voortrekkers dare not settle Zulu land. Dingane be kill in 1840 during a civil war. His brother Mpande take over and strengthened Zulu territories to the north. In 1879 the Zulu Kingdom be invade by Britain in a quest to control all of South Africa. The Zulu Kingdom be victorious at the Battle of Isandlwana but be defeat at the Battle of Ulundi.[ 202][ 203]

The 18th century saw the whole of Rajputana virtually subdued by the Marathas. The Second Anglo-Maratha War distracted the Marathas from 1807 to 1809, but afterwards Maratha domination of Rajputana resumed. In 1817, the British went to war with the Pindaris, raiders who were based in Maratha territory, which quickly became the Third Anglo-Maratha War, and the British government offered its protection to the Rajput rulers from the Pindaris and the Marathas. By the end of 1818 similar treaties had been executed between the other Rajput states and Britain. The Maratha Sindhia ruler of Gwalior gave up the district of Ajmer-Merwara to the British, and Maratha influence in Rajasthan came to an end.[331] Most of the Rajput princes remained loyal to Britain in the Revolt of 1857, and few political changes were made in Rajputana until Indian independence in 1947. The Rajputana Agency contained more than 20 princely states, most notable being Udaipur State, Jaipur State, Bikaner State and Jodhpur State.

Phillip sent exploratory missions in search of better soils, fixed on the Parramatta region as a promising area for expansion, and moved many of the convicts from late 1788 to establish a small township, which became the main centre of the colony's economic life. This left Sydney Cove only as an important port and focus of social life. Poor equipment and unfamiliar soils and climate continued to hamper the expansion of farming from Farm Cove to Parramatta and Toongabbie, but a building program, assisted by convict labour, advanced steadily. Between 1788 and 1792, convicts and their gaolers made up the majority of the population—but after this, a population of emancipated convicts began to grow who could be granted land and these people pioneered a non-government private sector economy and were later joined by soldiers whose military service had expired—and finally, free settlers who began arriving from Britain. Governor Phillip departed the colony for England on 11 December 1792, with the new settlement having survived near starvation and immense isolation for four years.[133] On 16 February 1793 the first free settlers arrived. The settlers: Thomas Rose, with his wife and four children, Edward Powell, Thomas Webb, Joseph Webb, and Frederick Meredith.[135]

Another approach to approximate a definition of continental philosophy be by list some of the philosophical movements that be or have be central in continental philosophy: German idealism, phenomenology, existentialism( and its antecedents, such as the thought of Kierkegaard and Nietzsche), hermeneutics, structuralism, post-structuralism, French feminism, and the critical theory of the Frankfurt School and some other branches of Western Marxism.[ 32]

A suitable environment have develop to question scientific doctrine. The discovery in 1492 of the New World by Christopher Columbus challenge the classical worldview. The works of Ptolemy( in geography) and Galen( in medicine) be find to not always match everyday observations. As the Protestant Reformation and Counter-Reformation clash, the Northern Renaissance show a decisive shift in focus from Aristotelean natural philosophy to chemistry and the biological sciences( botany, anatomy, and medicine).[ 57] The willingness to question previously hold truths and search for new answers result in a period of major scientific advancements.

Few contemporary Western readers of Hessen took his paper at face value. His rigid connection between economy and knowledge was not accepted by a majority of historians. However, his assertion that a connection existed between the growth of knowledge and the art of war, and that ballistics played a central part of physics and Newton's world, was viewed with keen interest. In the shadow of the first war to employ chemical weapons, and as the war machines were again gearing up in preparation for another world war, the role between science, technology, and warfare was becoming more interesting to scholars and scientists. Previous views of science as separate from the mundane or vulgar aspects of practical life — the disembodiment of the scientific mind from its context — were becoming less attractive than a view that science and scientists were increasingly embedded in the world in which they worked.

In the interest of national glory, the Chinese begin send impressive junk ships across the South China Sea and the Indian Ocean. From 1403 to 1433, the Yongle Emperor commission expeditions lead by the admiral Zheng He, a Muslim eunuch from China. Chinese junks carry hundreds of soldiers, goods, and animals for zoos, travel to Southeast Asia, Persia, southern Arabia, and east Africa to show off Chinese power. Their prowess exceed that of current Europeans at the time, and have these expeditions not end, the world economy may be different from today.[ 29] In 1433, the Chinese government decide that the cost of a navy be an unnecessary expense. The Chinese navy be slowly dismantle and focus on interior reform and military defense begin. It be China's longstanding priority that they protect themselves from nomads and they have accordingly return to it. The grow limits on the Chinese navy would leave them vulnerable to foreign invasion by sea later on.

The Victorian era of the United Kingdom be the period of Queen Victoria's reign from June 1837 to January 1901. This be a long period of prosperity for the British people, as profits gain from the overseas British Empire, as well as from industrial improvements at home, allow a large, educate middle class to develop. Some scholars would extend the beginning of the period—as define by a variety of sensibilities and political games that have come to be associate with the Victorians—back five years to the passage of the Reform Act 1832.

Unlike Bacon, Descartes successfully apply his own ideas in practice. He make significant contributions to science, in particular in aberration-corrected optics. His work in analytic geometry be a necessary precedent to differential calculus and instrumental in bring mathematical analysis to bear on scientific matters.

The United States originally used horse-powered machinery for small scale applications such as grain milling, but eventually switched to water power after textile factories began being built in the 1790s. As a result, industrialisation was concentrated in New England and the Northeastern United States, which has fast-moving rivers. The newer water-powered production lines proved more economical than horse-drawn production. In the late 19th century steam-powered manufacturing overtook water-powered manufacturing, allowing the industry to spread to the Midwest.

Marxist anthropologist Eric Wolf once characterize anthropology as `` the most scientific of the humanities, and the most humanistic of the social sciences.'' Understanding how anthropology develop contributes to understand how it fit into other academic disciplines. Scholarly traditions of jurisprudence, history, philology and sociology develop during this time and inform the development of the social sciences of which anthropology be a part. At the same time, the Romantic reaction to the Enlightenment produce thinkers such as Herder and later Wilhelm Dilthey whose work form the basis for the culture concept which be central to the discipline.

Australia enjoy significant growth in prosperity in the 1950s and 1960s, with increases in both living standards and in leisure time.[ 351][ 352] The manufacturing industry, previously play a minor part in an economy dominate by primary production, greatly expand. The first Holden motor car come out of General Motors-Holden's Fisherman's Bend factory in November 1948. Car ownership rapidly increased—from 130 owners in every 1,000 in 1949 to 271 owners in every 1,000 by 1961.[ 353] By the early 1960s, four competitors to Holden have set up Australian factories, employ between 80,000 and 100,000 workers, `` at least four-fifths of them migrants. ``[ 354]

Upon the outbreak of a cholera epidemic in Alexandria, Egypt, two medical missions went to investigate and attend the sick, one was sent out by Pasteur and the other actually led by Koch.[94] Koch's group returned victorious in 1883, having discovered the cholera pathogen.[94] In Germany, however, Koch's bacteriologists had to vie against Max von Pettenkofer, Germany's leading proponent of miasmatic theory.[95] Pettenkofer conceded bacteria's casual involvement, but maintained that other, environmental factors were required to turn it pathogenic, and opposed water treatment as a misdirected effort amid more important ways to improve public health.[95] The massive cholera epidemic in Hamburg in 1892 devastasted Pettenkoffer's position, and yielded German public health to "Koch's bacteriology".[95]

Both yes–no questions and wh-questions in English are mostly formed using subject–auxiliary inversion (Am I going tomorrow?, Where can we eat?), which may require do-support (Do you like her?, Where did he go?). In most cases, interrogative words (wh-words; e.g. what, who, where, when, why, how) appear in a fronted position. For example, in the question What did you see?, the word what appears as the first constituent despite being the grammatical object of the sentence. (When the wh-word is the subject or forms part of the subject, no inversion occurs: Who saw the cat?.) Prepositional phrases can also be fronted when they are the question's theme, e.g. To whose house did you go last night?. The personal interrogative pronoun who is the only interrogative pronoun to still show inflection for case, with the variant whom serving as the objective case form, although this form may be going out of use in many contexts.[193]

New technologies, such as biotechnology and computer science( for data processing and storage), and technological advances have make it possible to develop new research fields, include genetic engineering, improved statistical analysis, and precision farming.

In Mesoamerica, the Aztecs be active farmers and have an agriculturally focused economy. The land around Lake Texcoco be fertile, but not large enough to produce the amount of food need for the population of their expanding empire. The Aztecs develop irrigation systems, form terraced hillsides, fertilize their soil, and develop chinampas or artificial islands, also know as `` float gardens''. The Mayas between 400 BC to 900 AD use extensive canal and raise field systems to farm swampland on the Yucatán Peninsula.[ 61][ 62]

In the Southwest of North America, Hohokam and Anasazi societies have be engage in agricultural production with ditch irrigation and a sedentary village life for at least two millennia before the Spanish arrive in the 1540s.[ 21] Upon the arrival of the Europeans in the `` New World'', native peoples find their culture change drastically. As such, their affiliation with political and cultural groups change as well, several linguistic groups go extinct, and others change quite quickly. The name and cultures that Europeans record for the natives be not necessarily the same as the ones they have use a few generations before, or the ones in use today.

The application of steam power to the industrial processes of printing support a massive expansion of newspaper and popular book publishing, which reinforce rise literacy and demands for mass political participation.

The doubling of the Cape of Good Hope in 1487 by Bartolomeu Dias first bring explorers within touch of the Antarctic cold, and prove that there be an ocean separating Africa from any Antarctic land that might exist.
The philosophes spent a great deal of energy disseminating their ideas among educated men and women in cosmopolitan cities. They used many venues, some of them quite new.

A genetic study of Agricultural science begin with Gregor Mendel's work. Using statistical methods, Mendel develop the model of Mendelian inheritance which accurately describe the inheritance of dominant and recessive genes. His results be controversial at the time and be not widely accept.

The earliest known physician be also credit to ancient Egypt: Hesy-Ra, `` Chief of Dentists and Physicians'' for King Djoser in the 27th century BCE.[ 11] Also, the earliest know woman physician, Peseshet, practice in Ancient Egypt at the time of the 4th dynasty. Her title be `` Lady Overseer of the Lady Physicians.'' In addition to her supervisory role, Peseshet train midwives at an ancient Egyptian medical school in Sais.[ citation need]

Les Fauves (French for The Wild Beasts) were early-20th-century painters, experimenting with freedom of expression through color. The name was given, humorously and not as a compliment, to the group by art critic Louis Vauxcelles. Fauvism was a short-lived and loose grouping of early-20th-century artists whose works emphasized painterly qualities, and the imaginative use of deep color over the representational values. Fauvists made the subject of the painting easy to read, exaggerated perspectives and an interesting prescient prediction of the Fauves was expressed in 1888 by Paul Gauguin to Paul Sérusier,

Modern history, the modern period or the modern era, be the global historiographical approach to the timeframe after the Post-classical history.[ 1][ 2] Modern history can be further break down into periods:

The late Bronze Age Urnfield culture,( 1300–700 BC) be characterize by cremation burials. It include the Lusatian culture in eastern Germany and Poland( 1300–500 BC) that continue into the Iron Age. The Central European Bronze Age be follow by the Iron Age Hallstatt culture( 700–450 BC).

Oceania be first explore by Europeans from the 16th century onwards. Portuguese navigators, between 1512 and 1526, reach the Moluccas( by António de Abreu and Francisco Serrão in 1512), Timor, the Aru Islands( Martim A. Melo Coutinho), the Tanimbar Islands, some of the Caroline Islands( by Gomes de Sequeira in 1525), and west Papua New Guinea( by Jorge de Menezes in 1526). In 1519 a Castilian('Spanish') expedition lead by Ferdinand Magellan sail down the east coast of South America, find and sail through the strait that bear his name and on 28 November 1520 enter the ocean which they name `` Pacific''. The three remain ships, lead by Magellan and his captains Duarte Barbosa and João Serrão, then sail north and catch the trade wind which carry them across the Pacific to the Philippines where Magellan be kill. One survive ship lead by Juan Sebastián Elcano return west across the Indian Ocean and the other go north in the hope of find the westerlies and reach Mexico. Unable to find the right winds, it be force to return to the East Indies. The Magellan-Elcano expedition achieve the first circumnavigation of the world and reach the Philippines, the Mariana Islands and other islands of Oceania.

Supernova SN1987A was observed by astronomers on Earth both visually, and in a triumph for neutrino astronomy, by the solar neutrino detectors at Kamiokande. But the solar neutrino flux was a fraction of its theoretically expected value. This discrepancy forced a change in some values in the standard model for particle physics.

The Middle Stone Age was a period of African prehistory between Early Stone Age and Late Stone Age. It began around 300,000 years ago and ended around 50,000 years ago.[61] It is considered as an equivalent of European Middle Paleolithic.[62] It is associated with anatomically modern or almost modern Homo sapiens. Early physical evidence comes from Omo [63] and Herto,[64] both in Ethiopia and dated respectively at c. 195 ka and at c. 160 ka.

The period between AD 320–550 is known as the Classical Age, when most of North India was reunited under the Gupta Empire (c. AD 320–550). This was a period of relative peace, law and order, and extensive achievements in religion, education, mathematics, arts, Sanskrit literature and drama. Grammar, composition, logic, metaphysics, mathematics, medicine, and astronomy became increasingly specialized and reached an advanced level. The Gupta Empire was weakened and ultimately ruined by the raids of Hunas (a branch of the Hephthalites emanating from Central Asia). Under Harsha (r. 606–47), North India was reunited briefly.

Australia recover relatively quickly from the financial downturn of 1929–1930, with recovery begin around 1932. The Prime Minister, Joseph Lyons, favour the tough economic measures of the Premiers' Plan, pursue an orthodox fiscal policy and refuse to accept the proposals of the Premier of New South Wales, Jack Lang, to default on overseas debt repayments. According to author Anne Henderson of the Sydney Institute, Lyons hold a steadfast belief in `` the need to balance budgets, lower costs to business and restore confidence'' and the Lyons period give Australia `` stability and eventual growth'' between the drama of the Depression and the outbreak of the Second World War. A lowering of wages be enforce and industry tariff protections maintain, which together with cheaper raw materials during the 1930s saw a shift from agriculture to manufacturing as the chief employer of the Australian economy—a shift which be consolidate by increase investment by the commonwealth government into defence and armaments manufacture. Lyons saw restoration of Australia's exports as the key to economic recovery.[ 291]

With the emergence of the Parthians and Sassanids there was an appearance of new forms. Parthian innovations fully flowered during the Sassanid period with massive barrel-vaulted chambers, solid masonry domes, and tall columns. This influence was to remain for years to come. The roundness of the city of Baghdad in the Abbasid era for example, points to its Persian precedents such as Firouzabad in Fars.[9] The two designers who were hired by al-Mansur to plan the city's design were Naubakht, a former Persian Zoroastrian who also determined that the date of the foundation of the city would be astrologically auspicious, and Mashallah, a former Jew from Khorasan. The ruins of Persepolis, Ctesiphon, Jiroft,[10] Sialk, Pasargadae, Firouzabad, Arg-é Bam, and thousands of other ruins may give us merely a distant glimpse of what contribution Persians made to the art of building.
Portugal

Ancient music be music that develop in literate cultures, replace prehistoric music. Ancient music refers to the various musical systems that be develop across various geographical regions such as Persia, India, China, Greece, Rome, Egypt and Mesopotamia( see music of Mesopotamia, music of ancient Greece, music of ancient Rome, Music of Iran). Ancient music be designate by the characterization of the basic audible tones and scales. It may have be transmit through oral or write systems. Arts of the ancient world refers to the many types of art that be in the cultures of ancient societies, such as those of ancient China, Egypt, Greece, India, Persia, Mesopotamia and Rome.

Of particular note be the use in Chinese mathematics of a decimal positional notation system, the so-called `` rod numerals'' in which distinct ciphers be use for numbers between 1 and 10, and additional ciphers for powers of ten.[ 82] Thus, the number 123 would be write use the symbol for `` 1'', follow by the symbol for `` 100'', then the symbol for `` 2'' follow by the symbol for `` 10'', follow by the symbol for `` 3''. This be the most advanced number system in the world at the time, apparently in use several centuries before the common era and well before the development of the Indian numeral system.[ 83] Rod numerals allow the representation of numbers as large as desired and allow calculations to be carry out on the suan pan, or Chinese abacus. The date of the invention of the suan pan be not certain, but the earliest write mention dates from AD 190, in Xu Yue's Supplementary Notes on the Art of Figures.

Benin was never a significant exporter of slaves, as Alan Ryder's book Benin and the Europeans showed. By the early 18th century, it was wrecked with dynastic disputes and civil wars. However, it regained much of its former power in the reigns of Oba Eresoyen and Oba Akengbuda. After the 16th century, Benin mainly exported pepper, ivory, gum, and cotton cloth to the Portuguese and Dutch who resold it to other African societies on the coast. In 1897, the British sacked the city.[192]

The Ottomans united the whole region under one ruler for the first time since the reign of the Abbasid caliphs of the 10th century, and they kept control of it for 400 years, despite brief intermissions created by the Iranian Safavids and Afsharids. "The Ottoman Empires was one of the greatest, most extensive, and long lasting in the History of the World. It included most of the territories of the Eastern Roman Empire(...)and held portions that the Byzantines never ruled (...)The Ottoman Empire was born in 1300 and endured until World War I-."[15]

Economic motivations for the practical use of geological data caused governments to support geological research. During the 19th century the governments of several countries including Canada, Australia, Great Britain and the United States funded geological surveying that would produce geological maps of vast areas of the countries. Geological surveying provides the location of useful minerals and such information could be used to benefit the country’s mining industry. With the government funding of geological research, more individuals could study geology with better technology and techniques, leading to the expansion of the field of geology.[11]

The High Middle Ages was a period of tremendous expansion of population. The estimated population of Europe grew from 35 to 80 million between 1000 and 1347, although the exact causes remain unclear: improved agricultural techniques, the decline of slaveholding, a more clement climate and the lack of invasion have all been suggested.[157][158] As much as 90 per cent of the European population remained rural peasants. Many were no longer settled in isolated farms but had gathered into small communities, usually known as manors or villages.[158] These peasants were often subject to noble overlords and owed them rents and other services, in a system known as manorialism. There remained a few free peasants throughout this period and beyond,[159] with more of them in the regions of Southern Europe than in the north. The practice of assarting, or bringing new lands into production by offering incentives to the peasants who settled them, also contributed to the expansion of population.[160]

Churches were built with more and more windows and the use of colorful stained glass become a staple in decoration. One of the most famous examples of this is found in the cathedral of Notre Dame de Paris. By the 14th century Western societies were both richer and more cultivated and painters found new patrons in the nobility and even the bourgeoisie. Illuminated manuscripts took on a new character and slim, fashionably dressed court women were shown in their landscapes. This style soon became known as International Gothic and tempera panel paintings and altarpieces gained importance.

Henry Maudslay, who train a school of machine tool makers early in the 19th century, be a mechanic with superior ability who have be employ at the Royal Arsenal, Woolwich. He be hire away by Joseph Bramah for the production of high security metal lock that require precision craftsmanship. Bramah patent a lathe that have similarities to the slide rest lathe. Maudslay perfect the slide rest lathe, which could cut machine screws of different thread pitches by use changeable gears between the spindle and the lead screw. Before its invention screws could not be cut to any precision use various earlier lathe designs, some of which copy from a template.[ 15][ 30] :392–95 The slide rest lathe be call one of history's most important inventions, although not entirely Maudslay's idea.[ 15] :31, 36

Ancient astronomers were able to differentiate between stars and planets, as stars remain relatively fixed over the centuries while planets will move an appreciable amount during a comparatively short time.

Renaissance art mark a cultural rebirth at the close of the Middle Ages and rise of the Modern world. One of the distinguishing features of Renaissance art be its development of highly realistic linear perspective. Giotto di Bondone( 1267–1337) be credit with first treat a painting as a window into space, but it be not until the demonstrations of architect Filippo Brunelleschi( 1377–1446) and the subsequent writings of Leon Battista Alberti( 1404–1472) that perspective be formalize as an artistic technique.[ 49]

The Indus Valley Civilization (IVC) was a Bronze Age civilization (3300–1300 BCE; mature period 2600–1900 BCE) which was centered mostly in the western part of the Indian Subcontinent; it is considered that an early form of Hinduism was performed during this civilization. Some of the great cities of this civilization include Harappa and Mohenjo-daro, which had a high level of town planning and arts. The cause of the destruction of these regions around 1700 BCE is debatable, although evidence suggests it was caused by natural disasters (especially flooding).[3] This era marks Vedic period in India, which lasted from roughly 1500 to 500 BCE. During this period, the Sanskrit language developed and the Vedas were written, epic hymns that told tales of gods and wars. This was the basis for the Vedic religion, which would eventually sophisticate and develop into Hinduism, a religion based on the caste system of class (which consisted of the four varnas), the brahman priesthood, and the developing semi-monotheism.[4]

Midway through the 19th century, the focus of geology shifted from description and classification to attempts to understand how the surface of the Earth had changed. The first comprehensive theories of mountain building were proposed during this period, as were the first modern theories of earthquakes and volcanoes. Louis Agassiz and others established the reality of continent-covering ice ages, and "fluvialists" like Andrew Crombie Ramsay argued that river valleys were formed, over millions of years by the rivers that flow through them. After the discovery of radioactivity, radiometric dating methods were developed, starting in the 20th century. Alfred Wegener's theory of "continental drift" was widely dismissed when he proposed it in the 1910s, but new data gathered in the 1950s and 1960s led to the theory of plate tectonics, which provided a plausible mechanism for it. Plate tectonics also provided a unified explanation for a wide range of seemingly unrelated geological phenomena. Since 1970 it has served as the unifying principle in geology.

Wallonia was also the birthplace of a strong Socialist party and strong trade-unions in a particular sociological landscape. At the left, the Sillon industriel, which runs from Mons in the west, to Verviers in the east (except part of North Flanders, in another period of the industrial revolution, after 1920). Even if Belgium is the second industrial country after Britain, the effect of the industrial revolution there was very different. In 'Breaking stereotypes', Muriel Neven and Isabelle Devious say:

The first evidence of recognition that astronomical phenomena be periodic and of the application of mathematics to their prediction be Babylonian. Tablets date back to the Old Babylonian period document the application of mathematics to the variation in the length of daylight over a solar year. Centuries of Babylonian observations of celestial phenomena be record in the series of cuneiform tablets know as the Enūma Anu Enlil. The oldest significant astronomical text that we possess be Tablet 63 of the Enūma Anu Enlil, the Venus tablet of Ammi-saduqa, which list the first and last visible risings of Venus over a period of about 21 years and be the earliest evidence that the phenomena of a planet be recognize as periodic. The MUL.APIN, contain catalogues of stars and constellations as well as schemes for predict heliacal risings and the settings of the planets, lengths of daylight measure by a water clock, gnomon, shadows, and intercalations. The Babylonian GU text arrange stars in'strings' that lie along declination circles and thus measure right-ascensions or time-intervals, and also employ the stars of the zenith, which be also separate by give right-ascensional differences.[ 16]

Pāṇini (c. 4th century BCE) opposes the Yāska view that sentences are primary, and proposes a grammar for composing semantics from morphemic roots. Transcending the ritual text to consider living language, Pāṇini specifies a comprehensive set of about 4,000 aphoristic rules (sutras) that:

The golden ratio seem to be reflect in many Egyptian constructions, include the pyramids, but its use may have be an unintended consequence of the ancient Egyptian practice of combine the use of knot ropes with an intuitive sense of proportion and harmony.[ 210]
A number of aesthetic movements continued or emerged in the 20th century, including:

`` Manifest destiny'' be the belief that the United States be destine to expand across the North American continent, from the Atlantic seaboard to the Pacific Ocean. During this time, the United States expand to the Pacific Ocean—'' from sea to shin sea'' —largely define the borders of the contiguous United States as they be today.[ citation need]

Throughout the 19th century, chemistry was divided between those who followed the atomic theory of John Dalton and those who did not, such as Wilhelm Ostwald and Ernst Mach.[56] Although such proponents of the atomic theory as Amedeo Avogadro and Ludwig Boltzmann made great advances in explaining the behavior of gases, this dispute was not finally settled until Jean Perrin's experimental investigation of Einstein's atomic explanation of Brownian motion in the first decade of the 20th century.[56]
